Sec. 17-34. Abatement Hearing:
If the recipient of the notice of abatement makes a written request for hearing within the notice period,
then the city shall immediately schedule a hearing during a regular business day. The hearing shall be
conducted by a designated public officer who shall receive evidence, review the investigation and
prepare a written order. The order shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to all relevant
parties within ten (10) days of the hearing, unless otherwise stated at the hearing, and prior to the city
taking any action to abate the violation.
The order shall describe the relevant facts relied upon, state the specific code provisions being relied
upon should a violation be found, and state any such other stipulations, methods of abatement or orders
as deemed necessary. (Ord. 95-44, § 1, 12-20-1995; Ord. 02-04, § 4, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-35. Abatement By The City:
If the property owner, representative or tenant fails to request a hearing and fails to abate the violations
within the notice period, then the city may go onto the property to abate the violation in a reasonable
manner. The city shall not be responsible for damage to property due to reasonable methods of gaining
entrance onto the property or for damages to property in the reasonable exercise of its duty to the public
to abate the violations. The city may use its own employees or contract for services to abate violations of
this article. (Ord. 95-44, § 1, 12-20-1995)
Sec. 17-36. Notice Of Cost; Assessment And Collection:
(a) If the city takes action to abate the violation, it shall provide a notice of costs to the property owner,
representative or tenant. The notice of costs shall be delivered by personal service or restricted mail,
return receipt requested, at the last known mailing address; or if the property is vacant or
unoccupied, the notice of costs may also be posted on the property in a reasonable manner. The
notice of costs shall state:
(1) The common or legal description of the property, or both;
(2) The nature of the violation, including relevant ordinances;
(3) The nature of the work performed to abate the violation;
(4) The costs incurred for the abatement of the violations in either a lump sum or in itemized form;
(5) That the notice is a demand for payment within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice;
(6) That failure to pay the entire amount within thirty (30) days shall allow the City to file a tax lien
against the property or to pursue litigation for the recovery of the costs, or both;
(7) That such additional remedies to recover costs shall include additional amounts, including
additional administrative costs, attorney fees when applicable, and interest;
(8) That payments shall be made by check or money order made payable to the City, with no postdating
of the check, and sent to the address stated within the notice, with a written indication of the
purpose for the payment and the address of the property where the violations occurred. Partial
payments will not be accepted and shall be considered as nonpayments.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 256/510
(b) If the payment of costs is not made within the thirty (30) day period, the City may levy a special
assessment for such cost against the lot or piece of land. The City Clerk, at the time of certifying
other City taxes to the County Clerk, shall certify the aforesaid costs, and the County Clerk shall
extend the same on the tax roll of the County against the lot or parcel of ground, and it shall be
collected by the County Treasurer and paid to the City as other City taxes are collected and paid.
Provided further, the City may collect the costs in the manner provided at K.S.A. 12-1,115, and
amendments thereto, by bringing an action in the appropriate court as a personal debt.
The City may pursue both assessment and collection at the same time until the full cost, including
applicable interest, court costs, attorney fees and administrative cost have been paid in full. (Ord. 95-44,
§ 1, 12-20-1995)
Sec. 17-37. Action In Municipal Court:
If an authorized public officer determines that a violation of this Article exists, the officer may file a
complaint with the Municipal Court for such violation. No other procedures are required as a prerequisite
to the filing of a complaint. (Ord. 95-44, § 1, 12-20-1995)
Sec. 17-38. Penalty:
(a) Any property owner, representative or tenant found in violation of this Chapter shall be subject to
prosecution in the Emporia Municipal Court. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this
Article shall be subject to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00); or imprisonment for a term not to exceed thirty (30) days; or both;
(b) Prosecution of any offender under this Chapter does not limit the City's right to abate any violation
under this Article or to additionally pursue assessment or collection of costs as stated in this Article or
by other laws;
(c) Each day that any violation of this Article continues shall constitute a separate offense;
(d) The City shall further have the authority to maintain suits or actions in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing any provision of this Article, to seek civil penalties, to abate
nuisances maintained in violation thereof, and in addition to seek other remedies, institute injunction,
mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful nuisance or
condition. (Ord. 95-44, § 1, 12-20-1995)
ARTICLE IV. INSURANCE PROCEEDS
Sec. 17-39. Scope And Application:
The City is hereby authorized to utilize the procedures established by K.S.A. 40-3901 et seq., whereby
no insurance company shall pay a claim of a named insured for loss or damage to any building or other
structure located within the City, arising out of any fire, explosion, or windstorm, where the amount
recoverable for the loss or damage to the building or other structure under all policies is in excess of
seventy five percent (75%) of the face value of the policy covering such building or other insured
structure, unless there is compliance with the procedures set out in this Article. (Ord. 97-23, § 1, 9-3-
1997)
Sec. 17-40. Lien Created:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 257/510
The Governing Body of the City hereby creates a lien in favor of the City on the proceeds of any
insurance policy based upon a covered claim payment made for damage or loss to a building or other
structure located within the City, caused by or arising out of any fire, explosion, or windstorm, where the
amount recoverable for all the loss or damage to the building or other structure under all policies is in
excess of seventy five percent (75%) of the face value of the policy(s) covering such building or other
insured structure. The lien arises upon any unpaid tax, special ad valorem levy, or any other charge
imposed upon real property by or on behalf of the City which is an encumbrance on real property,
whether or not evidenced by written instrument, or such tax, levy, assessment, expense or other charge
that has remained undischarged for at least one year prior to the filing of a proof of loss. (Ord. 97-23, §
1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-40.1. Lien Created; Encumbrances:
Prior to final settlement on any claim covered by Section 17-40 of this Article, the insurer or insurers
shall contact the County Treasurer, Lyon County, Kansas, to determine whether any such encumbrances
are presently in existence. If the same are found to exist, the insurer or insurers shall execute and
transmit in an amount equal to that owning under the encumbrances a draft payable to the County
Treasurer, Lyon County, Kansas. (Ord. 97-23, § 1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-40.2. Lien Created; Pro Rata Basis:
Such transfer of proceeds shall be on a pro rata basis by all insurance companies insuring the building
or other structure. (Ord. 97-23, § 1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-41. Procedure:
(a) When final settlement on a covered claim has been agreed to or arrived at between the named
insured or insureds and the company or companies, and the final settlement exceeds seventy five
percent (75%) of the face value of the policy covering any building or other insured structure, and
when all amounts due the holder of a first real estate mortgage against the building or other
structure, pursuant to the terms of the policy and endorsements thereto, shall have been paid, the
insurance company or companies shall execute a draft payable to the City Treasurer in an amount
equal to the sum of fifteen percent (15%) of the covered claim payment unless the Planning and
Development Director of the City has issued a certificate to the insurance company or companies
that the insured has removed the damaged building or other structure, as well as all associated
debris, or repaired, rebuilt, or otherwise made the premises safe and secure.
(b) Such transfer of funds shall be on a pro rata basis by all companies insuring the building or other
structure. Policy proceeds remaining after the transfer to the City shall be disbursed in accordance
with the policy terms.
(c) Upon the transfer of the funds as required by subsection (a) of this Section, the insurance company
shall provide the City with the name and address of the named insured or insureds, the total
insurance coverage applicable to said building or other structure, and the amount of the final
settlement agreed to or arrived at between the insurance company or companies and the insured or
insureds, whereupon the Planning and Development Director shall contact the named insured or
insureds by registered mail, notifying them that said insurance proceeds have been received by the
City and apprise them of the procedures to be followed under this Article. (Ord. 97-23, § 1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-42. Fund Created; Deposit Of Monies:
The City Treasurer is hereby authorized and shall create a fund to be known as the "Insurance Proceeds
Fund". All monies received by the City Treasurer as provided for by this Article shall be placed in said
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 258/510
Fund and deposited in an interest-bearing account. (Ord. 97-23, § 1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-43. Investigation; Removal Of Structure:
(a) Upon receipt of monies as provided for by this Article, the City Treasurer shall immediately notify the
Planning and Development Director of said receipt, and transmit all documentation received from the
insurance company or companies to the Planning and Development Director.
(b) Within twenty (20) days of the receipt of said monies, the Planning and Development Director shall
determine, after prior investigation, whether the City shall instigate proceedings under the provisions
of K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended, and shall notify the City Treasurer whether he or she intends
to initiate such proceedings.
(c) If the Planning and Development Director has determined that proceedings under K.S.A. 12-1750 et
seq., as amended, shall be initiated, he or she will do so immediately but no later than thirty (30)
days after receipt of the monies by the City Treasurer.
(d) Upon notification to the City Treasurer by the Planning and Development Director that no
proceedings shall be initiated under K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended, the City Treasurer shall
return all such monies received, plus accrued interest, to the insured or insureds as identified in the
communication from the insurance company or companies. Such return shall be accomplished within
thirty (30) days of the receipt of the monies from the insurance company or companies. (Ord. 97-23,
§ 1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-44. Removal Of Structure; Excess Monies:
If the Planning and Development Director has proceeded under the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq.,
as amended, all monies in excess of that which is ultimately necessary to comply with the provisions for
the removal of the building or structure, less salvage value, if any, shall be paid to the insured. (Ord. 97-
23, § 1, 9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-44.1. Removal Of Structure; Disposition Of Funds:
If the Planning and Development Director, with regard to a building or other structure damaged by fire,
explosion, or windstorm determines that it is necessary to act under K.S.A. 12-1756, any proceeds
received by the City Treasurer under the authority of subsection 17-41(a) of this Article relating to that
building or other structure shall be used to reimburse the City for any expenses incurred by the City in
proceeding under K.S.A. 12-1756. Upon reimbursement from the insurance proceeds, the Planning and
Development Director shall immediately effect the release of the lien resulting therefrom. Should the
expenses incurred by the City exceed the insurance proceeds paid over to the City Treasurer under
subsection 17-41(a) of this Article, the Planning and Development Director shall publish a new lien as
authorized by K.S.A. 12-1756, in an amount equal to such excess expenses incurred. (Ord. 97-23, § 1,
9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-45. Effect Upon Insurance Policies:
This Article shall not make the City a party to any insurance contract, nor is the insurer liable to any party
for any amount in excess of the proceeds otherwise payable under its insurance policy. (Ord. 97-23, § 1,
9-3-1997)
Sec. 17-46. Insurers; Liability:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 259/510
Insurers complying with this Article or attempting in good faith to comply with this Article shall be immune
from civil and criminal liability and such action shall not be deemed in violation of K.S.A. 40-2404 and
any amendments thereto, including withholding payment of any insurance proceeds pursuant to this
article, or releasing or disclosing any information pursuant to this article. (Ord. 97-23, § 1, 9-3-1997)
ARTICLE V. BUILDING AND PROPERTY MAINTENANCE
Sec. 17-47. Legislative Findings:
The governing body finds that there exists within the city structures and lands which are unfit for human
use or habitation due to dilapidation, defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities,
lack of ventilation, light or sanitary facilities, or due to such other conditions which render such structures
or lands dangerous or injurious to the health, safety or general welfare of the occupants of such
structures and lands or other residents of the city, or which have a blighting influence on the properties in
the area. Such other conditions include the following, without limitation: defects therein increasing the
hazards of fire, accident or other calamities; lack of adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; air
pollution; dilapidation; disrepair; structural defects; uncleanliness; overcrowding; inadequate ingress and
egress, dead and dying trees, limbs or other unsightly natural growth or unsightly appearances that
constitute a blight to adjoining property, the neighborhood or the city; walls, sidings or exteriors of a
quality and appearance not commensurate with the character of the properties in the neighborhood;
unsightly stored or parked material, equipment, supplies, machinery, trucks or automobiles or parts
thereof, vermin infestation; inadequate drainage; or any violation of health, fire, building or zoning
ordinances and regulations or any other laws, regulations or ordinances relating to the use of land and
the use and occupancy of the buildings and improvements.
The governing body further finds that the foregoing conditions render such structures or lands unsafe,
unsanitary or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or morals or otherwise detrimental to the
welfare of the residents of the city, and it is hereby deemed necessary to require or cause the repair,
closing, demolition or removal of such structures or the remediation of such lands in the manner herein
provided. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996)
Sec. 17-48. Scope:
The provisions of this article shall apply to residential and nonresidential structures, to residential and
nonresidential lands and to vacant lots. Provided, however, that this article shall not apply to mobile
homes to the extent any provision is inconsistent with the generally accepted construction standards for
such structure. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996)
Sec. 17-49. Public Officer:
In addition to the authority which may be specifically provided in this chapter, the public officer may
exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and
provisions of this article. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996)
Sec. 17-50. Owner Responsibility:
Any person representing the actual owner by contract or otherwise shall comply with the provisions of
this article to the same extent as the owner. A "person" is any individual, corporation, firm, partnership,
association, organization or other legal entity. The owner of the land shall maintain such land and
structures thereon in compliance with the requirements set forth in this article. A person shall not occupy
as owner-occupant or allow another to occupy or use land or structures which do not comply with the
requirements of this article. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 5, 3-6-2002)
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 260/510
Sec. 17-51. Foundation:
(a) The foundation of a structure shall have no openings large enough to allow animals to enter under
the structure.
(b) The foundation elements shall support the structure.
(c) Any repair or replacement necessitated by this section shall be accomplished with materials that are
compatible with the remaining foundation. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996)
Sec. 17-52. Exterior Wall Surface:
Exterior wall surfaces shall be free of holes, breaks, damaged construction materials or any other
conditions which might admit rain, or animals to the interior portions of the walls or occupied spaces of
the structure. All exterior wall surfaces shall be maintained and kept in repair using materials compatible
with the remaining undamaged wall surfaces and recognized as acceptable pursuant to the city building
code. Areas of exterior walls with exposed insulating material shall be covered with a compatible exterior
finish including siding, masonry or brick. Where an existing painted wall surface has areas of chipping,
peeling, scaling or missing paint equal to or greater than fifty percent (50%) of the painted area, then
such surface shall be completely repainted or stripped of all paint and given a water resistant coating if
necessary. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 6, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-53. Windows And Doors:
(a) Every exterior opening shall be fitted with a window, door, basement hatchway cover or crawl space
cover, as appropriate, which shall be maintained in sound condition and good repair. Every doorway
which gives access from a habitable room or area to the exterior of the structure shall be fitted with a
door, equipped with hardware capable of ensuring privacy and security to the occupants of such
habitable room or structure. Every door available as an exit shall be capable of being easily opened
from the inside.
(b) All windows shall be fully supplied with glass windowpanes without open cracks or holes.
Windowpanes may only be repaired using a means specifically designed for glass repair and
approved by the public officer, or another material may be substituted for the glass if it is similar in
appearance and form to glass and is approved by the public officer. An entire window unit, including
sills, jambs and trim, may be replaced with a building material suitable for exterior use and finished to
match the adjacent wall surfaces. No windows or other openings shall be covered with boards or
other materials not approved by the public officer. If storm windows are provided, the entire assembly
shall be maintained in good effective working condition. When present, awnings are to be kept in
good repair. Every other opening located within four feet (4') of the ground level shall be protected
against the possible entry of rodents. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 7, 3-6-
2002)
Sec. 17-54. Roofing And Guttering:
The roof, eave and soffit shall be structurally sound, and shall not contain openings observable from the
exterior. All repairs shall be made with materials compatible with the unaffected portions of the roof,
eave or soffit. Any guttering or downspouts that have been broken shall be repaired or replaced with
materials that are compatible with the undamaged guttering and downspouts, or in the alternative such
guttering or downspouts may be removed. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 8, 3-6-
2002)
Sec. 17-55. Attached Structures:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 261/510
Exterior surfaces, porches, landings, fire escapes, decks, railings and exterior stairs shall be maintained
in a safe and functional condition. Treads, risers, floor surfaces and railings that are broken, or missing
shall be replaced. Any repair or replacement work required pursuant to this section shall be
accomplished with materials that are compatible to the undamaged portions of the structure. Where any
attached structure has been previously painted and there are areas of chipping, peeling, scaling or
missing paint equal to or greater than fifty percent (50%) of the attached structure, then such surface
shall be completely repainted, or stripped of all paint and given a water resistant coating if necessary.
(Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 9, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-56. Fences:
All fencing, including gates, shall be free of missing structural members and shall be maintained in
quality and appearance so as not to constitute a blight to adjoining property. Repairs or replacements
shall be made with materials compatible with the undamaged portions of the fence. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-
1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 10, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-57. Pools Of Water:
(Rep. by Ord. 02-04, § 13, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-58. Sheds, Garages Or Other Outbuildings:
Sheds, garages or other outbuildings shall be maintained in the same manner as provided in sections
17-51 through 17-55 of this article. Provided, however, that outbuildings on agriculturally zoned property
and used for agricultural purposes shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. (Ord. 96-3, § 1,
3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996)
Sec. 17-59. Outdoor Storage; One- And Two-Family Dwellings:
No property owner or resident shall allow the placement, storage, installation or construction of any item,
object or structure on any property zoned or used for a single-family or two-family residence except as
specifically and explicitly permitted by this section. The following items, objects or structures are
permitted:
(1) Any item, object or structure permitted under the applicable provisions of this code, in full
compliance with the authorizing provisions. The intent of this subsection is to permit only those items
specifically permitted under the applicable zoning district regulations or the applicable accessory use
regulations.
(2) Authorized trash containers stored and maintained in compliance with the requirements of this
code.
(3) Firewood, neatly stacked; provided that such storage shall not occur at any location on the
property that is within twenty five feet (25') of an improved street.
All other items: Any item, object or structure not specifically authorized in subsection (1), (2) or (3) of this
section or otherwise prohibited by any provision of this code must be located within a fully enclosed
structure, or within the back yard and substantially screened from view from any adjacent property by a
wall or fence. The director of planning may approve mature landscape materials as an acceptable
screen if he/she determines that it provides the substantial equivalent of approved fence or wall
materials. Materials for a fence or wall shall be of a type, material and quality compatible with the
immediate neighborhood, as determined by the director of planning. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-
1996)
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 262/510
Sec. 17-60. Outdoor Storage; Other Property:
No property owner or occupant shall allow the placement, storage, installation or construction of any
item, sales inventory, object or structure on any property other than that property zoned or used for a
single-family or two-family residence except as specifically and explicitly permitted by this section. The
following items, objects or structures are permitted:
(1) Any item, sales inventory, object or structure permitted under the applicable provisions of this
code, in full compliance with the authorizing provision. The intent of this subsection is to permit only
those items specifically permitted under the applicable zoning district regulations or the applicable
accessory use regulations.
(2) Authorized trash containers stored and maintained in compliance with the requirements of this
code. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996)
Sec. 17-61. Maintenance After Casualty Damage:
Within a period of ninety (90) days after a casualty damage to any premises the owner and operator
shall take the following steps:
(1) Contract for the repair and restoration of damage areas and removal of debris.
(2) Contract for the demolition and removal of any part of the premises not to be repaired or restored
and for the removal of debris in connection therewith.
Should an adjustment of insurance claims take longer than ninety (90) days, the public officer may grant
an extension in the period of time needed to comply with this section. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-
1996)
Sec. 17-62. Notice To Abate:
If the public officer determines a violation of this article exists, the public officer may issue a notice and
order to the owner thereof of such violation. Such notice and order shall contain:
(1) The street address and a legal description sufficient for identification of the owner's property.
(2) A statement by the public officer that the owner's property has been found to be in violation of this
chapter and a concise description of the conditions of the property giving rise to the violation or
violations.
(3) A statement by the public officer that the public officer has determined that the property must be
repaired or properly maintained and an order requiring that all required permits be secured therefor
and the work physically completed within such time as the public officer shall determine is
reasonable under all of the circumstances.
(4) Repealed.
(5) The notice required by this article shall be served upon the owner, and any other person if known
or disclosed from official public records who has any estate or legal interest in the dwelling. Service
of any notice shall be made upon an owner in person or by mailing a copy of such notice by
restricted mail, return receipt requested, to such owner at their address as it appears on the records
of the register of deeds, Lyon County. If the location of such person is unknown or if no address of
such person so appears after diligent effort, then a copy of the notice shall be posted at the address
of the dwelling involved, and such notice shall be published once in the official city paper. The failure
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 263/510
of a person to receive notice shall not affect the validity of any proceedings taken under this section.
The failure of the public officer to serve any person shall not invalidate any proceedings hereunder as
to any other person duly served or relieve any such person from any duty or obligation imposed by
this chapter. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 02-04, § 11, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-63. Appeal:
(Rep. by Ord. 02-04, § 13, 3-6-2002)
Sec. 17-64. Penalty:
(a)Any property owner found in violation of this chapter shall be subject to prosecution in the municipal
court. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not
less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); or
imprisonment for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or both;
(b)Each day that any violation of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. Separate
offenses under this article may be joined together in one complaint. Leave to amend a complaint
under this article to join separate offenses involving the same section of the code may be granted by
the court at any time;
(c)For violations of this building and property maintenance article, the municipal court judge may, after
the sentence has been announced, suspend the imposition of sentence and continue the sentencing
hearing, and allow the defendant such time as may reasonably appear necessary to the judge to
remedy the violation. At the sentencing hearing, upon proof that the violation has been remedied, the
judge may reduce any part of the fine and sentence, but not the court costs of the case. Should the
violation be continuing, the judge shall impose sentence;
(d)The city shall further have the authority to maintain suits or actions in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing any provision of this article, to seek civil penalties, to abate
nuisances maintained in violation thereof, and in addition to seek other remedies, institute injunction,
mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful nuisance or
condition. (Ord. 96-3, § 1, 3-6-1996, eff. 4-1-1996; Ord. 05-10, § 1, 3-2-2005)
Sec. 17-65. Rental Housing:
(a)Exclusions : This section shall not apply to:
(1) Transient occupancy in a hotel, motel or similar business;
(2) Hospitals, rest homes, convalescent homes and nursing homes;
(3) Campgrounds;
(4) Fraternities and sororities; and
(5) State licensed group homes.
(b)Minimum Standards For Rental Units : A "rental unit" is a room or group of rooms, consisting of a
dwelling or located within a dwelling, and forming a single habitable unit which is under rent or lease
to a person or persons not related to the owner within the third degree of kinship. The owner of each
rental unit in the city which is offered for, or is under, rent or lease is responsible for providing each
such rental unit with the following:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 264/510
(1) A bathroom containing a toilet, properly connected to the city wastewater system, a lavatory basin
and a bathtub and/or shower. All plumbing serving the rental unit must be properly installed whether
in the bathroom, kitchen or basement. A landlord is not required by this code to provide a kitchen or
basement sump pump, but if provided, they must be in proper working order;
(2) A heating system installed and maintained so as to be reasonably safe to the occupants and the
structure; and able to maintain a temperature of sixty degrees Fahrenheit (60°F) to all livable rooms
in the unit;
(3) An electrical system installed and maintained so as to be reasonably safe to the occupants and
the structure;
(4) One functioning, UL approved smoke detector for each level of a rental unit;
(5) An unobstructed means of egress leading to the ground level as required by the building code.
(c)Enforcement : The public officer is hereby authorized to inspect between the hours of eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. all dwellings, structures and surroundings which are subject to
the provisions of this article for the purpose of determining whether there is compliance with its
provisions. The public officer shall present identification and notice of the purpose of the inspection to
the owner, occupant or other person in charge of the structure and shall, if possible, obtain a written
waiver and permission to inspect the premises.
(1) If any owner, occupant or other person in charge of a dwelling refuses to permit access and entry
to the structure or premises under the person's control, or any part thereof, for the purpose of
conducting an inspection authorized by this article, the public officer may, upon a showing that
probable cause exists for the inspection and for the issuance of a notice and order directing
compliance with the requirements of the rental housing code, petition and obtain a warrant for
inspection purposes from the district court.
(2) A verified complaint by a current tenant, or by a city, county or state employee, based on personal
knowledge that a violation exists shall constitute probable cause for an inspection of the rental unit.
Names of complainants shall be held confidential to the extent allowed by law.
(3) When the housing officer has inspected and determined that a violation of the requirements of
this article has occurred, the housing officer shall issue a notice directed to the owner of the dwelling
as provided by section 17-62 of this article. (Ord. 02-04, § 12, 3-6-2002; Ord. 05-36, § 1, 12-21-2005)
Sec. 17-66. Residential Parking Restriction:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person or operator to park a motor vehicle on any portion of the required
front yard of any residential lot, or to park more than one motor vehicle in the side yard of any
residential lot; except for vehicles parked completely on a driveway or pad surfaced in compliance
with the requirements of city of Emporia zoning regulation 22-305, as amended.
(b)The penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine of ten dollars ($10.00). Each day that any
violation of this section continues shall constitute another offense. The fine for this infraction shall be
imposed upon a voluntary entry of appearance, plea of guilty or no contest to a traffic citation alleging
such violation and payment of the fine and any court costs.
(c)The procedures used for parking citations contained in sections 100, 101 and 102 of the currently
adopted standard traffic ordinance for Kansas cities shall be followed in the issuance of citations
under this section. (Ord. 05-10, § 3, 3-2-2005)
Sec. 17-67. Outdoor Furniture Restriction:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 265/510
(a)No person, including the owner of real property or any person in possession of real property, shall
place, use, keep, store, or maintain any upholstered furniture not manufactured for outdoor use,
including, without limitation, upholstered chairs, upholstered couches, and mattresses, in any outside
areas located in the following places:
(1) In any front yard;
(2) In any side yard;
(3) In any rear yard or other yard that is adjacent to a public street. However, an alley shall not be
considered a "public street" for purposes of this section; or
(4) On any covered or uncovered porch.
(b)The interior of any fully enclosed porch, including a screened porch, that cannot be accessed from
outside except through a door that can be locked shall not be considered an outside area for the
purposes of this section.
(c)It shall not be a violation of this section that:
(1) Such furniture was temporarily placed in an outside location in order to allow it to be moved
during a move of a resident;
(2) Such furniture was temporarily placed in an outside location to be collected for trash removal on
the day scheduled for such removal; or
(3) Such furniture was temporarily placed in an outside location in order that it be offered for sale at a
yard sale or garage sale licensed by the city, or at an auction on the day of the auction.
(d)The penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine of ten dollars ($10.00). Each day that any
violation of this section continues shall constitute another offense. The fine for this infraction shall be
imposed upon a voluntary entry of appearance, plea of guilty or no contest to a citation alleging such
violation and payment of the fine and any court costs.
(e)The public officer shall issue a citation and order upon the owner or tenant in possession of the
premises, if known, or as disclosed by property records, or post a notice to abate to the attention of
the owner or person in possession of the property, if no one is present. A citation may be issued for
each day that the violation continues until it is removed. (Ord. 05-10, § 4, 3-2-2005)
Chapter 18
PARKS AND RECREATION 152
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. Application of city ordinances.
All ordinances of the city shall be in full force and effect in and over all the parks and public grounds of
the city, whether such parks and public grounds are situated within the city or are located beyond the
boundaries of the city.
(Code 1962, § 13-101)
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 266/510
Sec. 18-2. Recreation commission.
There is hereby created a recreation commission. The members of the commission shall serve without
pay.
(Code 1962, §§ 17-101, 17-102)
State law reference- Recreation commission generally, K.S.A. 12-1902, 12-1907.
Sec. 18-3. Fires.
It shall be unlawful to build any fire within any park or public grounds except within stoves, ovens,
furnaces or other places provided for that purpose. It shall be unlawful for any person, after having
kindled and started a fire, to leave the vicinity thereof, until the same is extinguished.
(Code 1962, § 13-103)
Sec. 18-4. Traffic generally.
It shall be unlawful to drive or park any vehicle within city parks and public grounds contrary to any signs
or other directions posted and established by the city.
(Code 1962, § 13-105)
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 25.
Sec. 18-5. Trucks.
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a truck, track tractor or any other vehicle having a gross
weight when loaded or unloaded exceeding eight thousand (8,000) pounds in any public park having
roadways surfaced with any material other than gravel or dirt.
(Ord. No. 571, § 1, 10-4-72)
Sec. 18-6. Reserved.
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-5, § 1, adopted January 20, 1988, repealed § 18-6, concerning fishing
licenses, in its entirety. Former § 18-6 derived from Ord. No. 323, § 2, adopted August 2, 1967; and Ord.
No. 534, § 3, adopted January 19, 1972.
Sec. 18-7. Closing hours.
Dryer Park, Pumping Station Park and Hammond Park shall be closed to the public between the hours
of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Soden's Grove shall be closed to the public from 11:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m.,
except when dances, entertainments or other amusements authorized by the city, are being held therein,
in which case the closing hours shall be from 1:00 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. Any person who shall be within
any of the foregoing parks and public grounds when the same are closed to the public, shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor.
(Code 1962, § 13-106)
Secs. 18-8-18-18. Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. PETER PAN PARK AND JONES PARK
Sec. 18-122. Obedience To Rules, Directions Or Orders Of City Officials:
All persons upon the grounds of Peter Pan Park or Jones Park, or in or upon the waters of Peter Pan
Lake or Jones Lake, shall obey all lawful rules, directions, orders, requests or demands of the City
police, City officials, or City employees in charge of the lake and surrounding grounds. (Ord. 369, § 4, 6-
5-1968)
Sec. 18-123. Contamination Of Water:
It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act upon the lake or lake premises at Peter Pan Lake,
located in Peter Pan Park or at Jones Lake, located in Jones Park, which act would tend to contaminate
the water. (Ord. 369, § 1, 6-5-1968)
Sec. 18-124. Fishing - Peter Pan Lake:
(a) Fishing Allowed : Fishing shall be allowed in Peter Pan Lake, located in Peter Pan Park, during the
hours the park is open. All fishing in such Lake shall be subject to and in accordance with the
provisions of this Article; the rules and regulations of the City and the State of Kansas Department of
Wildlife and Parks; and such other statutes, ordinances, and regulations of the City or the State as
may be applicable thereto.
(b) Fishing License :
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person, who is sixteen (16) years of age or more or sixty four (64)
years of age or less, to fish in Peter Pan Lake unless such person has in their possession a valid
fishing permit issued by the City.
(2) The permit fee is hereby fixed in the following amounts:
Resident: One day $1.00/$10.00 annual
Nonresident: One day $2.00/$20.00 annual
For the purpose of this Section residency shall be based on whether the person applying for the
permit resides within the City limits of the City of Emporia.
(3) Permits shall be valid only for the day issued for the one day license and the calendar year in
which issued for the annual license.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 268/510
(4) No permit shall be assignable or transferable, and no permit fee shall be prorated or refundable.
(5) Any person desiring a permit may apply therefor at the office of the City Clerk, during normal
office hours; exhibit the person's state license, if one be required by State law; and pay the required
license fee. Each permit shall be validated by the signature of the City Clerk and be countersigned by
the applicant, and shall not be altered. In addition to the office of the City Clerk, the City Manager
may designate such other places within the City, where persons may acquire City fishing permits
upon such terms and conditions as the City Manager may deem advisable. Upon designation of an
alternate site, the City Clerk shall provide a supply of City permits for issuance and shall receive
accountings for any permits issued and fees remitted. Any business establishment designated as an
alternate site may charge a handling fee of fifty cents ($0.50) in excess of the fee set herein for
permit issuance.
(6) The holder of a City fishing permit shall, upon demand, exhibit the same to any law enforcement
or wildlife and parks official.
(c) State License : All persons required by the State to have a Kansas fishing license shall have the
license in their possession while fishing in Peter Pan Lake.
(d) Fishing Method : The only legal equipment and method for fishing shall be with an attended pole.
There will be no more than two (2) poles, which must be attended, allowed per person.
(e) Creel Limits :
(1) A "creel limit" is defined as the maximum total number of a species that can be taken per person
in a calendar day.
(2) The following daily creel limits are hereby established for Peter Pan Lake:
Channel catfish - two (2)
(3) The creel limit established herein does not replace those established by the State except to the
extent the established limits are more restrictive.
(f) Regulations : The City Manager may adopt such rules and regulations as deemed necessary to
implement and administer the provisions of this Section and it shall be unlawful for any person not to
comply with any posted rules and regulations while fishing at Peter Pan Lake. (1962 Code, § 13-107;
Ord. 534, § 1, 1-19-1972; Ord. 99-15, § 1, 6-16-1999)
Sec. 18-124.1. Fishing - Jones Recreation Park Lakes:
(Rep. by Ord. 09-35, § 1, 12-16-2009)
Sec. 18-125. Boats:
It shall be unlawful to keep, have, maintain or operate any boat or raft upon Peter Pan Lake or upon
Jones Lake. (Ord. 369, § 2, 6-5-1968)
Sec. 18-126. Swimming:
It shall be unlawful for any person to swim in or upon Peter Pan Lake or Jones Lake. (Ord. 369, § 3, 6-5-
1968)

1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 269/510

5-1968)
Sec. 18-128. Closing Hours:
(a) Peter Pan Park : Peter Pan Park shall be closed to the public between the hours of eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. following. Any person who shall be within such Park when it
is closed to the public shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor 156 .

(11:00) P.M. and daylight following. Any person, without lawful authority and excuse, who shall be in

ARTICLE V. CIVIC AUDITORIUM 157
Sec. 18-140. Management And Control:
The management of the civic auditorium shall be under the control of the City Manager. The City
Manager may, with the approval of the Governing Body, enter into agreements with any person as shall
be deemed in the best interest of the City in the scheduling and operation of this facility. (1962 Code, §
13-301; Ord. 1107, § 1, 8-25-1982)
Sec. 18-141. Rules and regulations.
The city manager, with the approval of the governing body, shall from time to time, as deemed
necessary, adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the safe and efficient operation of the civic
auditorium.
(Code 1962, 13-302; Ord. No. 1107, § 1, 8-25-82)
Sec. 18-142. Liability for damages.
All parties using the civic auditorium shall be responsible for the payment of any and all damage that the
building, furniture or fixtures may sustain from such use. The city manager may require parties renting
the civic auditorium to make a cash deposit to reimburse the city for any damages to the building,
furniture or fixtures. The deposit in excess of damages, estimated by the city manager, shall be returned
when the use of the building is surrendered by the lessee.
(Code 1962, § 13-303; Ord. No. 1107, § 1, 8-25-82)
Sec. 18-143. Gate fee.
(a) Any event at the civic auditorium which has an admission charge shall also be assessed a gate fee.
This fee shall be ten (10) percent of gross receipts for all receipts over one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00). Amateur athletic events shall be exempt from this gate fee.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 270/510
(b) Within twenty-four (24) hours after an event subject to a gate fee, the contracting party for the facility
shall file with the city clerk a sworn statement showing gross receipts and pay the gate fee as
provided. The city manager is authorized to require a cash deposit for the gate fee, from any person
contracting the facility whenever it is deemed advisable.
(Code 1962, §§ 13-304, 13-305; Ord. No. 1107, § 1, 8-25-82)
Sec. 18-144. Rental, etc., charge.
(a) The following shall be the charges for the rental and services provided at the civic auditorium:
(1) Main arena, public gatherings:
a. Monday through Friday: Two-hundred seventy dollars ($270.00) per day.
b. Saturday and Sunday: Three-hundred thirty dollars ($330.00) per day.
(2) Main arena, floor use only:
a. Monday through Friday: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour.
b. Saturday and Sunday: Thirty dollars ($30.00) per hour.
(3) Set-up charges:
a. For chairs: Ten dollars ($10.00) per one hundred (100) chairs.
b. Activity set-up charge: Ten dollars ($10.00) per hour.
(4) Stage crew, spotlight and piano tuning shall be contracted at the commercial rate.
These fees will be subject to annual review by the governing body.
(b) For any use not previously specified, a charge shall be determined by the city manager.
(c) The rental charge shall cover the services of only those employees of the city who are regularly
employed on the civic auditorium staff and shall not be deemed to cover any extraordinary services
by such employees nor services by other persons.
(d) For those who lease the facility on a number of consecutive days, or use the facility for more than
five (5) days in the calendar year, the city manager or his designee may negotiate a rate.
(Code 1962, §§ 13-306-13-308; Ord. No. 1107, § 1, 8-25-82; Ord. No. 83-31, § 1, 8-17-83; Ord. No. 84-
42, § 1, 9-19-84; Ord. No. 88-26, § 1, 9-7-88)
Sec. 18-145. Security service.
At the discretion of the city manager, qualified security officers may be required at events held in the
civic auditorium. The city manager will inform the lessee of the standards set by the city for security
officers. These officers will be obtained at the expense of the lessee.
(Code 1962, § 13-309; Ord. No. 1107, § 1, 8-25-82)
Secs. 18-146-18-160. Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE
Sec. 18-161. Definitions.
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as
follows:
Annual fees : The yearly fee for unlimited usage of the golf course during its operating hours.
Cart storage : The annual fee for space available at the golf course for cart storage and for annual trail
fee for the stored cart.
Daylight rate : The rate charged for green fees from the daily opening of the facility until 5:00 p.m.
Green fees : The charge for usage of the Emporia Municipal Golf Course during its operating hours.
Junior players : Persons seventeen (17) years of age and under.
Senior citizen : Persons sixty-five (65) years of age or older, or age sixty-two (62) or older if receiving
social security.
Trail fees : The fee for usage of privately owned golf carts on the trails provided on the course.
Exceptions: Golf carts do not include pull carts.
Twilight Rate: The rate charged for green fees after five o'clock (5:00) P.M. and until the facility closes.
(Ord. 1108, § 1, 8-25-1982; Ord. 83-20, § 1, 6-1-1983; Ord. 85-20, § 1, 6-5-1985; Ord. 85-50, § 1, 12-18-
1985; Ord. 86-1, § 1, 2-5-1986; Ord. 88-34, § 1, 12-7-1988; Ord. 89-1, § 1, 1-4-1989; Ord. 89-12, § 1, 5-
3-1989)
Sec. 18-162. Management And Control:
The management of the Emporia Municipal Golf Course shall be under the control of the city manager.
The city manager may, with the approval of the governing body, enter into agreements with any person
as shall be deemed in the best interest of the city in the operation of this facility. (Ord. 1108, § 2, 8-25-
1982)
Sec. 18-163. Rules And Regulations:
The city manager, with the approval of the governing body, shall, from time to time, as deemed
necessary, adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the same and efficient operation of the
Emporia Municipal Golf Course. (Ord. 1108, § 3, 8-25-1982)
Sec. 18-164. Jurisdiction Of City Ordinances, Etc.:
The city does hereby extend all its police powers and ordinances pertaining thereto and over the
Emporia Municipal Golf Course property and grounds to the same degree and with the same force and
effect as if said golf course were situated within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. 1108, § 4, 8-25-
1982)
Sec. 18-165. Charges:
The governing body shall by resolution establish fees and charges for various services provided at the
Emporia Municipal Golf Course, including, but not limited to, the following services: green fees, including
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 272/510
daylight rates, twilight rates, and weekends; annual fees; trail fees; and cart storage. Any resolution
passed pursuant to this section shall be available for public inspection at the office of the city clerk
during regular business hours and shall be posted at the Emporia Municipal Golf Course. The fees
established pursuant to this section shall be subject to annual review by the governing body. (Ord. 1108,
§ 5, 8-25-1982; Ord. 83-32, § 1, 9-21-1983; Ord. 84-41, § 1, 9-19-1984; Ord. 85-20, § 2, 6-5-1985; Ord.
85-50, § 2, 12-18-1985; Ord. 86-44, § 1, 12-31-1986; Ord. 87-42, § 1, 12-16-1987; Ord. 88-34, § 2, 12-7-
1988; Ord. 89-41, § 1, 12-6-1989; Ord. 90-25, § 1, 12-19-1990; Ord. 91-26, § 1, 12-18-1991)
Sec. 18-166. Golf Advisory Board; Created, Composition:
(a)Creation; Membership: There is hereby created an advisory board to be known as the golf advisory
board to advise the governing body on matters relating to the development, maintenance,
improvement and operation of the municipal golf course. The board shall consist of five (5) members
who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the governing body.
(b)Residence, Appointment To Fill Vacancy; Compensation: Four (4) of the five (5) members of the
board shall reside within the limits of the city of Emporia. The fifth member may reside anywhere
within the limits of Lyon County. Any member who moves his or her residence outside the area shall
automatically cease to be a member, and a vacancy shall thereby be created. Appointment of new
members to fill vacancies shall be made by the mayor with the consent of the governing body. The
members of the board shall serve without compensation.
(c)Term: The term of office of each member of the committee shall be three (3) years or until his or her
successor is appointed. Members of the committee shall serve no more than two (2) successive
three (3) year terms in addition to any unexpired term to which they may have been appointed.
Members may be eligible for reappointment after one year.
(d)Meetings; Quorum, Attendance: The board shall meet regularly once each quarter, at a time decided
by the board for the purpose of conducting such business as may come before it. Special meetings
may be called by the chairperson or by a majority of the board presently serving. A majority of the
presently serving members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting the
business thereof. The board may, by majority vote of the board, recommend to the governing body
that a member's term be terminated and a new member to fill any unexpired term, whenever a
member fails to comply with the attendance requirements of the board's bylaws.
(e)Officers: The board shall elect from among its members a chairperson and vice chairperson. The vice
chairperson shall act as the chairperson during the absence or incapacity of same. The term of office
for the chairperson and vice chairperson shall be for one year, and no person shall serve more than
two (2) consecutive years in the same office. The chairperson and vice chairperson may resign from
office at any time during their terms and may do so without resigning from membership on the board.
(f)Removal Of Member: No member or members of the board shall attempt to act on any matter over
which the board has jurisdiction unless and until the board has given prior approval to such action.
Any member of the board may be removed by the mayor with the consent of the governing body for
inefficiency, neglect of duty or misconduct or malfeasance in office; no such removal shall be
effective until the member proposed to be removed has been furnished a written statement of the
charges and an opportunity to be heard thereon by the governing body. (Ord. 85-21, § 1, 6-5-1985;
Ord. 92-35, § 1, 10-21-1992; Ord. 12-19, 6-20-2012)
Sec. 18-167. Golf Advisory Board; Powers And Duties:
The board shall have the following function, powers, duties and responsibilities:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 273/510
(1) Review all major proposals for improvements of the municipal golf course and make reports and
recommendations to the golf course staff.
(2) Act as a fundraising committee for special improvement projects at the municipal golf course.
(3) Promote the game of golf at the municipal golf course through the education of the users of the
golf course.
(4) Provide information to the users of the golf course and others regarding the maintenance and
improvement of the municipal golf course.
(5) Receive input, suggestions, complaints and comments from users of the golf course and others
regarding the municipal golf course.
All reports or recommendations made by the board to the governing body shall be advisory only and
shall be submitted in writing through the office of the city manager. (Ord. 85-21, § 2, 6-5-1985; Ord. 92-
35, § 2, 10-21-1992)

Sec. 20-13. Members 162 :
(a) The Joint Planning Commission shall consist of nine (9) members, who shall be appointed jointly by
the Governing Body of the City and the Board of County Commissioners of the County. All terms of
office shall be for three (3) years, and the terms of three (3) members shall expire annually in
accordance with the staggered terms established. Three (3) new members shall be appointed
annually in the following manner:
(1) One member shall be appointed by the Board of County Commissioners of the County; and
(2) Two (2) members shall be appointed by the Governing Body of the City.
No more than one member from each the City and from the County shall be an elected officer of
such City or County.
(b) No member shall serve more than two (2) consecutive three (3) year terms. All terms shall
commence on January 1 and expire on December 31, except that, in the event no appointments are
made prior to that time, members shall serve until such time as new appointments are made. In case
of the death, incapacity, resignation or disqualification of any member, the commissioners having
appointed such member shall appoint another member for the unexpired term of such deceased,
incapacitated, resigned or disqualified member. Any person who resides within the City or within
three (3) miles of the City limits shall be eligible for appointment by the governing bodies.
(c) All members, including the chairman, shall have the right to take part in all discussions and to vote,
except that any member who has a conflict of interest in regard to any proposal or discussion shall
disqualify himself from the discussion and from voting. Members of the Joint Planning Commission
shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for expenses actually incurred in the
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 275/510
performance of their duties as members of the Joint Planning Commission. (Ord. 984, § 2, 12-19-
1979; Ord. 87-1, § 2, 1-7-1987)
Sec. 20-14. Officers And Meetings:
(a) The Joint Planning Commission shall convene for its meetings at such time and place as shall be
fixed by the chairman of the Board of County Commissioners of the County and by the Mayor of the
City, and they shall organize and elect officers, adopt bylaws and fix and determine times and places
of future meetings, which meetings shall not be less frequent than once a month. Said Joint Planning
Commission shall elect one member as chairman and another as vice chairman. The terms of the
chairman and vice chairman shall be for one year and until their successors shall have been elected
and qualified. Special meetings of the Joint Planning Commission may be called by the chairman, or,
in his absence, by the vice chairman, or by either governing body. A quorum of the Joint Planning
Commission shall consist of five (5) members.
(b) The Joint Planning Commission shall designate a secretary and may also designate an assistant
secretary, neither of whom need be members of the Commission. The secretary shall cause a proper
record to be kept of all proceedings of the Joint Planning Commission, copies of which shall be
promptly furnished to both governing bodies. (Ord. 984, § 3, 12-19-1979; Ord. 87-1, § 3, 1-7-1987)
Sec. 20-15. Functions Generally:
The Joint Planning Commission shall have such powers and duties as prescribed by law and as may be
provided by joint resolution from time to time. The area under its jurisdiction shall be the Emporia-Lyon
County Metropolitan Area. As a primary function, the Joint Planning Commission shall have the
responsibility for the preparation, adoption, and recommendation of a long-range Comprehensive Plan to
guide the future physical development of the Emporia-Lyon County Metropolitan Area. Such General
Plan shall consist of a land use element, a circulation element, and a public facilities element. The plan
shall provide a statement of population distribution and density and proposed building intensities and
other uses of land. The Joint Planning Commission shall further have and exercise the following powers:
(1) To recommend development plans for specific public works projects and for urban renewal. Such
development plans shall be related to the General Plan and shall ensure the integration of proposed
land uses and for matters of access and relationship to the neighborhood within which such
development plans provide for construction. Development plans shall also contain analysis of
methods of financing proposed public works.
(2) To cause to be prepared zoning studies and shall recommend the zoning of all land within their
jurisdiction, and shall have all of the zoning functions, powers, and duties which are given by the laws
of the State or by action of the City or County governing bodies.
(3) To cause to be prepared recommendations governing the control of subdivisions within the area
of their jurisdiction.
(4) To cause to be prepared annually for the City and the County a statement of current and past
growth and development trends and anticipated growth for the succeeding year and for the
succeeding five (5) years. Such annual statement of anticipated growth and development shall also
contain an annual review of the state of the General Plan and recommended adjustments in such
plan. Such annual review statement shall be transmitted to the governing bodies of the City and
County on or before the first Monday in March of each year for the use by the respective governing
bodies in the preparation of their annual capital improvement budget.
(5) To cause to have reviewed annually the proposed capital improvement budgets of both the City
and the County and the Commission shall comment upon the proposed budgets in terms of their
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 276/510
conformity to and furtherance of the General Plan.
(6) To perform all of the powers, duties, and functions at one time vested in the Emporia Planning
Commission and in the Lyon County Planning Commission.
The planning and development department of the City shall serve as staff for the Joint Planning
Commission and the proportionate share of cost and expenses, and the purchase of property and
materials for use of the Commission shall be negotiated annually by the City and County governing
bodies. (Ord. 984, § 4, 12-19-1979; Ord. 87-1, § 4, 1-7-1987)
Sec. 20-16. Referral Of Planning And Zoning Actions To Commission; Procedure
For Amendment Of Zoning Ordinances 163 :
(a) All planning and zoning actions of every kind or character heretofore taken by the Emporia-Lyon
County Metropolitan Planning Commission and its predecessors, the Emporia City Planning
Commission and the Lyon County Planning Commission, shall be continued in full force and effect.
All petitions for zoning changes, requests for approval of plats and dedications, and all other matters
pending before the Joint Planning Commission upon the effective date of this Ordinance shall
continue to be processed by such Commission.
(b) All zoning or planning action taken by the governing bodies of said City or County after the effective
date of this Ordinance shall be first referred to the Joint Planning Commission for its recommendation
in writing in accordance with K.S.A., and the procedure followed by said Joint Planning Commission
shall be in accordance with said K.S.A. and with the provisions hereof.
(c) No amendment, supplement, change, modification, or repeal of the zoning regulations or restrictions
of the city or county shall be made by the city or county until the matter has first been submitted to
the joint planning commission for its recommendation and report. If the joint planning commission
makes no written report approving or disapproving the submitted proposal to the governing bodies
within forty five (45) days of the date set for hearing in the published notice, it may be considered to
have made a report approving the submitted proposal.
(d) The joint planning commission shall hold a public hearing upon each zoning amendment,
supplement, change, modification, or repeal, giving at least twenty (20) days' notice of the time and
place of the hearing, which notice shall be published in the official newspaper of the city or county or
both, depending upon the location of the land affected thereby, not less than twenty (20) days before
the hearing.
(e) If the joint planning commission disapproves any proposed amendment, supplement, change,
modification, or repeal of a zoning restriction or regulation, or if a protest against the same, filed in
accordance with law, shall be submitted within fourteen (14) days of the date of hearing in writing to
the city clerk, duly signed and acknowledged in accordance with law, such proposal shall not be
passed by the governing body of the city except by a three-fourths (3/4) favorable vote of all the
members. If a protest against the same, filed in accordance with law, shall be submitted within
fourteen (14) days of the date of hearing in writing to the county clerk, duly signed and acknowledged
in accordance with law, such proposals shall not be passed by the governing body of the county
except by favorable vote of all the members of the Board of County Commissioners.
(f) Before any proposal made in accordance with law will be considered by the joint planning
commission, it must be reduced to writing so it clearly and understandably states the proposal. The
joint planning commission may require additional data and information, including drawings, plans,
and maps. A proposal will not be considered as submitted until all reasonable requirements of the
joint planning commission for information and data are met.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 277/510
(g) Interested parties may file written proposals for amendment, supplement, change, modification or
repeal of any zoning regulation or restriction of the city or of the county with the secretary of the joint
planning commission. A fee in a sum as established by the zoning regulations adopted by the Board
of County Commissioners and the governing body of the city, or as the same may be amended from
time to time, shall be paid to the secretary at the time of filing a proposal to cover the approximate
cost of the above procedure, and under no condition shall said sum or any part thereof be refunded.
(Ord. 984, § 5, 12-19-1979; Ord. 87-1, § 5, 1-7-1987)

ARTICLE III. DOWNTOWN BUSINESS IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT
Sec. 20-21. Boundaries And Name Of District:
The district shall be named the "Emporia Downtown Business Improvement District" and the boundaries
shall be as follows:
Beginning at the southeast corner of Lot 85 on Commercial Street in the Original Townsite of
Emporia, Kansas, thence west to the southwest corner of said Lot 85, thence north to the northwest
corner of Lot 91 on Commercial Street; thence west to the southwest corner of Lot 47 on Merchant
Street; thence north to the northwest corner of Lot 71 on Merchant Street; thence west to the
northwest corner of Lot 72 on Constitution Street; thence north to the northwest corner of Lot 130 on
Constitution Street; thence east to the northwest corner of Lot 259 on Merchant Street in the
Washington Park Addition; thence north to the northwest corner of Lot 172 on Merchant Street in the
Original Townsite; thence east to the northeast corner of Lot 344 on Commercial Street; thence south
to the southeast corner of Lot 2 on Commercial Street in the Washington Park Addition; thence east
to the southeast corner of Lot 116 on Mechanic Street in the Original Townsite; thence south to the
southeast corner of Lot 94 on Mechanic Street; thence east to the northeast corner of Lot 91 on
Market Street; thence south to the southeast corner of Lot 73 on Market Street; thence west to the
southeast corner of Lot 74 on Mechanic Street; thence south to the southeast corner of the north half
of Lot 44 on Mechanic Street; thence west to the northeast corner of Lot 86 on Commercial Street;
thence south to the southeast corner of Lot 86 on Commercial Street; thence west to the southeast
corner of Lot 85 on Commercial Street, being the point of beginning.
(Ord. 86-21, § 1, 7-16-1986)
Sec. 20-22. Services To Be Provided:
The services to be provided through the "Emporia Downtown Business Improvement District" will include
those authorized by statute and will encompass, but not be limited to, the following: Business
development, design, education, parking and promotions. (Ord. 86-21, § 2, 7-16-1986)
Sec. 20-23. Assessments:
(a) There is hereby levied and assessed against all businesses located within the Emporia Downtown
Business Improvement District a business improvement district service fee on each business located
within the Emporia Downtown Business Improvement District according to the following provisions:
(1) Businesses shall be classified in the following manner:
Retail : Includes businesses regularly engaged in the selling of tangible personal property, food, or
services, and selling only to the user or consumer and not for resale. Retail would not include
anything otherwise classified herein.
Business Service : Includes dry cleaners, barber and beauty shops, insurance agencies, real
estate agencies, consultants, fitness centers, travel agencies, photographers, printers and
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 280/510
newspapers. Also includes liquor stores, private clubs, drinking establishments and taverns; also
businesses providing entertainment. Also includes utilities in the business of providing electrical
energy, gas or water.
Professional : Includes doctors, attorneys and accountants.
Financial Institutions : Includes banks, savings and loans, credit unions and finance companies.
Apartments : Includes houses or buildings which are entirely devoted to rental unit(s). This does
not include apartments or vacant space in the upstairs of buildings occupied by nonapartment
businesses.
Light Industrial : Includes gas service stations, wholesale businesses, body shops, construction
companies, junkyards, buildings used for storage and undeveloped vacant lots.
Vacant : Includes unoccupied buildings and/or offices.
Exempt : Includes all property owners or used exclusively for federal, state, county, municipal,
literary, educational, scientific, religious, benevolent and charitable purposes. Also parking lots and
owner-occupied single-family residences.
(2) Businesses shall be assessed in the following manner:
a. A four dollar ($4.00) per front foot fee (rounded up to the nearest foot) is assessed to all
businesses except those which are not entered directly from the street and, therefore, do not have
actual front footage. The number of front feet is determined in the measurement of the building, if
there is a building. "Front" is determined by the side of the building entered by the public. The front
footage of a vacant lot is the measurement of the street side of the lot. Open doorways for access
to basements or second floors are not part of the front footage.
b. Those enclosed businesses (businesses not entered directly from the street) are assessed at
fifty dollars ($50.00) annually if they employ less than five (5) employees and one hundred dollars
($100.00) annually if they employ five (5) or more employees.
c. Businesses with front footage classified as "light industrial" and "apartment" are assessed at one
dollar ($1.00) per front foot (rounded up to the nearest foot) in lieu of the assessment specified in
subsection (a)(2)a of this section.
d. An additional annual "promotion fee" of fifty dollars ($50.00) is assessed to all businesses
classified as "retail", and that revenue will be used for the retail promotions portion of the business
improvement district budget. If a business changes to "retail" classification or a new retail business
moves into the district before July 1 of any year, the "promotion fee" shall be due in full for that
year.
e. Assessment for those businesses classified as "vacant" are made to the landowner.
Landowners shall not be responsible for assessments made to businesses vacating their building
after January 1 of any year. No additional "promotion fee" will be assessed to vacancies.
Businesses classified as vacant are assessed at one dollar ($1.00) per front foot (rounded up to
the nearest foot) in lieu of the assessment specified in subsection (a)(2)a. Enclosed businesses
which are "vacant" are assessed at one-fourth of the rate of the previous occupant.
f. If more than one business of identical ownership is conducted out of the same location, it is
considered one business.
g. A telephone address is not a business if there is no office or public business at the telephone
address.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 281/510
(b) Such assessment shall be assessed, billed and enforced as follows:
(1) All businesses within the district shall be notified by the city clerk's office of their assessment by
October 1 of the preceding year. Any questions regarding classifications and assessments shall be
presented by the business owner to the business improvement district advisory board provided for in
section 20-24 of this article within thirty (30) days of notification. The advisory board will study
appeals and final determination of assessment will be based on a majority vote of the advisory board.
Assessments shall be levied by ordinance at the first city commission meeting in February of each
calendar year based upon businesses existing on January 1 of such year. Pro rata refunds or
charges shall be made for new or vacating businesses after January 1 of the new year on a calendar
quarterly basis. There shall be no proration of charges or refunds as to the retail promotion fee,
except as provided in subsection (a)(2)d above.
(2) All assessments to businesses within the business improvement district as provided in this article
shall be billed by the city in February of each year within seven (7) days after adoption of the
ordinance levying the assessments. All monies received will be placed in a special fund as provided
in K.S.A. 12-1792 and amendments thereto.
(3) Any business wishing to make payments in two (2) installments shall notify the city clerk's office
before March 15 of the year. Any businesses electing this option shall pay half their assessment by
March 15 and a second half by August 15. No interest shall be charged for this option.
(4) Any fees which are not collected before March 15 of each year, except as provided in subsection
(b)(3) above, shall constitute a debt due to the city. The city attorney shall, at the direction of the city
manager, institute civil suit in the name of the city to recover any such unpaid fee and any associated
collection costs. No civil judgment shall bar or prevent a criminal prosecution for each and every
violation of this article.
(Ord. No. 86-21, § 3, 7-16-86; Ord. No. 86-42, § 1, 12-17-86; Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, 8-5-87; Ord. No. 88-
27, § 1, 9-21-88; Ord. No. 88-33, § 1, 12-7-88)
Sec. 20-24. Business improvement district advisory board.
(a) The membership of the business improvement district advisory board shall be selected and serve as
follows:
(1) There shall be twelve (12) voting members on the Emporia Downtown Business Improvement
District Advisory Board; three (3) to be appointed by the city commission and nine (9) to be elected
by the businesses within the district. Appointments shall be made at the first city commission meeting
in November.
a. Terms of office shall be two (2) years, except for the second year of operation of the Emporia
Downtown Business Improvement District in which four (4) members shall be elected to terms of
one year and five (5) members to terms of two (2) years, with the highest vote getters receiving
two-year terms. City commission appointments shall be two-year terms. A member shall serve no
more than three (3) consecutive terms.
b. Only business owners or representatives designated by business owners of a district within the
boundaries of the Emporia Downtown Business Improvement District shall be eligible to serve on
the advisory board.
(2) A vacancy occurring in the membership of the business improvement district advisory board shall
be filled through appointment by the advisory board. The new member shall fill the unexpired term.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 282/510
(3) The duties and responsibilities of the advisory board shall include, but not be limited to, the
following:
a. The business improvement district advisory board shall, not later than May 15 of each year,
submit to the governing body a recommended program of services to be performed or provided
within the district during the coming calendar year and a proposed budget to accomplish these
changes.
b. It shall be the responsibility of the advisory board to develop and implement bylaws to govern
the operation of the board.
c. It shall be the responsibility of the advisory board to insure that the program of services is
accomplished to the best of its ability each year.
(Ord. No. 86-21, § 4, 7-16-86; Ord. No. 87-21, § 2, 8-5-87)
Sec. 20-25. Penalty.
Any person convicted of violation of this article shall be fined in a sum no greater than five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. No. 86-21, § 5, 7-16-86)
