ARTICLE IV. TREE ADVISORY BOARD 164
Sec. 20-41. Creation and composition.
(a) Creation; membership . There is hereby created an advisory board to be known as the "City Tree
Advisory Board." The board shall consist of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the mayor,
with the consent of the governing body.
(b) Residence; appointment to fill vacancy; compensation . Four (4) of the five (5) members of the board
shall reside within the limits of the City of Emporia. The fifth member shall reside anywhere within the
limits of Lyon County. Appointment of new members to fill vacancies shall be made by the mayor with
the consent of the governing body. The members of the board shall serve without compensation.
(c) Term . One (1) member shall be designated to serve for a term of one (1) year, two (2) for a term of
two (2) years and two (2) for a term of three (3) years, and thereafter the members of such tree
advisory board shall hold their offices for a term of three (3) years and until their successor shall have
been appointed. Members shall serve no more than two (2) successive three-year terms in addition
to any unexpired term to which they may have been appointed.
(d) Meetings; quorum; attendance . The board shall meet regularly once each month, at a time decided
by the board for the purpose of conducting such business as may come before it. Special meetings
may be called by the chairperson or by a majority of the board presently serving. A majority of the
presently serving members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting the
business thereof. The board may, by majority vote of the board, recommend to the governing body
that a member's term be terminated and a new member to fill any unexpired term, whenever a
member fails to comply with the attendance requirements of the board's bylaws.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 283/510
(e) Officers . The board shall elect from among its members a chairperson and vice-chairperson. The
vice-chairperson shall act as the chairperson during the absence or incapacity of same. The term of
office for the chairperson and vice-chairperson shall be for one (1) year, and no person shall serve
more than two (2) consecutive years in the same office. The chairperson and vice-chairperson may
resign from office at any time during their terms and may do so without resigning from membership
on the board.
(f) Removal of member . No member or members of the board shall attempt to act on any matter over
which the board has jurisdiction unless and until the board has given prior approval to such action.
Any member of the board may be removed by the mayor with the consent of the governing body for
inefficiency, neglect of duty, or misconduct or malfeasance in office; no such removal shall be
effective until the member proposed to be removed has been furnished a written statement of the
charges and an opportunity to be heard thereon by the governing body.
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 1, 6-21-89; Ord. No. 93-2, § 1, 2-3-93)
Sec. 20-42. Duties and responsibilities.
It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update
annually, a written plan for trees and shrubs on public grounds and on other lands of public interest with
property owner cooperation. Such plan will be presented annually to the city commission and upon their
acceptance and approval, shall constitute the official Comprehensive City Tree Plan for the City of
Emporia, Kansas. The board, when requested by the city commission, shall consider, investigate, make
findings, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work.
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 2, 6-21-89)

POLICE 165
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. POLICE RESERVE
Sec. 21-11. Created:
A police reserve force is hereby created within the police department. (Ord. 208, § 1, 4-7-1965)
Sec. 21-12. Membership:
The members of the reserve police force shall be appointed by the city manager upon the
recommendation of the chief of police. Members shall serve on a voluntary basis without pay or
remuneration, and within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. 208, §§ 1, 2, 4-7-1965)
Sec. 21-13. Commanding Officer:
The chief of police shall be the commanding officer of the reserve police force and shall have control of
the assignment, training, stationing and direction in work of the members thereof. (Ord. 208, § 3, 4-7-
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 284/510
1965)
Sec. 21-14. Powers And Functions:
The members of the reserve police force shall not have police powers except when actually called on
active duty by the chief of police or the city manager. The reserve police force, when on duty, shall be
governed by the same rules and regulations governing members of the regular police force. The reserve
police force shall be ready at all times to assist the police department and police officers in periods of
national emergency, disaster, catastrophe or any other occasion when additional policemen may be
necessary or desirable as determined by the chief of police or the city manager. (Ord. 208, §§ 4-6, 4-7-
1965)
Secs. 21-15-21-19. Reserved:
ARTICLE III. LYON COUNTY 911 BOARD
Sec. 21-20. Agreement:
The city commission of the city of Emporia, Kansas, agrees to consolidate the emergency
communications for the Lyon County sheriff's office, the Lyon County rural fire departments, the Lyon
County emergency medical services, the police and fire department of the city of Emporia pursuant to
the authority of KSA 12-2904. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-21. Definitions:
As used in the resolution and ordinance the following definitions shall apply:
Board: The Lyon County 911 board.
Commission: The board of county commissioners of Lyon County.
Department: The director of Lyon County emergency communications.
911 Director: The director of the Lyon County emergency communications department. (Ord. 14-01,
1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-22. Lyon County 911 Board Created:
There is hereby created the Lyon County 911 board. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-23. Membership, Term:
The board shall consist of the Lyon County sheriff, the Lyon County emergency manager, the Emporia
police chief, the Emporia fire chief, the Emporia assistant chief for EMS, the captain of the ESU police
and one rural volunteer fire chief. The members of the board shall assume membership upon their
appointment or election to their respective positions. They will serve on the board as long as they hold
their respective election office or appointed position. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-24. Meetings And Organizations:
The board shall convene for its first meeting within thirty (30) days after adoption of the ordinance by the
city and adoption by resolution by the commission and thereafter its meetings shall be at such a time
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 285/510
and place as shall be fixed by the chair of the 911 board. The board shall elect one member as chair and
one member as vice chair. The terms of the chair and vice chair shall be for one year. No person shall
serve as the chair or vice chair more than two (2) consecutive years. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-25. Responsibilities Of The Commission:
The commission shall be responsible for reviewing reports from the board, providing personnel policy
guidance and approval of funding of the 911 budget. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-26. Responsibilities Of The Lyon County 911 Board:
The board shall be responsible for determining operational policies and procedures of the center.
Annually the board shall develop along with the 911 director, an operating budget and submit it for
approval to the board of county commissioners. The 911 board will annually conduct an evaluation of the
911 director and forward the conclusions of the same to the commission for their review and approval.
(Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-27. Lyon County Emergency Communications Center Authority, Function,
Responsibility And Location Of The Emergency Communications Operations:
The department will provide emergency communications for first/emergency responders in Lyon County.
The department will be physically located in the Emporia police department until the decision is made by
the commission to move the center to a county owned location. The physical relocation of existing
communications functions will be made as soon as practical and financially feasible after adoption of the
agreement by the Emporia city commission and by the board of county commissioners. (Ord. 14-01, 1-
15-2014)
Sec. 21-28. Budget, Disbursing Agent:
On or before June 1 of each year, the 911 director shall submit to the board, a budget of income and
expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year. This budget shall be submitted for review and comment. After
such review and comment, such budget shall be considered by the commission; and such budget as
approved shall be funded by the commission. The county treasurer is hereby designated as the
custodian and disbursing agent for the total budget. In the event funds for emergency communications
services are received from sources other than Lyon County then such funds shall be put into a fund for
new equipment. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-29. Director Of The Lyon County Emergency Communications Center:
The 911 director shall be hired by a majority vote of the board with final approval of the commission. The
911 director will serve at the pleasure of the 911 board with the advice and consent of the commission.
The 911 director shall serve in the capacity of the department head and shall exercise the day to day
supervision over all employees within the department. The 911 director shall act as staff to the board
and the 911 director will be required to develop a written standard operation procedure for the
department to be approved by the board. The 911 director shall be responsible for the employment and
discharge of all personnel of the department with the advice and consent of the commission. The 911
director shall be responsible for maintaining a record of the minutes of all meetings of the board and
further the 911 director will provide a monthly report to the board, and said report shall be submitted to
the commission detailing the activities of the department. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-30. Employees:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 286/510
The 911 director and all employees of the department will be paid for their services rendered by Lyon
County in the same manner and at the same time as all other employees. The 911 director and all
employees of the department shall operate under the Lyon County personnel policies. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-
2014)
Sec. 21-31. Equipment:
All equipment owned by the county and city presently utilized in emergency communications dispatch
centers will be assigned to the 911 department. If this agreement is terminated, all usable equipment will
be returned to the county or city whose previous ownership is shown on attachment A of the agreement.
(Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-32. Agreement And Effective Dates:
The resolution and ordinance implementing consolidation of dispatch shall constitute an interlocal
cooperation agreement between the city of Emporia and the board of commissioners of Lyon County
and shall take effect upon approval of the attorney general of the state of Kansas and upon compliance
with KSA 12-2904 et seq., its publication once in the official county newspaper. A fully executed and
attested copy shall be filed with the county clerk of Lyon County, register of deeds of Lyon County,
Kansas, and the city clerk of the city of Emporia, Kansas. (Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-33. Initial Equipment Purchase:
The parties to the agreement agree that the consolidated dispatch center known as Lyon County
emergency communications center will require new upgraded communications equipment, hereinafter
described as "the initial equipment".
The initial equipment shall be purchased by either the city of Emporia or Lyon County whichever entity
can obtain the most competitive pricing, with the nonpurchasing party contributing fifty percent (50%) of
the total cost of said initial equipment. Irrespective of which party purchases the initial equipment, title to
said equipment shall vest with Lyon County. The city of Emporia shall utilize its existing 911 funds
available at the time the agreement is approved by the attorney general for the purchase of initial
equipment. Once said purchase is complete all remaining 911 funds shall be transferred to the county.
(Ord. 14-01, 1-15-2014)
Sec. 21-34. Duration Of Agreement:
The agreement between the board of county commissioners of Lyon County and the Emporia city
commission on the operation of emergency communications for Emporia and Lyon County shall remain
in effect from the date of execution of the agreement until terminated as provided herein. The city
commission or county commission can unilaterally withdraw from the agreement by giving written notice
on or before July 1 of any year to be effective as of December 31 of the following year. The county
commission and the city commission can agree to amend or withdraw from this agreement at any time
by mutually agreed upon joint resolution of the commission and ordinance of the city commission. (Ord.
14-01, 1-15-2014)
Secs. 21-35-21-44. Reserved:
Chapter 22
RAILROADS 166
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 287/510
Sec. 22-1. Obstructing crossings.
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the free use and passage of any street, crosswalk or
sidewalk in the city by means of any railroad car or locomotive engine for a period of time longer than
five (5) minutes.
(Code 1962, § 16-101)
State law reference- Certain persons not subject to penalty for violation of above section, K.S.A. 66-
274.
Sec. 22-2. Speed limit.
It shall be unlawful for any person or any railroad or railway company or corporation to move, propel or
drive, or cause to be moved, propelled or driven, any train, railroad car, locomotive engine or other
power driven railroad vehicle within the city at a speed in excess of thirty (30) miles per hour.
(Code 1962, § 16-102; Ord. No. 825, § 1, 4-20-77)
State law reference- Authority to regulate speed of trains, K.S.A. 12-1633.
Sec. 22-3. Climbing on cars; blocking trains.
No person, except regular passengers, railroad employees and other authorized persons shall climb
upon, over, under or through any moving railroad cars or locomotive engines or cross the railroad tracks
immediately in front of any such cars or engines in motion.
(Code 1962, § 16-103; Ord. No. 825, § 1, 4-20-77)
Chapter 23
SOLID WASTES 167 , 168
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 23-1. Definitions:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Disposal Container : Containers to be collected with their contents for disposal and not to exceed thirty
five (35) gallons in capacity.
Garbage : All putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, including vegetable and animal offal
and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding recognized industrial byproducts, and shall include all
such substances from all public and private establishments and from all residences.
Permanent Solid Waste Container : An enclosed metal one, two (2) or four (4) yard container provided
for lease by the city of Emporia and reusable plastic and metal containers with handles, not exceeding
thirty five (35) gallons in capacity, for use as solid waste containers.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 288/510
Polycart : A container provided by the city of Emporia, Kansas, for the collection of solid waste. The
polycart is typically made of plastic or rubber and can be of various capacities. The polycart is portable
and has a lid that closes.
Refuse : Solid wastes resulting from normal community activities, including all garbage and rubbish.
Rubbish : All nonputrescible solid wastes, such as paper, wood, excelsior, yard trimmings, cans, glass,
ashes, leaves, etc.
Yard Waste : Organic material consisting of leaves, grass clippings, and other forms of organic garden
waste. (1962 Code, § 18-101; Ord. 92-9, § 1, 4-1-1992; Ord. 97-41, § 1, 11-5-1997; Ord. 06-03, § 1, 2-1-
2006)
Sec. 23-2. Prohibited Practices:
No person shall:
(1) Deposit garbage, refuse or rubbish from a residence or business in sidewalk litter receptacles
provided for collecting litter from pedestrians or others using the streets and sidewalks; or
(2) Deposit garbage, refuse or rubbish in any solid waste container other than his own without the
written consent of the owner of such container or with the intent of avoiding payment of the service
charge hereinafter provided for solid waste collection and disposal; provided that the above and
foregoing shall not apply to the proper use of sidewalk litter receptacles; or
(3) Interfere in any matter with solid waste collection equipment or with solid waste collectors in the
lawful performance of their duties as such; or
(4) Dispose of solid waste at a facility which is not approved by the city. (1962 Code, § 18-102a; Ord.
415, § 1, 9-17-1969; Ord. 938, § 1, 2-7-1979; Ord. 92-9, § 2, 4-1-1992)
Sec. 23-3. Backyards, Occupant's Duties:
The owner or occupant of any business lot, house or mercantile establishment, shall keep the property
between the rear of the building and the alley line, clean and clear of all garbage, trash, refuse, paper,
bottles, cans or other waste material. (Ord. 92-9, § 3, 4-1-1992)
Secs. 23-4-23-13. Reserved:
ARTICLE II. MUNICIPAL COLLECTION SERVICE
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 23-14. Use Generally:
No owner or lessee or any other person owning any public or private premises, shall accumulate upon
the premises any refuse, garbage or rubbish except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
and in accordance with the provisions of rules and regulations promulgated by the city manager for the
storage and collection of garbage, refuse and rubbish. Such rules and regulations shall include, but not
be limited to, the following:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 289/510
(1) All refuse, garbage and rubbish shall be accumulated for collection by the city in containers
approved by the city;
(2) Containers, except those specifically designed for mechanical lifting and emptying by the city
sanitation trucks, shall be designed not to exceed thirty five (35) gallons in capacity;
(3) Containers shall be constructed so as to be strong, not easily corroded, rodentproof, insectproof,
and shall be kept tightly covered at all times except when refuse is being deposited therein or
removed therefrom;
(4) No refuse resulting from the repair or remodeling of buildings, sidewalks, or other structures shall
be deposited for collection in said refuse containers;
(5) Garbage must be drained and wrapped in paper prior to being deposited in the refuse container;
(6) Plastic bags impervious to air circulation may be used as containers for garbage, refuse or
rubbish so long as the bag opening is kept securely tied or clamped shut except when rubbish is
being deposited in or removed from the bag;
(7) The owners of commercial buildings shall be responsible for assuring that there is an adequate
supply of appropriate refuse containers and collection frequency to preclude overflow at any time;
(8) Nonconforming containers may be collected together with their contents and disposed of. (1962
Code, § 18-102; Ord. 415, § 1, 9-17-1969; Ord. 938, § 1, 2-7-1979; Ord. 92-9, § 4, 4-1-1992; Ord.
99-6, § 1, 4-7-1999; Ord. 03-07, § 1, 2-26-2003; Ord. 06-03, § 2, 2-1-2006)
Sec. 23-15. Collection Service A Municipal Function; Exception:
(a)The collection of refuse within the city is hereby deemed solely a municipal function.
(b)To ensure the greatest efficiency and lowest cost in such collection to all the citizens of the city, the
city shall be the sole provider of such service, and commercial collection of refuse by any other
person, firm or corporation within the city limits is hereby strictly prohibited.
(c)Nothing contained herein shall prevent or be construed as preventing or prohibiting the commercial
collection of refuse not regularly collected within the city by the municipal refuse service nor as
prohibiting an individual or business from disposing personally of their own refuse in an approved
manner.
(d)The city manager shall have the authority to promulgate rules and regulations not inconsistent with
the terms of this section nor with this chapter, as amended, regarding the collection, hauling and
disposal of refuse.
(e)Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, any "trash hauler" as defined under article III of this
chapter, as amended, operating under a license issued pursuant to the terms of said article III of this
chapter shall not be prohibited from the operation of such business until the expiration, revocation or
other termination of his license. (Ord. 85-33, §§ 1-5, 9-18-1985; Ord. 85-51, § 1, 12-18-1985)
Sec. 23-16. Location Of Refuse And Polycart Containers:
(a)Refuse Containers :
(1) Collection From The Street : If the refuse collection vehicle makes the collection of refuse from
the street, disposable containers or permanent solid waste containers, not provided by the city, shall
be placed by the resident near the back of the curb or edge of the roadway but not in the street. Such
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 290/510
containers shall not be placed out for collection earlier than twelve (12) hours in advance of the start
of the scheduled collections. Exemptions to the curb line placement of such containers may be made
by the director of public works if, for valid physical reasons, no member of the household can be
expected to carry the containers to the curb line.
(2) Collection From The Alley : If the sanitation truck makes the collection of refuse from the alley,
permanent or disposable refuse containers shall be placed on private property near the alley line in
racks or in designated spaces with rails or guards to prevent them from being overturned.
(b)Polycart Containers :
(1) Collection From The Street : Collection of refuse from polycart containers provided by the city will
be from the street. Polycart containers shall be placed within five feet (5') of the back of the curb but
not in the roadway. The polycart container shall be placed so the lid opens toward the street and
such that there is a five foot (5') clear space on either side of the polycart. (Ord. 92-9, § 5, 4-1-1992;
Ord. 97-41, § 2, 11-5-1997)
Sec. 23-17. Certain Refuse Not Collected By City:
(a)Refuse generated by contractors and refuse items too bulky to be placed in containers shall not be
collected by the city.
(b)The removal of contagious disease refuse, or wearing apparel, bedding or other refuse from homes or
other places where highly infectious or contagious diseases have prevailed shall be performed under
the supervision and direction of the county health department or other healthcare professional.
(c)Inflammable or explosive refuse and highly flammable or explosive materials shall not be placed in
containers for regular collection.
(d)Permitted industrial waste, tires, and lead acid batteries shall not be placed in containers for regular
collection. (Ord. 92-9, § 6, 4-1-1992; Ord. 06-03, § 3, 2-1-2006)
Sec. 23-18. Miscellaneous Unlawful Practices:
It is hereby deemed unlawful:
(1) For any person to intentionally place, in any solid waste container or disposable container
anything other than the appropriate materials for pick up and to place that container at the curbside
for collection.
(2) For the owner or person in control of any dog or cat to allow that dog or cat to damage any
container or disturb the contents thereof after that container has been properly placed for collection.
(Ord. 92-9, § 7, 4-1-1992)
Sec. 23-19. Polycarts:
(a)Provision And Collection : Except as otherwise provided in this section, the city will provide a single
polycart to the resident without cost. Collection of the refuse will be provided once per week on a day
to be established by the city. In the event that the polycart is lost or stolen, the resident will notify the
police department and file a stolen property report. Upon the filing of such report, the polycart will be
replaced at no additional cost.
(b)Care And Maintenance : Standard maintenance of the physical condition of the polycart due to normal
usage will be performed by the city. The resident shall be responsible for the cleaning and storage of
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 291/510
the polycart. If a polycart is damaged due to abuse, placement of hazardous materials, or extremely
heavy materials within the cart, the resident will be charged for the replacement of the polycart at the
cost charged by the manufacturer to the city, plus an administrative charge of eight dollars ($8.00).
(c)Usage Of The Polycart: Residents provided the polycart shall utilize the cart for solid waste collection
in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the following:
(1) All refuse, garbage and rubbish shall be placed inside the polycart for collection by the city.
(2) All refuse, garbage and rubbish to be collected must be contained within the polycart and no
loose materials/refuse will be collected.
(3) Solvents, liquids or hazardous materials must not be placed in the polycarts.
(4) No hot ashes are to be placed in the polycart. Extremely heavy objects, such as concrete, engine
blocks, etc., should not be placed within the polycart.
(d)Additional Fees:
(1) If a resident finds that the polycart provided does not have sufficient capacity to contain the refuse
generated by the household, it is the resident's responsibility to notify the sanitation department and
request an additional container. The fee for each additional container provided shall be at the rate
shown in section 23-26 of this chapter.
(2) If a polycart cannot be physically picked up by the sanitation collection vehicle due to obstructed
access (i.e., a vehicle parked in front of the polycart or the cart being placed next to a tree/mailbox) it
will be passed for collection. Upon request by the resident, a special pick up can be made at an
additional cost shown in section 23-26 of this chapter.
(3) If the refuse generated by the household is in excess of the polycart capacity, an additional or
loose pick up can be made upon request of the owner at an additional cost shown in section 23-26 of
this chapter.
(e)Other Regulations: All other provisions of this chapter pertaining to municipal collection of solid waste
shall be applicable to the use of polycarts to the extent that such regulations are not inconsistent with
the provisions of this section. In the event that such regulations are inconsistent with this section, the
provisions of this section shall control. (Ord. 97-41, § 3, 11-5-1997; Ord. 03-07, § 2, 2-26-2003; Ord.
06-03, § 4, 2-1-2006; Ord. 09-30, 10-21-2009)
Secs. 23-20-23-25. Reserved:

Sec. 23-27. Collection:
The charge for the collection of refuse will be made at the same time and in the same manner as the
charge for the water utility service offered and furnished by the city, and such refuse charge shall be due
and payable at the same time and place as the charge for the water utility service that is due and
payable. The charge for refuse collections and the charge for water utility service are hereby declared to
be parts of one debt to the city insofar as the same affects any one customer or consumer, and the
refusal or failure to pay any part of such debt for any monthly period of service in accordance with the
rules and regulations established by the governing body shall be sufficient cause for discontinuing water
utility service. (1962 Code, §§ 18-106, 18-107)
Sec. 23-28. Exemptions:
Exemptions from payment of municipal refuse collection fees shall be granted to business
establishments who dispose of their own refuse or whose refuse is collected and disposed of in an
approved manner; provided, that all establishments receiving water service shall be subject to such
charges. (1962 Code, § 18-108)
Secs. 23-29-23-39. Reserved:
ARTICLE III. PRIVATE TRASH HAULERS 169
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 23-40. Definitions:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Trash : Refuse, waste material, litter, ashes, sawdust, leaves, grass cuttings, shrubbery and tree
trimmings, shavings, packing materials, boxes, excelsior, household rubbish and the like.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 294/510
Trash Hauler : Any person who is engaged in the business of collecting, hauling and disposing of trash
for hire. (Ord. 220, § 1, 9-1-1965)
Sec. 23-41. Rules And Regulations:
The city manager shall have the authority to make rules and regulations not inconsistent with the terms
of this article requiring the collection, hauling and disposal of trash to be done in such a manner as not to
endanger the public health and safety. (Ord. 220, § 7, 9-1-1965)
Secs. 23-42-23-52. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 23-53. Required:
No person shall operate a trash hauling business for hire without possessing a valid, unexpired and
unrevoked license issued by the city. (Ord. 220, § 2, 9-1-1965)
Sec. 23-54. Application:
Application for a license required by this division shall be made to the city clerk on an application form
prepared in duplicate. The city clerk shall supply the form. The application shall set forth the name of the
applicant, his address and the make and type of vehicle to be used for collection and hauling of trash.
(Ord. 220, § 4(a), (c), 9-1-1965)
Sec. 23-55. Investigation And Issuance:
(a) Upon the filing of an application, the chief of police or his representative shall inspect the vehicle of
the applicant to determine that the vehicle to be used is mechanically and operationally safe. If the
vehicle is found to be unsafe, the chief of police shall so report to the city clerk, and the license shall
be denied. If the vehicle is found to be safe, the chief of police shall so report to the city clerk. The
report shall be returned to the city clerk not more than five (5) days after application is made.
(b) Upon the filing of an application, the city manager or his representative shall investigate the
applicant's qualifications and ability to collect, haul and dispose of trash in a satisfactory manner, and
the sufficiency of the construction of the applicant's vehicle to haul trash without the contents of the
hauling bed escaping. If the applicant or his vehicle is found not to be qualified, the city manager
shall so report to the city clerk, and the license shall be denied. If the applicant and his vehicle are
found to be qualified, the city manager shall so report to the city clerk. The report shall be returned to
the city clerk not more than five (5) days after application is made.
(c) An investigation fee of five dollars ($5.00), which fee shall be in addition to the license fee, shall be
paid to the city clerk at the time the application for a license is made.
(d) If the reports of the chief of police and the city manager indicate that the applicant is qualified, the city
clerk shall then issue the license. (Ord. 220, § 5, 9-1-1965)
Sec. 23-56. Fee:
The fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each vehicle
to be operated pursuant to such license. Such fee shall be paid at the time the license application is
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 295/510
made. If the license is not issued, the city clerk shall return the fee to the applicant. The full amount of
the fee shall be paid regardless of when the license is issued. (Ord. 220, §§ 3, 4(b), 9-1-1965)
Sec. 23-57. Term:
A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight
on December 31 next following its issuance, provided, however, that such term shall be specifically
subject and limited by the other provisions of this division. (Ord. 220, § 3, 9-1-1965; Ord. 85-51, § 2, 12-
18-1985)
Sec. 23-58. Revocation:
(a) The governing body of the city, upon ten (10) days' written notice to the person or persons holding
the license may revoke a license issued pursuant to this division with or without cause at any time
the governing body deems it expedient to the efficient transition of refuse collection to an exclusive
collection function. Any trash hauler licensee shall have the opportunity to appear before the
governing body prior to revocation to present cause why the license should not be revoked and
notice of said opportunity shall be set forth in the aforementioned notice. The notice provided for
hereunder shall be deemed sufficient if delivered personally or forwarded by certified or registered
mail to the address contained in the licensee's application as provided by section 23-54 of this
division.
(b) Any of the following reasons shall be deemed sufficient cause for revocation of any license issued
pursuant to this division but the same shall not be deemed an exclusive listing:
(1) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement in applying for a license hereunder or in the course of
carrying on the business licensed.
(2) Any violation of the provisions of this section.
(3) Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude.
(4) Conducting the business of the licensee in an unlawful manner or in a manner constituting a
breach of the peace or a menace to health, safety and the general welfare of the public.
(5) Conviction of violating any ordinance or law prohibiting littering 170 .
(6) Conviction during the license period of more than two (2) traffic offenses. (Ord. 220, § 8, 9-1-
1965; Ord. 85-51, § 3, 12-18-1985)
Sec. 23-59. Sunset Provisions:
(a) This article, as amended, shall by this provision expire on a quarterly basis during the calendar year
unless the governing body at its first meeting after such date affirmatively by resolution finds that it is
necessary and desirable to extend the provisions of this article for another quarter. Provided that any
trash hauler licensed under the provisions of this article shall have the opportunity to appear at any
meeting at which the governing body shall be considering extending this article for purposes of
showing cause why the provisions of this article should be extended. In the event the governing body
does not take the affirmative action provided for herein any license issued under the provisions of
this article shall be deemed null and void as of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on the date of the
article's expiration and such trash hauler shall be at that point without authority to continue
commercial collection of refuse within the city limits.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 296/510
(b) For purposes of this section, the "date of the article's expiration" shall be deemed to be the date of
the first official meeting of the governing body after a regular quarterly expiration date whereat the
governing body fails to affirmatively extend the provisions of this article.
(c) For the purposes of this section, the term "quarterly" shall mean a period of three (3) calendar
months. (Ord. 220, § 8, 9-1-1965; Ord. 85-51, § 4, 12-18-1985)
Secs. 23-60-23-69. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. LANDFILL
Sec. 23-70. Established:
The governing body shall designate an area of land for the purpose of a sanitary landfill. (1962 Code, §
18-201; Ord. 1110, § 1, 9-1-1982)
Sec. 23-71. Management And Control:
The management of the sanitary landfill shall be under the control of the city manager. The city manager
may enter into agreements with any person as shall be deemed in the best interest of the city in the
operation of the facility. (1962 Code, § 18-202; Ord. 1110, § 1, 9-1-1982)
Sec. 23-72. Rules And Regulations:
(a) The operation of the transfer station is subject to various federal and state statutory and regulatory
requirements. The right is hereby reserved to refuse to accept the deposit of any waste at the
transfer station or condition the acceptance of such waste as may be necessary to comply with the
aforementioned requirements.
(b) The city manager may from time to time as deemed necessary, adopt and promulgate rules and
regulations for the safe and efficient operation of the transfer station. (1962 Code, § 18-203; Ord.
1110, § 1, 9-1-1982; Ord. 91-1, § 2, 1-2-1991; Ord. 94-21, § 2, 4-6-1994; Ord. 98-2, § 2, 1-7-1998)
Sec. 23-73. Jurisdiction Of City Ordinances, Etc.:
The city does hereby extend all its police powers and ordinances pertaining thereto and over the
sanitary landfill property and grounds to the same degree and with the same force and effect as if said
property were situated within the corporate limits of the city. (1962 Code, § 18-204; Ord. 1110, § 1, 9-1-
1982)

ARTICLE V. RECYCLING
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 23-81. Definitions:
Collection Point: The location specified in the curbside recycling service rules and regulations adopted
pursuant to this division.
MRF: Material recovery facility.
Organized Collection Service: A system for collecting solid waste, recyclables or both, including
franchise, organized collection, or a process in which a municipality goes from multiple haulers to one
single contracted hauler in which a specified collector, or a member of an organization of collectors, is
authorized to collect from a defined geographic service area or areas some or all of the solid waste or
recyclables that is released by generators.
Permitted Recyclable Materials: Those materials set forth in this division which the city will accept as
recyclable material in its residential recycling collection service.
Recyclable Materials: Any refuse designated from time to time by the governing body by ordinance as
being a permitted recyclable material for the purposes of separate disposal and collection by the city.
Single Stream: Commingled recyclable materials collected in a single recyclable container from singlefamily
and multi-family residential customers. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-82. Establishment Of Service; Residential Recycling:
After October 17, 2014, the city shall have the right to collect "permitted recyclable materials", as defined
in this division, for single-family and multi-family dwellings within the city limits of the city of Emporia,
Kansas, which utilize polycart refuse collection service. After October 17, 2014, no other person or
business shall collect residential permitted recyclable materials within the city unless authorized by
license or other formal agreement with the city. The city shall establish, maintain, and conduct a service
for the collection of residential recyclable materials and shall purchase such equipment and engage
such employees as may be needed, and shall pay such prices, salaries and wages as the city
commission may authorize for efficient operation of such service. The city may contract with a material
recovery facility (MRF) that provides recyclable material processing and related services. (Ord. 13-14, 4-
17-2013)
Sec. 23-83. Supervision; Rules And Regulations:
The collection, transportation, and recycling of residential recyclable materials shall be at all times under
the general supervision of the director of public works, who shall have the authority to promulgate rules
and regulations not inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this division, city ordinances and state
law. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-84. Voluntary Participation:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 300/510
Nothing in this division shall prohibit any person from declining to recycle or from transporting or
recycling his or her own residential recyclable materials. Those persons transporting or recycling their
own residential recyclable materials shall not be relieved from the monthly residential solid waste
charge, which shall include the residential recycling service charge, if any, imposed in accordance with
this division. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-85. Recycling Collection Services For Single-Family Residential Polycart
Customers:
(a)The city shall provide "single stream" recycling collection services for "permitted recyclable materials",
as defined in this division, for all single-family residential customers. The single-family residential
customers' collection point for recyclable materials shall be adjacent to the customer's polycart
collection point. The city shall provide containers for recyclable materials.
(b)The frequency of the residential recycling collection service shall be once every other week.
(c)The collection service schedule shall be established by the Emporia public works department. (Ord.
13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-86. Recycling Collection Services For Multi-Family Residential Polycart
Customers:
(a)The city shall provide "single stream" recycling collection services for "permitted recyclable materials",
as defined in this division, for multi-family residential polycart customers. The multi-family residential
customers' collection service for recyclable materials shall be similar to the method in which the
customers' solid waste is collected. The city shall provide the multi-family residential customers with
access to polycarts for recyclable materials at locations near the customers' solid waste service
collection point.
(b)The recycling service collection schedule and frequency of service shall be set forth in the residential
recycling collection service rules and regulations. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-87. Containers For Recyclable Materials:
(a)Single-Family Residential Customers: The city shall provide single-family residential customers one
95-gallon polycart for recyclable materials. Single-family residential customers may decline the
polycart for recyclables.
(b)Multi-Family Residential Customers: The city shall provide multi-family residential customers one 95-
gallon polycart for each family unit for recyclable materials. Multi-family residential customers may
decline the polycart for recyclables.
(c)Containers Exclusively For Recyclable Materials: Containers for recyclable materials shall be marked
accordingly and shall be used for recyclable materials only and shall not be used by customers to
contain refuse, yard waste, or any other materials other than permitted recyclable materials. The
polycarts for recyclable materials shall be the property of the city. The owner or occupant of any
single-family dwelling unit or owner of a multi-family unit or complex shall be responsible for cleaning
and the day to day care of the containers for recyclable materials provided to them, and replacement
value of damaged polycarts. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-88. Permitted Recyclable Materials:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 301/510
Residential customers may place the following materials in their designated container for recyclable
materials for collection service:
(1) Glass food and beverage containers (glass bottles and jars);
(2) Mixed paper (magazines, catalogues, junk mail, chipboard, milk/juice containers, paperback
books and telephone books);
(3) Newsprint (newspaper and advertising supplements);
(4) Office paper (printer and copier paper);
(5) Shredded paper, provided it is bagged in clear, plastic bags;
(6) Corrugated cardboard containers (unwaxed cardboard boxes);
(7) Tin, steel, aluminum and bimetal food and beverage containers;
(8) Scrap metal sized to less than thirty inches (30") in each direction and less than fifty (50) pounds
per piece (pots, pans, screen door trim, metal fixtures);
(9) Plastic containers marked with recycling symbols #1 through #7 (plastic bottles, tubs and jars);
and
The governing body may, from time to time, by ordinance, alter or amend the list of "permitted recyclable
materials". (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-89. Preparation And Placement Of Permitted Recyclable Materials By
Customers:
All permitted recyclable materials shall be empty, clean and dry. All permitted recyclable materials
consisting of paper materials shall be clean and dry. Residential recycling customers shall comply with
the city's rules and regulations concerning the preparation of recyclable materials for collection. (Ord.
13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-90. Residential Recycling Fees:
(a)For all single-family dwellings, and for each family dwelling unit in multi-family dwellings not charged
commercial container rates, residential recycling service charges will be included in the standard
monthly solid waste service charge, effective October 17, 2014.
(b)Such charges shall be billed by and paid to the city clerk on a monthly basis. Should the charges for
residential recycling service become delinquent, the city clerk shall pursue payment in the manner in
which it collects other delinquent city utility bills.
(c)Residential recycling service customers who believe there is an error in the bill or charges, shall
report the alleged error to the city clerk's utility billing office within thirty (30) days of receipt of the bill
so that corrections may be made, if appropriate. The city manager shall make recommendations to
the city commission concerning residential recycling collection service charges annually, including
whether existing rates are sufficient to balance the fees and expenses, including capital costs, such
that the program is revenue neutral. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-91. Unlawful Acts:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 302/510
On and after October 17, 2014, it shall be unlawful for any person to:
(1) Remove any portion of the contents of any residential recyclable materials container, or remove
any material placed by residents or occupants of any residential dwellings at the designated
recyclable materials collection point;
(2) Upset, turn over, remove or carry away a recyclable materials container, or to damage such
container in any manner;
(3) Set out, or cause to be set out, recyclable materials for collection that do not originate from the
premises where it is set out unless specifically approved by the director of public works in each case;
(4) Place any material other than permitted recyclable materials;
(5) To intentionally contaminate or soil recyclable materials so as to cause the city or an MRF to
reject a load or loads of recyclable materials;
(6) To damage, destroy carts or trash dumpsters for recyclable materials. (Ord. 13-14, 4-17-2013)
Sec. 23-92. Penalties:
Engaging in any of the unlawful acts set forth in this section shall be a separate municipal offense. Any
person violating a provision of this division shall upon an adjudication of guilt or the entry of a plea of no
contest, be subject to a minimum fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each unlawful act. (Ord. 13-14,
4-17-2013)
Secs. 23-93-23-130. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. NATURAL RESOURCES ADVISORY BOARD
Sec. 23-131. Creation And Composition:
(a)Creation; Membership : There is hereby created an advisory board to be known as the natural
resources advisory board. The board shall consist of not less than eight (8) members and not more
than twelve (12) members. Eight (8) of the members shall be appointed by the Emporia city
commission. Two (2) members shall be appointed by the Lyon County commission. Two (2)
members shall be appointed by the Chase County commission.
(b)Residence; Appointment To Fill Vacancy; Compensation : Members of the board shall reside within
the limits of Lyon County or Chase County. Any member who moves his or her residence outside
their respective area shall automatically cease to be a member, and a vacancy shall thereby be
created. Appointment of members to fill vacancies shall be made in the same manner as the original
appointment. The members of the board shall serve without compensation.
(c)Term : Members of such natural resources advisory board shall hold their offices for a term of three
(3) years and until their successor shall have been appointed. Members shall serve no more than two
(2) successive three (3) year terms in addition to any unexpired term to which they may have been
appointed.
(d)Meetings; Quorum; Attendance : The board shall meet on an as needed basis, at a time decided by
the board for the purpose of conducting such business as may come before it. Special meetings may
be called by the chairperson or by a majority of the board presently serving. A majority of the
presently serving members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting the
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 303/510
business thereof. The board may, by majority vote of the board, recommend to the governing body
that a member's term be terminated and a new member appointed to fill any unexpired term,
whenever a member fails to comply with the attendance requirements of the board's bylaws.
(e)Officers : The board shall elect from among its members a chairperson and vice chairperson. The
vice chairperson shall act as the chairperson during the absence or incapacity of same. The term of
office for the chairperson and vice chairperson shall be for one year, and no person shall serve more
than two (2) consecutive years in the same office. The chairperson and vice chairperson may resign
from office at any time during their terms and may do so without resigning from membership on the
board.
(f)Removal Of Member : No member or members of the board shall attempt to act on any matter over
which the board has jurisdiction unless and until the board has given prior approval to such action.
Any member of the board may be removed by the mayor with the consent of the governing body for
inefficiency, neglect of duty, or misconduct or malfeasance in office; no such removal shall be
effective until the member proposed to be removed has been furnished a written statement of the
charges and an opportunity to be heard thereon by the governing body. (Ord. 90-20, § 1, 10-17-1990;
Ord. 95-48, § 1, 12-20-1995; Ord. 05-16, § 1, 4-20-2005)
Sec. 23-132. Duties And Responsibilities:
It shall be the responsibility of the board to study and promote recycling and resource conservation. The
board, when requested by the city commission, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and
recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. (Ord. 90-20, § 2,
10-17-1990)
Chapter 24
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 1
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 24-1. Obstructing Street Or Sidewalk:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction on any street, alley,
sidewalk or other public way, except as may be specified by ordinance or be necessitated by public
improvements. It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any booth, stand, gasoline pump, air station or
other similar structure or device upon any street, alley or sidewalk in the city, except as may be
specified by ordinance.
(b)The provisions of this article prohibiting the obstruction of any street, sidewalk or alley shall not be
applicable to any fence, barricade, scaffold, sidewalk shed or walkway erected and maintained in
accordance with the provisions of the building code or other ordinances of the city. (1962 Code, §§
20-401, 20-403; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-2. Encroachments:
It shall be unlawful to erect any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or alley.
(1962 Code, § 20-402; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-3. Disturbing Barricades And Lights:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 304/510
It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade, light or other warning sign placed to protect
or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk or to
safeguard the traveling public. (1962 Code, § 20-404; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-4. Injuring New Pavement:
It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure in any manner any newly
laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign, light or barricade. (1962
Code, § 20-405; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-5. Steps Extending Into The Street:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any portico, platform or doorstep extending into any street, alley
or sidewalk. (1962 Code, § 20-406; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-6. Display Of Goods:
It shall be unlawful to use any street, sidewalk or other public place as space for the display of goods or
merchandise for sale or to write or make any sign for advertisement upon any such street, sidewalk or
other public place, except as may be specified by ordinance. (1962 Code, § 20-407; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-
1977)
Sec. 24-7. Obstruction Of Drains:
It shall be unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street property. (1962 Code, § 20-410; Ord. 847, §
1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-8. Removal Of Snow, Ice And Dirt From Sidewalks:
It is hereby made the duty of the owner and of the occupant of any lots abutting upon any sidewalks to
cause to be removed from such sidewalks all snow and ice within five (5) hours from the time the said
snow has fallen or ice has accumulated; provided, that if the snow falls or ice accumulates upon said
sidewalks in the nighttime, removal of same must be made within five (5) hours after sunrise on the
following day. Such owner and occupant must at all times keep the surface of such sidewalks free from
dirt, mud and all other obstructions. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). Whenever snow or ice is not
removed as herein provided, the city manager may cause such snow and ice to be removed and the
cost therefor shall be assessed against the abutting lot or lots and collected as provided by law. (1962
Code, § 20-411; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-1977)
Sec. 24-9. Reserved:
Sec. 24-10. Trees And Shrubs:
(a) Removal Of Obstructions :
(1) It shall be the duty of the owner of real property to remove from such property or from the public
right of way adjacent to such property, including, without limitation, the streets, alleys, avenues,
boulevards, public parking portions thereof, and other public rights of way within such city, any tree,
plant, shrub or other obstruction, or part thereof, which: a) obstructs the view of any driver,
constituting a traffic hazard; or b) overhangs or grows over or on any sidewalk, street, or other public
way in such a way as to impede, obstruct or interfere with traffic or travel on such public way.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 305/510
(2) When the city engineer, or other local authority designated by the governing body, determines
upon the basis of an engineering or traffic investigation that such an obstruction exists, the city
engineer, or such other local authority, shall notify the owner and order that the hazard be removed
within ten (10) days.
(3) The failure of the owner to remove such obstruction within ten (10) days shall constitute an event
punishable by a penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) and every day said owner shall fail to remove it shall
be a separate and distinct offense.
(b) Immediate Danger : If the city engineer, in consultation with the chief of police, determines that an
obstruction identified in subsection (a) of this section constitutes an immediate hazard to the public
health and safety whereby the physical safety of the users of the public way would be placed in
immediate jeopardy then the city engineer shall have the authority to cause the removal of the
obstruction causing said immediate hazard to the extent necessary to remove such imminent danger.
The city engineer shall attempt to cause the property owner to be notified in person prior to causing
said removal, but if unable to provide such notice, shall as soon as possible cause notice of such
action to be given to the property owner. The property owner shall have the right to a hearing before
the governing body as to whether said removal was justified.
(c) Notice : Notice as provided herein shall be given to the property owner according to the procedures
set forth in section 17-14 of this code, to the extent that said procedure is consistent with the
provisions of this section.
(d) Failure To Remove Obstruction : If the property owner to whom the notice required by subsection (a)
of this section has been given, neglects to cause the removal of the tree, plant, shrub, or other
obstruction, or part thereof, as required by such notice, the city may:
(1) Cause such tree, plant, shrub, or other obstruction to be removed according to the notice; and/or
(2) File a complaint against such owner in the municipal court of the city.
(e) Assessment And Collection Of Costs When Removal Is Conducted By City : If the city shall cause
such trees, plants, shrubs, or other obstructions to be removed, the cost of said removal, including all
administrative costs, shall be assessed to the property owner whose duty it was to perform the
removal, and shall collect said costs in accordance with the procedures established by section 17-16
of this code, as amended, to the extent such procedure is consistent with the provisions of this
section. (Ord. 88-31, § 1, 11-2-1988)
Sec. 24-11. Exception For Street Sales:
The following events and occurrences otherwise restricted by the provisions of sections 24-1 and 24-6 of
this article shall be excepted therefrom by action of the governing body at any regular or specially called
public meeting thereof, where such event or occurrence shall qualify as one of the following:
(1) The public sale of merchandise sponsored by an organization recognized by the governing body.
Streets and sidewalks may be used during such sale by any merchant endorsed by the organization
sponsoring such sale. Approval of the governing body shall be conditioned upon obtaining
permission from the proper authority for temporary closing of any street or highway. Said sale shall
be of no more than one day duration. The governing body shall exercise discretion regarding the
number of times per calendar year it authorizes this exception.
(2) A public sale of merchandise conducted by more than fifty percent (50%) of the merchants
occupying business establishments in any commercial area or zone in no more than one city block.
The sidewalks only may be used during such sale by the merchants located in such block. Approval
by the governing body shall be conditioned upon provision being made for adequate passage for
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 306/510
pedestrians upon said sidewalk, and no part of the street shall be used for such passage. Said sale
shall be for no more than one day in duration. The governing body shall exercise discretion regarding
the number of times per calendar year they authorize this exception. (1962 Code, § 20-407A; Ord.
847, § 1, 6-15-1977; Ord. 88-16, § 1, 6-1-1988)
Sec. 24-12. Traffic Controls For Street Construction And Maintenance Operations:
There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of setting forth basic principles, uniform
procedures and prescribed standards to follow in the design, application, installation and maintenance
operations for traffic control devices required for street construction and maintenance operations a
manual entitled "Traffic Controls For Street Construction And Maintenance Operations, City Of Emporia",
2007 edition, prepared and published by the engineering department, city of Emporia, Kansas; three (3)
copies of said manual are on file with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at
all reasonable hours. (Ord. 85-16, § 1, 4-3-1985; Ord. 01-47, §§ 1, 3, 12-19-2001; Ord. 07-28, § 1, 9-5-
2007)
Secs. 24-13-24-21. Reserved:
ARTICLE II. RIGHT OF WAY CONSTRUCTION AND ADMINISTRATION
24-22. Purpose And Scope:
(a)Short Title: THIS ARTICLE herein or ROW ORDINANCE.
(b)Application Of Ordinance:
(1) This article shall govern the construction within city's rights of way, unless otherwise described in
another ordinance or a franchise, license, occupancy, or use agreement of the city or the state.
(2) This article is intended to serve as management and control for use of rights of way within the city
and either owned by, leased by, under an easement by, or otherwise under the control of the city and
the city having the authority to regulate its use.
(3) All persons seeking to use rights of way for the construction and operation of facilities, is subject
to this article and also shall be subject to the requirement of filing with the city at the time of
application to use the rights of way any legal authorization including franchise, license, occupancy or
use agreement that may be required by applicable law including, but not limited to, the laws of the
state and the city having jurisdiction over such persons, use, occupancy, and applied for construction
permits to use such rights of way.
(4) Some persons may be subject to a franchise fee, according to the provisions of Kansas law and
the city's video service ordinance, primarily cable service providers and any authorization for such
provider will contain the requirements of such franchise fee. All persons that are not otherwise
governed by Kansas law and the city's video service ordinance will be required to comply with the
provisions of a franchise, license, occupancy, or use agreement granted to such persons by the city
granting rights to use or occupy rights of way and will be obligated to city, to the payment of a
comparable franchise or use fee and as determined by the city in its franchise, license, occupancy, or
use agreement granted to such person as either a percentage of five percent (5%) of gross revenue
or based on a charge of per linear foot of occupancy.
(5) In addition to any fee that may be imposed and generally described above, this article includes
certain fees and charges applicable to all persons that are not franchise fees. Rather, such fees as
described further in this article will be for the purpose of recovering the costs and expenses of the
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 307/510
city related to the issuing, processing, and verification of applications for construction within the rights
of way, fees to defray costs of inspection and rights of way management and fees that may be
permissible and applicable to recover costs on the part of the city for repair, maintenance, or
restoration and as incurred by the city as a result of such person's construction, use, occupancy, and
maintenance within the rights of way.
(6) This article is intended to provide uniform standards and requirements applicable to all persons
who seek to use and occupy the rights of way and construct facilities within the rights of way.
Differences in requirements, including fees or charges imposed by this article, will relate to the
differences in the costs of the city for administration and management and enforcement directly
related to a particular person's facilities.
(7) Any person subject to this article will also agree pursuant to any permit that is issued as well as a
franchise, license, occupancy, or use agreement that it is subject to all applicable ordinances of the
city affecting the person's occupation, construction and maintenance of its facilities within the rights
of way.
(c)Easements Not Impaired: Nothing in this article is intended to impair the legal obligation of any
contract, franchise, license, video service authorization, use agreement, or other legal authorization
or easement previously granted by the city, the state, or other lawful authority.
(d)Not In Lieu Of Franchise: Compliance with the permitting requirements of this article shall not excuse
any person from complying with all other requirements of law, including holding a valid video service
authorization, franchise, license, or use agreement from the city and/or the state.
(e)Area Of Jurisdiction: This article shall apply to all rights of way within the corporate limits of the city as
such corporate limits exist or may exist in the future. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-23. Definitions:
The following definitions apply in this article. References hereafter to "sections" are, unless otherwise
specified, references to sections in this article. Defined terms remain defined terms whether or not
capitalized.
Applicable Law: The federal communications act of 1934, as amended, the federal cable act, the federal
telecommunications act, the home rule charter of city, and such federal and state laws and rules and city
ordinances as may govern the construction, operation, and maintenance of facilities within the rights of
way.
Applicant: Any person requesting permission to obstruct or construct in a rights of way.
Application: The process by which an applicant submits a request for permission to obstruct or construct
in the rights of way.
Cable Act: The cable communications policy act of 1984, Pub. L. no. 98-549, (codified at 47 USC §§
521-611 [1982 and supp. V. 1987]) as amended by the cable television consumer protection and
competition act of 1992, Pub. L. no. 102-385, and the telecommunications act of 1996, Pub. L. no. 104-
104 (1996) as it may, from time to time, be amended.
City: City of Emporia, Kansas.
City Cost: The direct and indirect costs borne by the city for the administration of this article.
City Engineer: The city engineer of the city of Emporia, or his or her department or designee.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 308/510
Construct: To excavate, repair, rehabilitate, maintain, and install sanitary sewers, water mains, fire
hydrants, valves, meters, manholes, service lines and connections, gas mains, telephone and electrical
conduit and their miscellaneous service lines and connections, video and telecommunications facilities
cables, wires, lines, wave guides, antennas, and other equipment or facilities, pedestals, and service
cabinets, poles, guywires, storm drains, manholes, inlets, catch basins, irrigation systems, driveways,
sidewalks, pavement extensions, curbs, walks, steps, building canopies, balconies, overhead walkways,
and temporary detour pedestrian walkways on, above, or under any part of the rights of way provided
however, that construct shall not mean installation, repair, rehabilitation or maintenance of facilities that
do not involve excavation of any portion of the rights of way.
Construction Standards For Miscellaneous Construction, Utility Excavation, And Rights Of Way And
Pavement Restoration (Construction Standards): The compilation of provisions and requirements that
provide the technical specifications and details for the construction of facilities in the rights of way as
determined by the city engineer.
Emergency: A condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life or health, or of a significant loss
of property or utility service.
Excavation: Any work in the surface or subsurface of the rights of way including, but not limited to,
opening the rights of way, installing, servicing, repairing or modifying any facilities in or under the surface
or subsurface, and restoring the surface and subsurface of the rights of way.
Excavation Fee: Money charged by the city to recover the city costs associated with construction and/or
repair activities in the rights of way.
Extended Application: An application made to construct or obstruct more of the rights of way than
allowed in, or to extend, a permit that had already been issued.
Facilities: Any tangible thing located in any rights of way including, but not limited to, lines, conduits,
wires, fiber optic wires, cables, pipes, pipelines, poles, towers, vaults or appliances; but shall not include
boulevard plantings or gardens planted or maintained in the rights of way between a person's property
and the street edge of pavement.
Franchise, License, And Use Agreement: The grant of authority from city to use rights of way for any
purpose therein described.
In: When used in conjunction with rights of way, means over, above, in, within, on or under a rights of
way.
Landscape Or Landscaping: Trees, shrubs and other plantings of materials that are or may grow to a
height of eighteen inches (18") or more, and irrigation systems (in unpaved areas), in the rights of way.
Notice Of Violation: A written warning issued by the city engineer for a violation or possible violation of
this article.
Obstruct: To place any tangible object in a rights of way so as to hinder free and open passage over,
under, or through that or any part of the rights of way.
Performance Bond, Construction Bond, Or Maintenance Bond: Any bond required by city and posted to
ensure appropriate and timely performance in the construction and/or restoration of facilities and the
maintenance of facilities located in the public rights of way pursuant to a permit as determined by the city
engineer.
Permit Fee: Money charged by the city to cover the city costs associated with the issuing, processing
and verifying of an application as provided in this article.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 309/510
Permit Or Rights Of Way Permit: The permit which must be obtained before a person may construct in,
or obstruct in a rights of way as required by this article.
Permittee: Any person to whom a permit to construct or obstruct a rights of way has been granted by the
city.
Person: An individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, corporation, or governmental
entity.
Restoration: The process by which a constructed or obstructed rights of way is restored as specified in
this article.
Rights Of Way: The surface of and the space above and below any public street, public road, public
highway, public freeway, public lane, public way, public alley, public sidewalk, public boulevard, public
parkway, public drive or any public utility easement or public rights of way now or hereafter held by the
city which shall, within its proper use and meaning, entitle provider to the use thereof for the purpose of
installing or transmitting over poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes,
amplifiers, appliances, attachments and other property as may be ordinarily necessary and pertinent to
facilities.
Service Or Utility Service: Services provided by utilities.
Sidewalk: The paved pedestrian walkway between the edge of the road and the street rights of way line.
Telecommunications Act: The telecommunications act of 1996 codified at title 47 of the United States
Code.
Trenchless Technology: The use of directional boring, horizontal drilling and microtunneling and other
techniques in the construction of underground portions of facilities which result in the least amount of
disruption and damage to rights of way as possible.
Underground Facilities: All lines, cables, conduits, posts, tanks and any other facilities owned or
operated by persons other than the city which are located wholly or partially underneath rights of way.
Utilities: Any water, sewer, gas, drainage, sprinkler or culvert pipe and any electric power,
telecommunication, signal, communication, or cable television conduit, fiber, wire, cable, or operator
thereof.
Video Service Authorization: The certificate of authorization issued by the state corporation commission
of the right of a video service provider to offer video programming to any subscribers anywhere in the
state of Kansas. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-24. Administration:
The city engineer shall be the principal city official responsible for the administration of the rights of way,
rights of way permits, and this article. The city engineer may adopt and may amend from time to time,
construction standards and other rules reasonably required to carry out the purposes of this article. Any
requirement not specifically covered by this article or the construction standards shall be determined by
the city engineer. The city engineer may delegate any or all of the duties hereunder. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-
7-2010)
24-25. Permit; Fees; Appeal:
(a)Permit Requirement: Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person may construct or obstruct
any rights of way without first having obtained from the city or the state a franchise, license, video
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 310/510
service authorization, or use agreement or as otherwise may be authorized under applicable law.
(b)Rights Of Way Permit: A rights of way permit is a permit which allows the holder to construct,
obstruct, or landscape in that part of the rights of way described in such permit.
(1) A permit is valid only for the dates and the area(s) of rights of way specified in the permit. No
person may construct in or obstruct the rights of way beyond the date or dates specified in the permit
unless such person:
a. Makes an extended application for rights of way permit before the expiration of the initial permit;
and
b. A new permit or permit extension is granted.
However, if no work is initiated within sixty (60) days of obtaining a permit, the permit is rendered
invalid.
(2) When the work must commence immediately because of an emergency the permittee shall
comply with the provisions in this article.
(3) No permits shall be required for the following activities:
a. Installation of and repair of facilities by or for the city of Emporia; and
b. Installation of landscaping materials from a city approved list of plant materials for planting in the
right of way.
(4) The authority of a permittee to use and occupy the rights of way shall always be subject to and
subordinate to the reasonable public health, safety and welfare requirements and regulations of the
city.
(c)Permit Applications: Application for a permit is made to the city engineer.
(1) All permit applications shall include the requirements of this article, specifically including, but not
limited to, the following:
a. Each applicant's name, Kansas's One-Call registration certificate number, address, and e-mail
address, if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers.
b. The name, address, and e-mail address, if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of a
local representative. The local representative or designee shall be available at all times.
c. Insurance.
1. Verifying that an insurance policy has been issued to the applicant by an insurance company
licensed to do business in the state of Kansas or a form of self-insurance acceptable to the city.
2. Verifying that the applicant is insured as required by this article or a franchise, license, or use
agreement with city named as an additional insured.
d. The city may require a copy of certificate of insurance naming the city as additional insured with
insurer in good standing and licensed to do business in Kansas.
e. If the person is a corporation, a copy of the certificate of incorporation as recorded and certified
by the secretary of state.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 311/510
f. If applicable, a copy of the person's use agreement, video service authorization, franchise,
license, or other legal authorization or order granting a certificate of authority from the state of
Kansas corporation commission or other applicable state or federal agency.
(2) All permit applications must be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount in accordance with
subsection (d) of this section.
(3) In the event applicant furnished similar information to the city as may be required for a franchise,
license, video service authorization, or use agreement, such information may not be duplicated but
may be supplemented based on review by the city engineer.
(4) If the applicant does not provide a valid and administratively complete application, the city
engineer shall return the application and fee to the applicant within thirty (30) days of receipt of said
application and fee, citing reasons for incompleteness in writing.
(5) The applicant shall keep all of the information listed above current at all times by providing to the
city information as to changes within fifteen (15) days following the date on which the applicant has
knowledge of any change.
(d)Permit Fees:
(1) Permit fees shall be established by the city commission upon recommendation of the city
engineer. All permit fees and other fees made part of this article, may be periodically amended, by
recommendation of the city engineer, by the city commission. Said fees shall be in an amount
sufficient to recover the following costs:
a. The city costs of administration, including, but not limited to, issuing, processing and verification
of applications.
(2) No permit shall be issued without payment of such fees unless the city engineer authorizes
payment to be made thirty (30) days following billing. All changes in fees shall be approved by the
city commission.
(3) All permit fees are nonrefundable.
(4) The following are hereby adopted as the permit and excavation fees:
a. New Facilities: For the installation, replacement or extension of new facilities in the right of way,
the fee shall be calculated on the basis of fifty cents ($0.50) per linear foot for work in paved areas,
and ten cents ($0.10) per linear foot for work in unpaved areas of the rights of way to businesses
which have their principal place of business located within the limits of the city of Emporia. A fee of
sixty cents ($0.60) per linear foot for work in paved areas, and fifteen cents ($0.15) per linear foot
for work in unpaved areas of the rights of way shall be charged to businesses which do not have
their principal place of business within the limits of the city of Emporia. There is no cost for a permit
for resident homeowners.
b. Repair Of Existing Facilities: For the repair of existing facilities which requires work in the right of
way, a permit fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged to businesses which have their
principal place of business located within the limits of the city of Emporia; and a permit fee of thirty
