five dollars ($35.00) shall be charged to businesses which do not have their principal place of
business within the limits of the city of Emporia. There is no cost for a permit for resident
homeowners.
(e)Issuance Of Permit; Conditions:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 312/510
(1) If the city engineer determines that the applicant has satisfied the requirements of this article, the
city engineer shall issue a permit or issue notification and reason for denial.
(2) The city shall process each valid and administratively complete permit application for the use of
the rights of way within thirty (30) days.
(3) The city engineer may impose reasonable conditions upon the issuance of the permit and the
performance of the applicant thereunder in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, to
ensure the structural integrity of the rights of way, to protect the property and safety of other users of
the rights of way, and to minimize the disruption and inconvenience to the traveling public, including
notification to property owners.
(4) All permittees shall pay an excavation fee to the city. Excavation fees shall be established by the
city commission upon recommendation of the city engineer. Said fees shall be in an amount sufficient
to recover the following costs: All costs associated with construction and repair activity in the rights of
way by a permittee, their assigns, contractors and/or subcontractors and is expressly limited to
activity that results in an actual street or pavement cut, or trenching. An excavation fee shall not be
required for activities directly related to improvements for the health, safety and welfare of the public.
(f)Joint Applications: Applicants are encouraged to make joint application for permits to construct or
obstruct the rights of way at the same place and time. Applicants who apply for permits for the same
or similar obstruction or construction for the same rights of way location may share in the payment of
any permit, excavation and/or inspection fee. Applicants must agree among themselves as to the
portion each will pay and indicate the same on their applications.
(g)Request For Special Exception: The city engineer may grant a special exception to the requirements
of this article if a permittee demonstrates with written evidence that:
(1) The exception will not create any threat to the public health, safety or welfare.
(2) The permittee demonstrates that the increased economic burden and the potential adverse
impact on the permittee's construction schedule resulting from the strict enforcement of the
requirement actually or effectively prohibits the ability of the permittee to provide its services in the
city.
(3) The permittee demonstrates that the requirement unreasonably discriminates against the
permittee in favor of another person.
(4) Should any person be aggrieved by the decision of the city engineer, such person may appeal as
provided for in subsection (i) of this section.
(h)Denial Of Permit:
(1) Except in the case of an emergency, no rights of way permit will be granted:
a. To any person who has failed to comply with the requirements of this article.
b. If, in the discretion of the city engineer, the issuance of a permit for the particular date and/or
time would cause a conflict or interfere with an exhibition, celebration, festival, or any other event.
The city engineer, in exercising this discretion, shall be guided by the safety and convenience of
ordinary travel of the public over the rights of way, and by considerations relating to the public
health, safety and welfare.
(2) The city engineer may deny a permit in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, to
prevent interference with the safety and convenience of ordinary travel over the rights of way, or
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 313/510
when necessary to protect the rights of way and its users. The city engineer may consider one or
more of the following factors:
a. The extent to which rights of way space where the permit is sought is available.
b. The competing demands for the particular space in the rights of way.
c. The availability of other locations in the rights of way or in other rights of way for the facilities of
the particular company.
d. The applicability of ordinances or other regulations of the rights of way that affect location of
facilities in the rights of way.
e. The degree of compliance of the applicant with the terms and conditions of this article, and other
applicable ordinances and regulations; the degree of disruption to surrounding neighborhoods and
businesses that will result from the use of that part of the rights of way.
f. The condition and age of the rights of way, and whether and when it is scheduled for total or
partial construction; and the balancing of the costs of disruption to the public and damage to the
rights of way, against the benefits to that part of the public served by the expansion into additional
parts of the rights of way.
g. Whether the specific portion of the rights of way is environmentally sensitive as defined by state
or federal law or lies within a previously designated historic district as defined by local, state or
federal law.
(3) Denial of a permit is appealed under the procedures in subsection (i) of this section.
(i)Appeal Procedure:
(1) Within forty eight (48) hours of receiving a notice of violation, permittee shall contact the city
engineer with a plan, acceptable to the city engineer, for its correction and approval by the city
engineer. Permittee's failure to so contact the city engineer, or the permittee's failure to submit an
acceptable plan, or permittee's failure to reasonably implement the approved plan, shall be cause for
the city engineer to recover costs, expenses or damages from the construction bond or to deny
further rights of way construction or to revoke a permit.
(2) A person that: a) has had a permit revoked, b) believes that the fees imposed are invalid, c) was
denied a request for a special exception, or d) was denied a permit has the right to have the matter
reviewed. The applicant shall be furnished a written decision by the city by first class mail. The
applicant shall have ten (10) days from the date of the decision letter to make a written request for a
review by the city manager. Failure to make a timely request for a hearing shall constitute a waiver of
the applicant's right to contest the denial before the city commission. If an applicant is dissatisfied
with the outcome, he or she may request a hearing before the city commission concerning the denial.
The hearing shall be held by the city commission within thirty (30) days after the filing of the request
therefor, and the applicant shall be advised by the city of the time and place of the hearing. Following
a public hearing, if the city commission denies a potential applicant's request such determination may
be appealed to district court.
(j)Work Done Without A Permit:
(1) Each permittee shall notify the city engineer (by telephone or in person) of any event regarding its
facilities which it considers to be an emergency by the next business day. The applicant may proceed
to take whatever actions are necessary in order to respond to the emergency. Within two (2)
business days after the occurrence of the emergency, the applicant shall apply for the necessary
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 314/510
permits, pay the fees associated therewith and fulfill the rest of the requirements necessary to bring
itself into compliance with this article for the actions it took in response to the emergency.
(2) In the event that the city engineer becomes aware of an emergency regarding an applicant's
facilities, the applicant shall attempt to contact the local representative of each applicant affected, if
known, or potentially affected, by the emergency, who must comply with this article. In any event, the
city engineer may take whatever action deemed necessary in order to respond to the emergency.
(3) Except in the case of an emergency, any person who obstructs or excavates a rights of way
without a permit must subsequently obtain a permit, pay double the normal fee for said permit, pay
double all the other fees required by the code, is subject to the issuance of a notice of violation,
deposit with the city engineer the fees necessary to correct any damage to the rights of way and
comply with all of the requirements of this article. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-26. Construction Methods:
(a)Compliance With Construction Standards: All construction or maintenance of facilities shall be in
accordance with the requirements of a franchise, license, or use agreement or other lawful authority,
and this article, a copy of which will be filed with city by applicant.
(b)Erection Of Poles Prohibited; Aboveground And Underground Facilities:
(1) Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this article, a permittee shall not erect, for any reason,
any pole on or along any rights of way without the approval of the city. Nothing herein shall be
construed to limit or eliminate any right, requirement or obligation a permittee may have to enter into
a pole attachment agreement and/or agreement for conduit use with the city or a private utility for the
use of another's pole or conduit.
(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in this article, to the contrary, and except due to technological
reasons or due to the size or shape of facilities that would result in unreasonable expense and
therefore exempted as determined by the city engineer, or as otherwise described in a franchise,
license, or use agreement:
a. In those areas within the city where primarily all facilities are currently placed underground, all
facilities shall remain or be placed underground.
b. In areas where utility facilities are primarily aboveground at the time of a permittee's installation,
the city may allow permittee, at permittee's sole cost and expense, to install its facilities
aboveground, provided that at such time as the city adopts an underground plan and primarily all
utility facilities or other facilities are placed underground, permittee shall likewise place its facilities
underground without cost to the city. If as part of a plan to place underground, aboveground
facilities, public funding is available. All permittees shall be treated similarly unless such funding is
made available from a source other than the city and is designated for a specific use.
c. In no event shall permittee be authorized to place aboveground any facilities that have
previously been underground without prior approval from the city.
(c)Least Disruptive Technology: Applicants are encouraged to perform construction and maintenance of
facilities in a manner resulting in the least amount of damage and disruption of the rights of way.
Applicants may be required to use trenchless technology for construction projects, within roadway
limits, in arterial and other high volume streets and in streets constructed or resurfaced within the last
five (5) years, unless otherwise approved by the city engineer and such approval shall not be
unreasonably withheld. The city engineer may require trenchless technology in other locations,
where extreme circumstances prevent or make open cut methods impractical. Applicants may use
either the open cut method or trenchless technology for projects outside roadway limits.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 315/510
(d)Rights Of Way Restoration:
(1) The work to be done under the permit, and the restoration of the rights of way as required herein,
must be completed within the dates specified in the permit. In addition to its own work, the permittee
must restore the general area of the work, including all disturbed landscaping, planting and
improvement materials and the permitted areas, including the paving and its foundation, per the
construction standards described in this article.
(2) By restoring the rights of way, the permittee guarantees its work for twelve (12) months following
its completion, said work to be guaranteed by a construction or performance construction bond.
During twelve (12) months after completion, the permittee shall, upon notification from the city
engineer, correct all restoration work to the extent necessary using the method required by the city
engineer. Said work shall be completed within the time specified by the city engineer. During this
time, a maintenance bond will be required. All bonds required pursuant to this section will be in a
form acceptable to city and city may call any such bond as in its sole discretion decides. The city
shall release the performance bond and maintenance bond upon successful restoration of the right of
way and upon successful completion of the twelve (12) months' maintenance period respectively.
(3) If a permittee fails to promptly perform the repair and restoration required herein, after written
request of the city and has had a reasonable opportunity to satisfy that request, the city shall have
the right to return the rights of way back into its functional equivalence prevailing prior to permittee's
work. Such costs associated with repairing and restoring the public right of way because of damage
caused by a permittee, their assigns, contractors and/or subcontractors shall be fully reimbursable to
the city within thirty (30) days after its receipt of the city's invoice thereof. The city shall also have the
option to notify the bonding company to release to the city the performance bond or maintenance
bond as may be applicable. The proceeds from the bond shall be used to return the right of way back
into its functional equivalence.
(e)Inspection: Except for routine work, when the work under any permit hereunder is completed, the
permittee shall notify the city engineer.
(1) Permittee shall make the work site available to the city engineer or his authorized representative
and to all others as authorized by law for inspection at all reasonable times during the execution and
upon completion of the work.
(2) At the time of inspection, the city engineer or his authorized representative may order the
immediate cessation of any work which poses a serious threat to the life, health, safety or well being
of the public.
(3) The city engineer or his authorized representative may issue a notice of violation to the permittee
for any work which does not conform to this article. The notice of violation shall provide requirements
for correction of violation, any applicable penalties for continued violation, the process and
procedures and right of permittee that may be applicable as required.
(f)Other Obligations: Obtaining a rights of way permit does not relieve permittee of its duty to obtain all
other necessary permits, franchises, licenses, video service authorization, or use agreements, and
authority and to pay all applicable fees.
(1) A permittee shall comply with all requirements of local, state and federal laws, including a
franchise, license, video service authorization, or use agreement or other lawful authorization duly
adopted by the city commission, as well as the Kansas call excavation notice system.
(2) A permittee shall perform all work in conformance with all applicable codes and established rules
and regulations, and is responsible for all work done in the rights of way pursuant to its permit,
regardless of who performs the work.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 316/510
(3) A permittee shall comply with the provisions of standards and guides for traffic controls for street
and highway construction, maintenance, utility, and incident management operations part VI of the
"Manual Of Uniform Traffic Control Devices" (MUTCD), published by the U.S. department of
transportation, federal highway administration, 1988 edition, revision 3, dated September 3, 1993,
which is incorporated herein by reference as if fully set forth herein.
(4) Except in the case of an emergency, and with the approval of the city engineer, no rights of way
obstruction or excavation may be performed when seasonally prohibited or when conditions are
unreasonable for such work.
(5) A permittee shall not so obstruct a rights of way that the natural free and clear passage of water
through the gutters or other waterways shall be interfered with.
(6) Private vehicles not owned by or under contract to permittee may not be parked within or adjacent
to a permit area.
(g)Advertising, Signs, Or Extraneous Markings: Unless otherwise authorized by a franchise, license,
video service authorization, or use agreement or applicable law, permittee shall not place or cause to
be placed any sort of signs, advertisements, or other extraneous markings, whether relating to the
permittee or any other person or entity on rights of way, except such necessary minimal markings as
approved by the city as are reasonably necessary to identify the system for service, repair,
maintenance, or emergency purposes, or as may be otherwise required to be affixed by applicable
law or regulation.
(h)Clearing Poles And Cables: Permittee shall comply with all applicable city and state laws, rules, and
ordinances with respect to the removal, trimming and cutting of trees and keeping its facilities clear of
trees in and along rights of way. Except in emergency situations, in installing, maintaining, and
removing its facilities, permittee shall neither remove, cut, trim nor damage any trees within the rights
of way, alleys and public places of the city except with the prior consent of the city, or, where on
private property, without the property owner's consent.
(i)Removal And Relocation Of Facilities: A permittee may, or as may be determined by the city engineer,
be required, at its expense, to promptly protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate in, or
remove from, rights of way, lands or places, any facilities of permittee whenever required by the city
upon reasonable notice applicable to the conditions warranting such disconnection and as then
determined by city engineer by reason of the public health, safety and welfare, traffic conditions,
rights of way construction or any other reasonable public purpose. A permit shall be required but the
permit fee may be waived.
(j)Temporary Movement Of Facilities: Permittee, on the request of the city engineer, or any person
holding a lawful permit issued by the city, or any permit issued by an appropriate state agency, shall
temporarily move its facilities to permit the moving of large objects, vehicles, buildings or other
structures. Except where requested by the city or other governmental entity in connection with a
public project, the expense of such temporary moves shall be paid to permittee by the person
requesting the same and permittee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. In
no event shall the city pay such expense. Nothing herein shall be construed to abrogate the
provisions for moving facilities contained in any pole attachment agreement the permittee has with
another person.
(k)Joint Trench Coordination; Planned Infrastructure:
(1) Whenever it is possible and reasonably practicable to joint trench or share bores or cuts or joint
share conduit, permittee shall work with the city and other permittees and licensees, so as to reduce,
as far as possible, the number of street cuts within the city.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 317/510
(2) If required of other users of the rights of way, when permittee installs any new trench and/or
conduit as part of its facilities, the permittee may, at the request of the city or its designee install, at
the expense of the city, sufficient additional space and/or conduit or other related facilities to meet the
city's planned public improvement and infrastructure needs. Permittee may make such trench space
and/or conduit available to the city on the basis of not more than the pro rata cost of that portion of
the space in a trench and/or conduit determined by the total labor and material cost of all facilities
and facilities at that location. The city shall have the option to lay its own conduit or place other public
improvements that do not cause significant cost, delay or redesign, including, without limitation,
wiring for traffic signals, streetlights, etc., in permittee's open trenches during the initial construction
and during any future rebuilds or repairs. Permittee shall provide written notice of the proposed
construction to the city and the city will then have twenty (20) business days after receipt to indicate
in writing to the permittee, unless permittee requires a shorter time for city reply, as to its construction
needs and request for additional facilities.
(3) Permittee agrees to comply with all applicable city requirements applicable to city trenching
requirements, including, but not limited to, how long a trench shall remain open and unfilled as well
as any requirements related to signs or other markings that shall be utilized by permittee to ensure
safety to others. For purposes of this section, "open" shall mean and include any degree of refilling
and/or restoration of the trench short of the final restoration of the pavement or the ground to its
original grade.
(l)Company Identification: Permittee shall ensure that all of its vehicles and employees are clearly
identified to the general public as being associated with permittee while engaged in outside
construction maintenance or service. Said employee identification requirement may be satisfied by
the carrying of and presentment, upon request, of a company identification card.
(m)Abandonment Of Construction: In the event permittee abandons construction, once commenced, of
the facilities, for more than sixty (60) days prior to such time facilities are available for the intended
use, the city may reasonably request permittee to dismantle such facilities located within rights of
way after reasonable notice and opportunity to be heard by city commission. If permittee fails to so
dismantle based on a decision of the city commission, the city may dismantle at permittee's expense
and permittee shall reimburse the city within thirty (30) days of receipt of an invoice therefor. In the
event a permittee has been requested to relocate its facilities located in the rights of way due to the
abandonment or discontinued use of a structure supporting its facilities, the city may reasonably
request permittee to relocate such facilities to a new support structure. If permittee fails to so
relocate, the city may relocate at permittee's expense and permittee shall reimburse the city within
thirty (30) days of receipt of an invoice therefor. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-29. Applicant Or Permittee Indemnifies City:
Including as required by a franchise, license, or use agreement or other lawful authorization by
accepting a permit, a permittee is required, to indemnify, and hold the city whole and harmless from all
claims, lawsuits, judgments, costs, liens, losses, expenses, fees (including reasonable attorney fees and
costs of defense), proceedings, actions, demands, causes of action liability and suits of any kind and
nature, including personal or bodily injury (including death), property damage or other harm for which
recovery of damages is sought, to the extent that it is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be
caused by the negligence of the permittee, any agent, officer, director, representative, employee, affiliate
or subcontractor of the permittee or their respective officers, agents, employees, directors or
representatives arising out of the construction, presence, installation, maintenance, repair or operation of
its facilities, or out of any activity undertaken in or near a rights of way, whether any act or omission
complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by a rights of way permit.
It further agrees that it will not bring, nor cause to be brought, any action, suit or other proceeding
claiming damages, or seeking any other relief against the city for any claim nor for any award arising out
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 318/510
of the presence, installation, maintenance or operation of its facilities, or any activity undertaken in or
near a rights of way, whether the act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by a
permit.
The foregoing does not indemnify the city, its officers, employees, contractors or subcontractors for its
own negligence. If a permittee and the city are found to be jointly liable by a court of competent
jurisdiction, liability shall be apportioned comparatively in accordance with the laws of this state without,
however, waiving any governmental immunity available to the city under state law and without waiving
any defenses of the parties under state or federal law.
This section is not, as to third parties, a waiver of any defense or immunity otherwise available to the
applicant or to the city; and the applicant, in defending any action on behalf of the city, shall be entitled to
assert in any action every defense or immunity that the city could assert in its own behalf. This section is
solely for the benefit of the city and permittee and does not create or grant any rights, contractual or
otherwise, to any other person or entity. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-30. Claim Notification:
A permittee shall promptly advise the other in writing of any known claim or demand against the provider
or the city related to or arising out of the provider's activities in the rights of way. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-
2010)
24-31. Bond; Insurance:
(a)Performance Bond:
(1) The applicant shall be required to provide a performance bond, except as any such performance
bond as may be required by a franchise, license, or use agreement, to guarantee the proper
construction and completion of rights of way work and restoration. Such bond shall be made
available to the city engineer upon issuance of a permit and such performance bond must include a
procedure for the city to follow to recover costs, expenses or damages in order to ensure
enforcement of the terms and conditions of this article in compliance with subsection 24-25(i) of this
article or a franchise, license, video service authorization, or use agreement or other lawful
authorization applicable to rights of way use. A performance bond will not be required for small
projects if no paved area or rights of way is disturbed by the project. The city engineer may waive the
requirement for the performance bond for permittees who evidence financial ability to pay the cost of
the repairs to the city's rights of way resulting from their permitted activity.
(2) City departments performing installation of facilities, routine maintenance and repair, and other
agencies working in the rights of way that are not involved in the installation, repair and maintenance
of utilities, are exempt from the requirements of subsection (a)(1) of this section.
(b)Liability Insurance:
(1) Unless otherwise described in a franchise, license or use agreement or other lawful authorization,
a permittee shall maintain the insurance as required by this section, and furnish evidence of the
same to the city engineer with its application for a permit. At a minimum, the permittee shall be
required to provide liability insurance with a company licensed to do business in the state of Kansas
with a rating by Best of not less than "A", insuring permittee and the city with regard to all damages
mentioned in this section, in the minimum amounts of:
a. One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any one person.
b. Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage from any one accident.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 319/510
(2) All insurance policies required by this article shall name the city of Emporia, Kansas, as an
additional insured on the policy with rights in the city to collect directly, in its sole discretion, from an
insurer. An applicant will be required to furnish a certificate of insurance in compliance with this
section together with an application and maintain the insurance as required unless otherwise either
decreased or determined no longer required by the city in its sole discretion.
(3) The amounts shown in subsection (b)(1) of this section shall be increased by amendment to this
article.
(c)Workers' Compensation Insurance: A permittee will obtain and maintain workers' compensation
insurance for all permittee's employees, and in case any work is sublet, permittee will require any
subcontractor similarly to provide workers' compensation insurance for all subcontractor's
employees, in compliance with state laws, and to fully protect the city from any and all claims arising
out of work related occurrences. Permittee shall indemnify the city in accordance with section 24-29
of this article for any damage resulting to it from failure of either permittee or any subcontractor to
obtain and maintain such insurance. Permittee will provide the city with a certificate of insurance
indicating workers' compensation insurance prior to operations under a franchise, license or use
agreement or other lawful authorization and the commencement of any construction, system
upgrade, reconstruction, or maintenance of the facilities. The certificate of insurance should confirm
that the required endorsements are in effect. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-32. Penalty Provision:
Any person, firm, corporation, utility, or entity, or agent, contractor or subcontractor thereof, violating any
provision of this article shall be guilty of a municipal offense, and shall upon conviction be subject to a
maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day of violation shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-33. Nonexclusive Remedy:
The remedies provided in this article are not exclusive or in lieu of other rights and remedies that the city
may have at law or in equity. The city is hereby authorized to seek legal and equitable relief for actual or
threatened injury to the rights of way, including damages to the rights of way, whether caused by a
violation of any of the provisions of this article or other provisions of this article. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-
2010)
24-34. Severability:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this article is for any reason held
invalid or unconstitutional by any court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, such portion
shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portions thereof. If a regulatory body or a court of competent jurisdiction should
determine by a final, nonappealable order that any permit or right or any portion of this article is illegal or
unenforceable, then any such permit or right granted or deemed to exist hereunder shall be considered
as a permit with a mutual right in either party to terminate without cause upon giving sixty (60) days'
written notice to the other. The requirements and conditions of such a revocable permit shall be the
same requirements and conditions as set forth in the permit or right respectively, except for conditions
relating to the term of the permit and the right of termination. If a permit or right shall be considered a
revocable permit as provided herein, the permittee must acknowledge the authority of the city
commission to issue such revocable permit and the power to revoke it. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
24-35. Reservation Of Regulatory And Police Powers:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 320/510
The city by the granting of a rights of way permit, does not surrender or to any extent lose, waive, impair,
or lessen the lawful powers and rights, which it has now or may be hereafter vested in the city under the
constitution and statutes of the state of Kansas to regulate the use of the rights of way by the permittee
or to charge reasonable compensation for such use; and the permittee by its acceptance of a rights of
way permit must agree that all lawful powers and rights, regulatory power, or police power, or otherwise
as are or the same may be from time to time vested in or reserved to the city, shall be in full force and
effect and subject to the exercise thereof by the city at any time. A permittee or applicant is deemed to
acknowledge that its rights are subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and
enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to
comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to such powers.
Any conflict between the provisions of a rights of way permit and any other present or future lawful
exercise of the city's regulatory or police powers shall be resolved in favor of the latter. (Ord. 10-07, § 1,
4-7-2010)
24-36. Enforcement:
(a)Permittees hold permits issued pursuant to this article as a privilege and not as a right.
(b)If the city engineer determines that the permittee has violated a material term or condition of any
statute, ordinance, rule, regulation or any condition of the permit, the city engineer shall issue a
notice of violation to the permittee to remedy such violation. The notice of violation shall provide
requirements for correction of violation, any applicable penalties for continued violation, the process
and procedures for enforcement that may be applicable as required under the general ordinances of
the city. A material violation by permittee shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following:
(1) The violation of any material provision of the permit.
(2) An evasion or attempt to evade any material provision of the rights of way permit, or the
perpetration or attempt to perpetrate any fraud or deceit upon the city or its citizens.
(3) Any material misrepresentation of fact in the application for a permit.
(4) The failure to maintain the required bonds and/or insurance.
(5) The failure to complete the work in a timely manner.
(6) The failure to correct a condition indicated on an order issued pursuant to this article. (Ord. 10-07,
§ 1, 4-7-2010)
24-37. Exemptions:
The provisions of this article are not applicable to lawn irrigation systems, article III, "Sidewalks And
Driveways", and article IV, "Private Use Of The Parking Portion Of A Public Right Of Way", of this
chapter. (Ord. 10-07, § 1, 4-7-2010)
Secs. 24-38-24-48. Reserved:
ARTICLE III. SIDEWALKS AND DRIVEWAYS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 321/510
Sec. 24-49. Bond Required:
Except as otherwise provided in section 24-52 of this division, no person or firm shall construct, repair or
replace a sidewalk, curb and/or gutter, or driveway or contract to construct, repair or replace a sidewalk,
curb and/or gutter, or driveway within the public right of way without being a bonded concrete contractor.
(Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-50. Application; Bond:
Any person or firm desiring to be a bonded concrete contractor shall make application to the city
engineer on forms provided by the city engineer. Such applicant shall execute and file with the
application, a bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), approved by the city manager,
conditioned that the applicant shall observe and comply with all provisions of city ordinances and state
statutes relating to the construction of sidewalks, curbs and/or gutters, or driveways and save the city
harmless from all loss and damage resulting directly or indirectly from anything the applicant may do or
fail to do within the limits of any street or alley of the city and will defend all suits brought against the city
to recover damages for alleged loss or injury suffered, and further conditioned that the city or any person
that might be injured or damaged by the principal's failure to observe such ordinances may sue on such
bond to recover damages. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 96-39, § 1, 11-6-1996)
Sec. 24-51. Exceptions To Bonding:
A person or firm who is not bonded under the provisions of this article may construct, repair or replace
sidewalks, curbs and/or gutters, or driveways on public property under the following instances:
(1) When such person is the owner of record of abutting property and shall personally perform the
principal labor rather than act in a supervisory capacity. Such owner shall sign a bond releasing the
city from liability and conform to all other provisions of this article.
(2) When such person or firm is installing sidewalks and driveways in conjunction with a new city
street under contract to the city.
(3) When such person or firm is constructing, repairing or replacing sidewalks, curbs and/or gutters,
or driveways under contract with the city. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-52. Permits Required:
Except as otherwise provided, no person or firm shall construct, repair or replace any sidewalk, curb
and/or gutter, or driveway on public property without obtaining a permit to do so from the city engineer.
The applicant shall provide the address of the job, the name and address of the owner, and provide
information necessary to assure the work to be done is in conformance with this article. No work shall be
started prior to obtaining a permit. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 96-39, § 2, 11-6-1996)
Sec. 24-53. Fees; Penalties:
(a) Any person or entity desiring a permit for construction, repair or replacement of any sidewalk, curb
and/or gutter, or driveway on public property shall first make application to the city engineer and shall
pay the following permit fees:
(1) Free, if application is made at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the start of work.
(2) Twenty five dollars ($25.00) if application is made less than forty eight (48) hours before work
commences.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 322/510
(3) Fee is doubled to fifty dollars ($50.00) if work is commenced prior to obtaining a permit.
The city engineer may issue a cease and desist order to any person or entity that commences work
without first having obtained a city permit from the city engineer. Failure to obey the cease and desist
order will result in the city pursuing a remedy in court.
(b) Any person or entity intentionally violating a provision of this article is guilty of a public offense, and
upon conviction thereof shall be fined in a sum of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
Every day that this article is violated shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 03-01, § 2, 1-2-2003)
Secs. 24-54 24-59. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. SIDEWALK REPAIR, CONSTRUCTION, ETC.
Sec. 24-60. Construction Required:
(a)A sidewalk shall be constructed on at least one side of every street in the city at the time such street
is paved, or curbed and guttered, according and subject to the provisions of this section.
(b)Sidewalks, as provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be installed at the time of the street
paving and constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications of the city at a location within
the street right of way as approved by the city engineer.
(c)The cost of the sidewalks constructed pursuant to this section may be assessed in whole or in part to
the property owners as set forth by the city's hazardous sidewalk policy adopted by resolution 3532,
or in any benefit district established for this purpose.
(d)The city manager may, upon recommendations from the city engineer, waive the requirements set
forth herein in those instances where it is determined that the existence of sidewalks in a specific
location would not serve the public health, safety, or welfare, or where it is determined that
construction of sidewalks would be impractical. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 13-19, 6-19-2013)
Sec. 24-61. Owner's Responsibility:
The owner of property abutting any sidewalk shall be responsible for maintaining such sidewalk in a safe
condition unless waived by the city in accordance with resolution 3532. Should such sidewalk be
declared to be hazardous by the city, notice shall be sent to the owner to reconstruct such sidewalk
within ninety (90) days. If the sidewalk is not reconstructed by the property owner within the time
specified, the city shall cause the work to be done.
The city engineer shall keep an accurate record of all costs incurred in causing the sidewalk to be
replaced, including all removal of old material necessary to allow for the rebuilding and replacement of
such sidewalk, and shall notify the owner of record of such cost by certified mail, by mailing a notice to
his last known address. If after ninety (90) days from the mailing of such notice of cost, the cost has not
been paid, the city engineer shall certify all such costs to the city clerk. The city clerk immediately upon
receipt of such certification of cost shall certify such cost incurred to the county clerk as a special
assessment to be collected with other general taxes as provided by law. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord.
96-39, § 3, 11-6-1996; Ord. 13-19, 6-19-2013)
Sec. 24-62. Hazardous Sidewalk Defined:
A "hazardous sidewalk" is a sidewalk or portion thereof that becomes inadequate or unsafe for public
travel due to broken or missing pieces, unevenness or upheaval which causes at least a one-half inch
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 323/510
(1/2") difference in height between two (2) adjoining portions of the sidewalk, or one that has an abrupt
change in elevation, or a sidewalk which in the opinion of the city engineer has become unsafe for travel
due to deterioration or other reasons. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 96-39, § 4, 11-6-1996)
Sec. 24-63. Plans And Specifications:
All sidewalks within the city shall be constructed, repaired and reconstructed according to the plans and
specifications of the city. A copy of said plans and specifications approved by the governing body shall
be kept on file in the city clerk's office and the city engineer's office. If any property owner, person or
contractor shall construct any sidewalk in violation of this article, he shall be guilty of a class C
misdemeanor, and the sidewalk may be condemned by the governing body and torn out and rebuilt, and
in case of a contractor, no payment shall be due or made for such improperly constructed sidewalk.
(Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 96-39, § 5, 11-6-1996)
Sec. 24-64. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. DRIVEWAYS
Sec. 24-65. Permits Conditioned:
All permits for the use of public property under the provisions of this article shall be granted on the
condition that the permittee or his successors in title will, upon the abandonment of any driveway
entrance, restore or reconstruct the curb and gutter to its original condition upon notice from the city
engineer. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 96-39, § 6, 11-6-1996)
Sec. 24-66. Interference With Street Lighting Poles, Hydrants, Etc.:
No driveway entrance shall be constructed which will interfere with public facilities including street
lighting poles, traffic signal standards, signs, catch basins, hydrants, crosswalks, loading zones, utility
poles, fire alarm supports, underground pipes or ducts or other necessary street structures. (Ord. 86-2, §
2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-67. Maximum Number Per Lot:
No more than one driveway entrance shall be constructed for access to one parcel of ground less than
fifty feet (50') in width, except that one entrance shall be permitted to any lot of lesser width under
separate ownership; provided, that there may be one entrance from each street of a corner lot, and more
than one entrance may be constructed to gain access to commercial and industrial occupancies from a
single street front. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-68. Size Limitations:
(a)No driveway entrance in an R-1 low density residential district of the city shall have a width of less
than twelve feet (12') or more than thirty six feet (36'). Such width shall not exceed fifty percent (50%)
of the length of the property line on which the driveway is located. Further, no more than fifty percent
(50%) of the lot between the house and the property line may be covered with driveway.
(b)No driveway entrance in an R-2 medium density or R-3 high density residential district of the city shall
have a width of less than twelve feet (12') or more than twenty four feet (24').
(c)No driveway entrance in a commercial district of the city shall have a width of less than twelve feet
(12') or more than forty feet (40').
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 324/510
(d)No driveway entrance in the industrial district of the city shall have a width of more than forty feet
(40'), provided, that upon written request made to the city engineer by any property owner whose
property is zoned for either light or heavy industrial usage and is located on and seeking to construct
a driveway on a local or collector street, such property owner may construct a drive or drives the
width of which may equal eighty percent (80%) of the width of the property, but which may not
exceed a maximum width of sixty feet (60'); and provided further, that such drives shall lead to either
private property, suitable off street parking or a building entrance having a minimum width of seven
feet (7') and that a minimum of five feet (5') of street curb length shall be maintained on each side of
such driveways.
(e)No curb cutting width shall exceed the width of the driveway entrance at the sidewalk or property line
by more than ten feet (10') for a residential entrance, or as approved by the city engineer for a
driveway entrance in an industrial or commercial district in the city. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord.
06-12, § 1, 6-7-2006; Ord. 16-44, 11-2-2016)
Sec. 24-69. Angle To Street:
The sides, edges or curbs of driveway entrances shall be at right angles to the street curb except for a
curb return. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-70. Repair, Etc., Of Sidewalks And Curbs:
(a)No driveway entrance shall be constructed across any sidewalk unless such sidewalk be constructed
or reconstructed in accordance with specifications pertaining to the construction of sidewalks to be
used as driveway entrances.
(b)No driveway entrance shall be constructed in a manner to change or interfere with the gutter flow line
or sidewalk grade where such driveway entrance crosses any such gutter or sidewalk.
(c)The sidewalk and curb shall, insofar as possible, be cut and removed at the nearest joint and upon
replacement and reconstruction of a sidewalk as an entrance, the construction of the curb return and
any pavement in connection with an entrance or driveway, suitable joints shall be provided in all such
work where the same come into contact, all such spaces shall be filled by a bituminous fiber or
compound in accordance with the specifications of the city. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-71. Construction:
All driveway entrances shall be constructed with permanent type surfacing and in accordance with the
plans and specifications approved by the governing body and on file in the office of the city engineer and
city clerk. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 96-39, § 7, 11-6-1996)
Sec. 24-72. Traffic Committee:
Upon application and for good cause shown, the traffic committee is hereby authorized to provide
substitute or alternative provisions to the regulations regarding driveways set forth in sections 24-67 and
24-68 of this division. For the purposes of this section, applications for modifications of the requirements
of sections 24-67 and 24-68 of this division shall be considered by the traffic committee as a routine
traffic and parking regulation and the provisions of chapter 25, article V of this code, shall be applicable
to such application. (Ord. 87-37, § 1, 12-2-1987)
Secs. 24-73 24-74. Reserved:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 325/510
ARTICLE IV. PRIVATE USE OF THE PARKING PORTION OF A PUBLIC
RIGHT OF WAY
Sec. 24-75. Parking Portion Of Street Right Of Way Defined:
The public parking portion of any street, highway or public way is that portion of a street, highway or
public way lying between the boundary line of real property and the curbline or edge of a roadway
therein used for vehicular travel. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-76. Mailboxes:
A property owner may cause the installation of a United States postal service approved receptacle for
the delivery and collection of mail upon the public parking adjacent to his property. Multiple occupancy
structures and areas shall not have any mail receptacle that is of such a size that cannot be mounted
upon a single pedestal of no more than six inches (6") in thickness. Only one such receptacle shall be at
any one location. If more than one is required, due to the size of the usage, the locations shall be
approved by the building official. No mail receptacle shall be so located as to interfere with any traffic or
utility. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-77. Decorative Fences And Walls:
(a)General Restrictions: Decorative fences and driveway approach walls, excluding retaining walls, may
be installed on adjacent public parking upon approval of the building official under the following
provisions:
(1) Such structure does not obstruct a public sidewalk.
(2) Such structure is not an enclosure, fence, or wall.
(3) Such structure is not a continuation of a fence on the private property.
(4) Such structure shall not exceed eight feet (8') in length in any direction.
(5) Such structure shall not exceed the height allowed by the zoning regulations for a fence in a front
yard.
(6) No part of the structure shall be located in a sight triangle as defined by the zoning regulations.
(b)Approval By The Governing Body: Uses desired within the parking area of a street not listed in or
limited by subsection (a)(1) of this section may be approved by the governing body of the city upon
receiving a specific written request. The governing body, if they desire to approve such requests,
may impose restrictions or limitations as they deem necessary in order to protect the public interest.
(Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 87-41, § 1, 12-16-1987)
Sec. 24-78. Landscaping:
Landscaping consisting of flowers, shrubs or other vegetation or of other natural or manmade material
may be installed in the public parking provided that they do not interfere with the sight triangle as defined
in the zoning regulations and do not cause a hazard to people, animals or vehicles, because of shape,
size, location or construction. All such use is subject to removal at the expense of the owner when
necessary because of any new or repaired public sidewalk, street, utility or other public improvement, or
when deemed by the building official to be a hazard to people, animals or vehicles because of shape,
size, location or construction. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 326/510
Sec. 24-79. Other Uses:
Other uses of the public parking is allowed only if specific approval is granted by the building official,
who shall determine if such use is necessary and/or desirable. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986)
Sec. 24-80. Removal Of Trees And Shrubs And Other Obstructions On Parkings:
When it is advisable and necessary that certain trees and shrubs on the parking of any street be
trimmed, cut or removed, or that any other obstruction on the parking of any street be removed, in the
interest of public safety, said removal shall be accomplished in accordance with the procedures as set
forth in section 24-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 86-2, § 2, 2-19-1986; Ord. 88-31, § 2, 11-2-1988)
Sec. 24-81. Reserved:
ARTICLE V. MOVING OF BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, ETC.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 24-82. Police Escort:
It shall be unlawful for any person to move, haul or transport any building or structure for which a permit
is required by the provisions of this article upon any of the streets of the city without a police escort.
(1962 Code, § 6-805)
Sec. 24-83. Notice To Remove Wires:
If in moving a house, building, derrick or other structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article it
shall be necessary to cut and move, raise or in anywise interfere with any telephone, telegraph, electric
light or electric power wires, the party receiving the permit shall give twenty four (24) hours' written
notice to the person owning or operating such wires, or to their agents, of the time and place, when and
where the removal of said poles, or the raising, cutting or otherwise interfering with said wires will be
necessary. (1962 Code, § 6-806)
Sec. 24-84. Removal Of Wires Or Poles:
(a)It shall be the duty of any person owning or operating poles or wires, after service of notice as
required in section 24-83 of this division, to remove such wires or poles or raise or cut such wires as
will be necessary to facilitate moving of such house, building, derrick, or other structure.
(b)The necessary expenses incurred in cutting, raising, removing, and replacing such wires and poles
shall be paid by the mover of the house, building, derrick or other structure, and the owner of the
wires and poles may require the payment to be made in advance, with the understanding that the
company can require enough money to be paid to cover the cost of the work, but that the company
will refund any excess in the amount paid over the actual cost.
(c)No person engaged in moving any house, building, derrick or other structure, shall cut or interfere with
any poles or wires unless the persons owning or having control thereof fail or refuse to do so after
having been notified as required by section 24-83 of this chapter, and after the advance payment
called for above has been made. If such owners or persons in control fail to do so the mover may
remove or cut wires or poles, but only competent workmen shall be employed in such work, and the
work shall be done in a careful and workmanlike manner, and the poles and wires shall be promptly
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 327/510
replaced, and the damage thereto promptly repaired. In this case the necessary and reasonable
expense of moving and replacing the wires and poles shall be paid by the owners or operators of the
wires and poles. (1962 Code § 6-807; Ord. 198, § 1, 12-16-1964)
Sec. 24-85. Tree Damage Or Removal:
(a)No tree or part thereof shall be broken, cut or removed for the purpose of moving any house, building,
derrick or other structure except with the permission and under the direction and supervision of a
person duly authorized by the city and in such manner and way and with such treatment of said tree
thereafter as may be required by the city. Any person breaking or removing any tree or part thereof
as herein forbidden or who shall direct or request such breaking, cutting or removing or who may be
responsible therefor shall pay the expense incurred by the city in supervising the cutting or treatment
of such tree.
(b)This section shall not be deemed to permit the cutting or trimming of any tree contrary to the law or
ordinance or relieve any such persons of any liability on account of such cutting, breaking or trimming
of trees.
(c)In moving any house, building, derrick or other structure, stakes shall not be driven into or through the
pavement nor shall trees growing within the streets be attached to in any way. (1962 Code § 6-808)
Sec. 24-86. Warning Signs And Lights:
If any house, building, derrick or other structure which is being moved, or any apparatus, tools or
equipment used in connection with such moving, shall be left in any street or public place at night or at
any other time while no work is being done in connection therewith, the person doing such moving shall
place at each end of the block a warning sign, of such size and method of construction as may be
approved by the city engineer which shall leave space for the passing of traffic, for the purpose of
notifying users of the streets that the same is blocked. Such sign, house, building, derrick or other
structure, apparatus, tools and equipment shall be sufficiently lighted at night with red lights to make it
plainly visible to all persons approaching the same. The person moving such house, building, derrick or
other structure shall notify the city engineer of the exact location of the same, if within any street,
avenue, alley or other public thoroughfare in the city. (1962 Code § 6-810)
Sec. 24-87. Liability For Damage:
If in moving any house, building, derrick or other structure, damage shall be done to any street, avenue,
alley or the pavement thereof, or to any building, bridge or other property belonging to the city or to trees
or other private property or to any person lawfully using the street, the house mover shall be liable for
and pay the damages, and if not paid, may be recovered under said bond by any party damaged or
injured. (1962 Code § 6-809)
Sec. 24-88. Violations And Penalty:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article or the permit granted under this article
shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor. The person making the application for the permit shall be
deemed to have authorized and shall be responsible for any violation of this article by any person in his
employ; but nothing herein contained shall relieve any other person from responsibility for any violation
of the terms of this article of which such person may be found guilty. (1962 Code § 6-811)
Secs. 24-89-24-99. Reserved.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 328/510
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 24-100. City Permit Required:
No person shall move, haul or transport any house, building, derrick or other structure, which, after
having been placed in final position for moving, shall be or exceed a height of sixteen feet (16'), or a
width of fifteen feet (15'), or a length of one hundred twenty six feet (126'), upon, across or over any of
the streets, avenues or alleys of the city without first obtaining a permit for so doing from the city. (1962
Code § 6-801; Ord. 14-13, 5-21-2014)
Sec. 24-101. Application:
An application for the permit required by this division shall be in writing, and shall be signed by the
applicant. It shall name the owner of and describe the house, building, derrick, or other structure to be
moved including the dimensions of such house, building, derrick, or other structure when loaded, the
date and time of the move; the location, to and from which the house, building, derrick or other structure
is being moved, the route to be used and the proposed use of the house, building, derrick or other
structure when it is relocated. (1962 Code § 6-804; Ord. 189, § 1, 10-28-1964)
Sec. 24-102. Issuance:
An application for the permit required by this division shall be presented to the city engineer and if he
finds that removal will not conflict with the ordinances of the city and if in his judgment the move can be
made with safety to the public, and without damage to the streets, trees, or other property, he may
approve the proposed route or designate a different one. He may require the planking of streets, the
shoring up of bridges, cribbing of ditches, and such other regulations as he shall deem necessary. The
city engineer shall endorse on such application his approval or disapproval and recommendations. Each
application, if approved, shall be filed with the city clerk who shall issue the permit upon payment of the
required fee. Each applicant must apply to the city no less than five (5) business days prior to the
proposed date of movement. The movement date will be selected to allow sufficient time for each
approving entity to review the route, including Westar which requires fifteen (15) days' notice. Each
application, if approved, shall be filed with the city clerk who shall issue the permit upon payment of the
required fee. (1962 Code § 6-804; Ord. 189, § 1, 10-28-1964; Ord. 14-13, 5-21-2014)
Sec. 24-103. Fee:
Any person receiving a permit pursuant to the provisions of this division shall pay a fee of seventy five
dollars ($75.00) to the city clerk prior to the issuance of the permit. This fee does not include the charge
for the required police escort or any fee required by another entity. If the work for which a permit is
required is commenced prior to obtaining the permit, the permit shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00). (1962 Code § 6-804; Ord. 189, § 1, 10-28-1964; Ord. 84-7, § 1, 3-7-1984; Ord. 94-35, § 1, 8-
3-1994; Ord. 14-13, 5-21-2014)
Sec. 24-104. Insurance:
Before the permit required by this division shall be issued, the applicant therefor shall file, in addition to
the required bond, a policy of insurance or a certificate thereof providing public liability insurance with
limits of liability not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury of any one
person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury in any one accident and fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for damage to property in any one accident. (1962 Code § 6-803)
Sec. 24-105. Bond:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 329/510
Before the permit required by this division shall be issued, the applicant therefor must execute and
deliver to the city a good and sufficient bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), to be
approved by the city manager, conditioned that the applicant shall and will carry out, perform and
observe all of the duties imposed upon him by the provisions of this article, also those imposed by the
permit and that such applicant will indemnify and save harmless the city and all other parties from and
against all claims for injury or damage whatsoever suffered or claimed to have been suffered on account
of the moving of any such house, building, derrick or other structure or on account of the omission or
commission of any act in connection therewith and indemnifying the city and the public and any and all
persons against any injury, damage or loss suffered by them or caused by reason of said moving or
resulting therefrom or from the violation of any of the terms of this article or the permit granted, whether
caused by the principal, his agents or employees. Such bond shall provide that the city or any individual
who is injured or damaged by reason of such moving may file suit directly against the surety named in
such bond. One bond may be filed by any person to cover any and all moving of houses, buildings,
derricks or other structures by such person during the period of such bond. Any surety may cancel any
such bond by giving ten (10) days' notice in writing of such cancellation to the city clerk, to take effect at
the expiration of said ten (10) days, and after the giving of such notice, but the surety shall remain liable
on all permits previously issued; however, no permit shall be issued to the principal named in such bond,
after receipt of such notice, until he shall file another bond as required by this section. (1962 Code § 6-
802)
Sec. 24-106. Sewer Capping As Prerequisite:
Prior to the issuance of a permit pursuant to the provisions of this division the owner of such house,
building, derrick or structure to be moved shall cause the sewer to be capped by a licensed plumbing
contractor and such capping shall be inspected and approved by the building official. All such sewers
shall be capped in an approved manner at a location between the connection to the sewer main and a
point five feet (5') inside of the property line nearest such sewer. (1962 Code § 6-804(a); Ord. 1094, § 1,
4-7-1982)
Sec. 24-107. Term:
A permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall expire ninety (90) days after its issuance.
(1962 Code § 6-804; Ord. 189, § 1, 10-28-1964)
Secs. 24-108-24-118. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS
Sec. 24-119. Required:
All buildings fronting on public streets in the city shall be numbered in conformity with the provisions of
this article. (1962 Code § 6-901)
Sec. 24-120. Scheme:
(a)The numbering system for all buildings fronting on public streets shall be as follows:
(1) On all streets running north and south, the numbering shall commence at their intersection with
South Avenue with number "1" on the west side of the street, and number "2" on the east side and
shall increase going north and south giving each twenty five feet (25') a number along the building
line to the intersection with the next avenue; thence commencing with 101 on the west side of the
street and number 102 on the east side of the street and so on through each street.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 330/510
(2) On avenues running east and west, the numbering shall commence at their intersection with
Commercial Street with number "one" on the south side of the avenue and number "two" on the north
side and shall increase going east and west giving a number to each twenty two feet (22') along the
building line to the intersection with the next street; thence commencing with number 102 on the
north and 101 on the south side of the avenue and so on through each avenue.
(3) Where streets and avenues do not intersect but join only at approximately right angles, the
numbering of buildings on that side of the street or avenue that is not intersected shall increase one
hundred (100) at the point approximately opposite the side of the joining street or avenue that is
farther from South Avenue or Commercial Street, as the case may be.
(4) Where streets and avenues do not intersect directly, but do continue at an offset and under the
same name, the numbering shall be controlled by the street or avenue that was first established as
such within the City.
(b)The Building Official is hereby authorized to establish such exceptions to the numbering system
described in subsection (a) as may be made necessary by the irregular routing of any street or
avenue of the City. (1962 Code, §§ 6-901, 6-904)
Sec. 24-121. Placement Of Numbers:
The owner of each building fronting on public streets or avenues of the City shall place on the front of his
building in any conspicuous place a number assigned by the Building Official in accordance with this
Article, unless such house or building is already correctly numbered. Such numbers shall be at least two
inches (2") in height. (1962 Code, § 6-902; Ord. 87-4, § 1, 1-21-87)
Sec. 24-122. Numbering:
When any new building shall be erected so as to front on any street or avenue, the same shall be
numbered within thirty (30) days after completion as provided in this Article for buildings already erected.
(1962 Code, § 6-903)
Sec. 24-123. Violations:
If any owner neglects or refuses to number his building as provided in this Article, he shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1962 Code, § 6-905)
Sec. 24-124. Painted Curb Numbers (Optional):
(a) The painting of address numbers on street curbs in accordance with the provisions of this Section is
hereby approved by the property owner, a resident of such property, or by an individual hired by
either of such persons.
(b) Any persons holding themselves out for hire for the painting of address numbers on curbs shall be
required to register with the City Clerk's office, but no fee for such registration shall be imposed and
there shall be no permit required for the painting of such address numbers.
(c) Only one address number per house is permitted to be painted on the curb, provided, however, that a
house on a corner lot may have address numbers painted on either or both street frontage curbs. All
numbers painted on the curb shall be four inch (4") stenciled numbers painted in white and a
reflective paint is encouraged, but not required, or in the alternative the numbers may be painted in
black upon a white rectangular background. Except as specifically provided, painting of any
background color is prohibited.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 331/510
(d) The painting of address numbers on the curb shall be supplemental to and shall not replace any
numbering requirements for buildings provided by this Article, the Fire Code 174 , or any other code
or regulation of the City. (Ord. 94-14, § 1, 4-6-94; Ord. 95-11, § 1, 3-22-95)
Secs. 24-125-24-134. (Reserved)
ARTICLE VII. PUBLIC PARADES, MEETINGS, SPEECHES AND
EXHIBITIONS 175
Sec. 24-135. Definitions:
As used in this Article the term "parade" shall mean any parade, march or procession upon any street.
(1983 Code)
Sec. 24-136. Exemptions:
This Article shall not apply to:
(1) Funeral processions;
(2) Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such
conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities;
(3) A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions;
(4) Activities regulated by Section 24-11 of this Chapter. (1983 Code)
Sec. 24-137. Permit Required:
No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, or make any public speech or
hold any meeting or make any exhibition with intent to attract a crowd in any street without a permit
issued by the Chief of Police. (1962 Code, § 20-409; Ord. 847, § 1, 6-15-77)
Sec. 24-138. Permit Applications:
(a) A person desiring the permit required by this Article shall file an application with the Chief of Police
on forms provided by such officer. Such application shall be filed not less than ten (10) days before
the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade.
(b) The application for a permit shall set forth the following information:
(1) The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade or
make such speech or exhibition or hold such meeting;
(2) If the parade, speech, exhibition or meeting is proposed to be conducted, held or made for, on
behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the
organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization;
(3) The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be responsible for the conduct
of such parade, exhibition or meeting;
(4) The date when the parade, speech, exhibition or meeting is to be conducted;
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 332/510
(5) The parade route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; in the case of a
speech, meeting or exhibition, the location where it will be held or made;
(6) The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute or
attend such parade, meeting, speech or exhibition; and the type of animals, and description of the
vehicles;
(7) The time when such parade, speech, exhibition or meeting will start and terminate;
(8) A statement as to whether the parade, speech, exhibition or meeting will occupy all or only a
portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed or used;
(9) The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade, speech, exhibition or meeting;
(10) The time at which units of the parade, exhibition, speech or meeting will begin to assemble at
any such assembly area or areas;
(11) The interval of space to be maintained between units of the parade;
(12) If the parade, exhibition, speech or meeting is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for,
any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a
communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, exhibition, speech or
meeting, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf;
(13) Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair
determination as to whether a permit should issue.
(c) The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any
application hereunder which is filed less than ten (10) days before the date such parade, speech,
exhibition or meeting is proposed to be conducted.
Sec. 24-139. Standards for permit issuance.
The chief of police shall issue a permit pursuant to this article when, from a consideration of the
application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that:
(1) The conduct of the parade, exhibition, speech or meeting for which a permit is required will not
substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route;
(2) The conduct of such parade, exhibition, speech or meeting will not require the diversion of so
great a number of police officers of this municipality to properly police the line of movement and the
areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this municipality;
(3) The conduct of such parade, exhibition, speech or meeting will not require the diversion of so
great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this city other
than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto;
(4) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of such parade,
exhibition, speech or meeting will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or
ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas;
(5) The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of fire-fighting equipment en
route to a fire;
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 333/510
(6) The conduct of the parade will not create a clear and present danger of injury to persons or
property, or of provoking disorderly conduct or creating a disturbance;
(7) The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously
and without unreasonable delays en route;
(8) The parade, exhibition, speech or meeting is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any
product, cause, goods or events and is not designed to be held purely for private profit.
Sec. 24-140. Notice of permit denial.
If the chief of police disapproves the application for the permit required by this article, he shall mail to the
applicant within three (3) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action.
Sec. 24-141. Alternative permit.
The chief of police, in denying an application for the permit required by this article, shall be empowered
to authorize the conduct of the parade, exhibition, meeting or speech on a date, at a time, at a place or
over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate
permit shall, within five (5) days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of
acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall
have the effect of a permit under this article.
Sec. 24-142. Contents of permit.
Each permit issued pursuant to this article shall state the following information:
(1) Starting time;
(2) Minimum speed;
(3) Maximum speed;
(4) Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade;
(5) The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade, speech, meeting
or exhibition;
(6) The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof;
(7) Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this
article.
Sec. 24-143. Carrying Permit:
The chairman or other person heading or leading the activity for which a permit is required by this article
shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of same. (1983 Code)
Sec. 24-144. Revocation Of Permit:
The chief of police shall have the authority, after a hearing affording due process, to revoke a permit
issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. (1983 Code)
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 334/510
Sec. 24-145. Compliance With Laws And Regulations:
A person holding a permit issued pursuant to this article shall comply with all permit directions and
conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. (1983 Code)
ARTICLE VIII. STREET AND SIDEWALK SOLICITATION
Sec. 24-146. Prohibition:
It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to engage in street or sidewalk charitable solicitation
without first obtaining a permit from the office of the Emporia city clerk. This section shall not apply to
door to door solicitation, or the exercise of a person's right to legally picket or protest. (Ord. 04-36, § 1,
11-17-2004)
Sec. 24-147. Permit Application:
Every person or organization subject to the provisions of this article shall file with the Emporia city clerk
an application in writing on a form to be furnished.
(1)Applications under this section shall be filed fourteen (14) days in advance of the planned street or
sidewalk solicitation. No permit shall be valid for longer than three (3) days. No organization or
individual, or their servant, employee or agent, shall be issued more than one permit in any six (6)
month period of time.
(2)The application shall be forwarded to the office of the chief of police. Upon receipt of the application,
the chief of police, or his designee, shall review the application as deemed necessary to protect the
public health, safety and welfare.
(3)A permit shall not be issued if the location and time of the solicitation would endanger the safety and
welfare of the solicitors or the public; or for fraud, misrepresentation or false statement. A permit shall
not be issued to any person or entity, when they have, within the preceding seven (7) years been
convicted or pled guilty to any felony or misdemeanor involving force or threat of force, theft,
dishonesty, fraud or sexual misconduct. An applicant may appeal the denial to the city commission
not later than thirty (30) days after the mailing of the notification to the last known address of the
applicant.
(4)Any permit issued under this section may be revoked by the chief of police, or his designee, due to
failure to conform to the requirements of subsection (3) of this section, or for conducting solicitation in
such a manner as to create a public nuisance, committing a breach of the peace, or endangering the
public health or safety. (Ord. 04-36, § 1, 11-17-2004)
Sec. 24-148. Dangerous Intersections:
