Due to traffic volume, the following roadways and intersections within the city of Emporia shall not be
used for sidewalk and street solicitation:
12th Avenue and Industrial Street.
12th Avenue and Merchant Street.
15th Avenue and Industrial Street.
18th Avenue and Industrial Street.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 335/510
24th Avenue and Industrial Street.
Commercial Street between 11th Avenue and 4th Avenue.
State Highway 50. (Ord. 04-36, § 1, 11-17-2004)
Sec. 24-149. Penalty:
Violation of any of the provisions of this article is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for each day of the violation. (Ord. 04-36, § 1, 11-17-2004)
Chapter 25
TRAFFIC
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 25-1. Traffic Signs, Signals, Etc. 1:
The existence and location of all traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings, which are not
inconsistent with the manual and specifications adopted by the state highway commission, are hereby
ratified and confirmed by the governing body. (1983 Code)
Sec. 25-2. Careless driving.
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or halt any vehicle on public or private property in such a
manner as to indicate a careless or heedless disregard for the rights or the safety of others, or in such a
manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger, any person or property. A person shall be considered in
violation of this section who:
(1) Fails to remain alert and give full attention to the safe operation of his vehicle; or
(2) Engages in any activity which interferes with the safe control of his vehicle; or
(3) Because of driving error or inattention, collides with another vehicle, person or fixed object; or
(4) Operates a vehicle with unnecessary and excessive noise or spinning of wheels; or
(5) Drives a vehicle abreast of another vehicle while any person in his vehicle carries on a
conversation with any person in the other vehicle.
(Ord. No. 853, § 1, 8-17-77)
Sec. 25-2. Careless Driving KSA §§ 8-2001, 8-2002.2:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or halt any vehicle on public or private property in such a
manner as to indicate a careless or heedless disregard for the rights or the safety of others, or in such a
manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger, any person or property. A person shall be considered in
violation of this section who:
(1) Fails to remain alert and give full attention to the safe operation of his vehicle; or
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 336/510
(2) Engages in any activity which interferes with the safe control of his vehicle; or
(3) Because of driving error or inattention, collides with another vehicle, person or fixed object; or
(4) Operates a vehicle with unnecessary and excessive noise or spinning of wheels; or
(5) Drives a vehicle abreast of another vehicle while any person in his vehicle carries on a
conversation with any person in the other vehicle. (Ord. 853, § 1, 8-17-1977)
Sec. 25-2.5. Stopping Of Vehicles Under Certain Conditions:
(a)Stopping Conditions: Whenever a visual sign or signal to stop is given within a school speed zone by
a school crossing guard approved by school authorities or by the city of Emporia police department,
who is displaying or wearing identifying markings or clothing, all persons shall bring their vehicles to
an immediate and complete stop and shall not proceed until such time as said school crossing guard
advises any person so stopped to proceed.
(b)Penalty: Any person found guilty of violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a class
C misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by
confinement in the county jail for a definite term not to exceed one month, or be both so fined and
confined. (Ord. 83-4, §§ 1, 2, 4-6-1983)
Sec. 25-3. Violation Of Driver's License Restrictions:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in any manner in violation of the restrictions
imposed in a restricted operator's or chauffeur's license issued to him by the vehicle department of the
state highway commission or the appropriate department of any state issuing such licenses. Any person
who shall violate this article shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor. (Ord. 514, §§ 1, 2, 8-4-1971)
Sec. 25-4. Towing Or Removal Of Vehicles:
(a)In the circumstances hereinafter enumerated, preservation of the public safety and welfare requires
that vehicles be removed from the public right of way without delay. Therefore, any police officer,
acting in his official capacity, is hereby authorized, in his discretion, to order the towing or removal of
an unoccupied vehicle from any street, alley, highway, roadway, sidewalk, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, or
any other public way or place or from any restricted or prohibited parking area, without permission of
the owner or person using the same, to a public or private garage or yard suitable for the storage of
impounded vehicles under any of the circumstances hereinafter enumerated:
(1) When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, causeway or viaduct, or in any subway,
where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to the normal movement of traffic.
(2) When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic or the person
or persons in charge of the vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as
to be unable to provide for its custody and removal.
(3) When a vehicle is found being driven upon the streets and is not in proper condition to be driven.
(4) When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is parked so illegally as to constitute a
definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic.
(5) When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and such vehicle
would thereby be left unattended upon a street.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 337/510
(6) When removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm or other
emergency reasons.
(7) When a driver, owner, or person in charge of such vehicle fails to appear in municipal court after a
warrant has been issued and served upon said owner or person alleging a violation of the provisions
of any tragic or parking ordinance of the city.
(8) When such vehicle is subject to tow or removal under the provisions of any ordinance of the city.
(9) When the driver of any vehicle or the vehicle in which he is driving is reasonably suspected of
having been involved in any hit and run accident.
(10) When any vehicle is reasonably suspected of being a stolen vehicle, or parts thereof to be stolen
parts.
(11) When the driver of any vehicle is taken into custody for suspected felony or misdemeanor, or
when the vehicle is suspected of containing stolen goods or other contraband.
(12) When such vehicle is illegally left standing under such circumstances as to obstruct the normal
movement of traffic from or to private property.
(13) When any vehicle is found unattended upon a street, alley, highway or any other public right-ofway
in such a position as to obstruct the commencement or on-going operation of a construction,
maintenance, or repair project in such right-of-way, and it is not practicable to move such vehicle or
require the driver or person in charge of the vehicle to move the same to a nearby position where it
may be readily found by its driver where it will not constitute an obstruction to traffic or violate a
parking regulation; provided that, unless forty-eight (48) hours advanced notice of the project and
parking prohibition, including the dates and hours of the parking ban, has been conspicuously posted
and maintained on the site, and inquiries have been made at abutting properties in an effort to locate
the vehicle owner, the city or other person or entity which requested the impoundment shall be
responsible for towing and storage charges and, if necessary, shall assist the owner in retrieving
such vehicle from the storage lot.
(b)No vehicle so removed and stored or impounded by order of a police officer as provided in subsection
(a) shall be surrendered to the duly identified owner or person using the same unless the reasonable
charges for the expense of the towing or removing of said vehicle, reasonable storage charges, and
any other reasonable cost resulting from such order have been paid.
(c)Upon demand of the owner of an impounded vehicle, if such demand is made before payment of the
charges specified in subsection (b) or if such charges are paid under protest, the judge of the
municipal court shall conduct a hearing, as soon as is practicable, at which time testimony and
evidence may be presented relative to the propriety of assessing such charges, and, the judge of the
municipal court shall be, and hereby is, after such hearing, authorized and empowered to waive or
adjust any such charges whenever in his judgment a vehicle has been removed and stored or
impounded through no fault of the owner thereof or because of clear error or judgment on the part of
the officer or other city employee.
(d)Whenever, as authorized by subsection (a), an officer or employee of the city removes a vehicle from
the place where it was left, and the officer or employee knows and is able to ascertain from the
license or registration the name and address of the owner thereof, and if the vehicle is not reclaimed
within two (2) days of impoundment, such officer or employee shall give, or cause to be given, on the
first business day subsequent to the first two (2) days of impoundment, a notice by mail or other
means to such owner of the fact of such impoundment, reason therefore, place to which the vehicle
has been removed, and that such person may have a hearing before payment of the impoundment
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 338/510
fees. Unless reasonable attempts to provide such notice have been made, the city shall be
responsible for unnecessary storage fees, but nothing more.
(e)Whenever, pursuant to the terms of this section, a vehicle has been stored in any public or private
garage or yard maintained or designated for the storage of impounded vehicles for a period of fifteen
(15) days, and no claim of ownership or the right to possession thereof has not been made, or when
such claim has been made, but not established to the satisfaction of the chief of police, or his
authorized agents, and no suit or action to determine such claim has been instituted and is pending,
the chief of police or his authorized agents, shall appraise the value of the vehicle and make a record
thereof, shall declare the vehicle abandoned and shall dispose of such vehicle in the manner as
provided by K.S.A. 8-1102.
(Ord. No. 1128, §§ 1-5, 11-3-82)
Sec. 25-5. Impoundment, disposition and sale of abandoned motor vehicles.
(a) The impoundment, disposition and sale of motor vehicles abandoned on public streets or other
property open to use by the public in the city shall be made in accordance with K.S.A. 8-1101, et
seq., as amended.
(b) All proceeds from the sale of vehicles pursuant to this section shall be first applied toward the
satisfaction of towing, storing, publication, and other expenses incurred by the city in connection with
said vehicles. Any surplus proceeds shall be raid into the general operating fund of the city.
(Ord. No. 934, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-79)
Cross references- Junked vehicles, § 17-29 et seq.; inoperable motor vehicles, App. C, Art. XV, §
12.
Sec. 25-6. Penalties.
Every person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter for which another penalty is
not specifically provided shall, for first conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days; for a second such
conviction within one year thereafter such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00), or by imprisonment for not more than twenty (20) days, or by both such fine
and imprisonment; upon a third or subsequent conviction within one year after the first conviction such
person shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment
for not more than six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (1962 Code, § 21-301)
Sec. 25-7. Truck Routes:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any vehicle, other than those which are designed, used, or maintained primarily
to carry passengers, to enter upon or to be operated upon any street within the city except those
streets designated as and identified as truck routes.
(b)The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to those vehicles engaged in repairing,
maintaining or constructing streets, utility services, conducting refuse collections, or other city
vehicles, vehicles carrying goods, wares, merchandise or other articles to and from any house,
residence, or business establishment within the city, provided the vehicle takes the most direct route
to and from the facilities on the routes designated in this section. Further, all vehicles to which the
designated routes are applicable shall be permitted to enter upon streets in areas under construction
or where construction and building are taking place for the purpose of delivery and receiving
construction goods or materials to any location in the city provided the vehicle takes the most direct
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 339/510
route to and from the location by the designated routes in this section when entering or leaving the
construction area or area where building is taking place. For purposes of this subsection taking the
most direct route shall not be deemed to include the use of local streets when access can be
obtained from an arterial or collector street.
(c)The following streets are designated as truck routes in the city:
(1) U.S. 50 alternate from the west city limits east to east city limits.
(2) 6th Avenue from Overlander Street east to U.S. 50.
(3) 12th Avenue from Hatcher Street east to Burlingame Road.
(4) 15th Avenue from Hatcher Street east to Industrial Road.
(5) Overlander Street from 6th Avenue north to U.S. 50.
(6) Graphic Arts Road from 6th Avenue north to U.S. 50.
(7) Industrial Road from 6th Avenue north to I-35 bypass.
(8) Merchant Street from 2nd Avenue north to I-35 bypass.
(9) Commercial Street from Cottonwood River north to 12th Avenue.
(10) Peyton Street from 6th Avenue north to 12th Avenue.
(11) South Avenue from Prairie Street east to Weaver Street.
(12) Hatcher Street from 12th Avenue north to 15th Avenue.
(13) Graham Street from U.S. 50 north to 12th Avenue.
(14) Prairie Street from U.S. 50 Highway south to city limits.
(15) Second Avenue from Merchant Street east to Commercial Street.
(16) Logan Avenue from Commercial Street east to Weaver Street.
(17) Weaver Street from Logan Avenue north to U.S. 50.
(d)The streets designated in subsection (c) of this section shall be properly identified and posted as truck
routes within the city. (Ord. 96-31, § 1, 10-2-1996; Ord. 10-29, 11-3-2010)
Secs. 25-8-25-20. Reserved:

(a)Adopted: There is hereby incorporated by reference, for the purpose of regulating traffic within the
corporate limits of the city, that certain standard traffic ordinance known as the "Standard Traffic
Ordinance For Kansas Cities", 44th edition, 2016, prepared and published in book form by the
League Of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas, save and except such sections, parts or portions
as are hereafter omitted, deleted, modified or changed. No fewer than three (3) copies of said
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 340/510
standard traffic ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Section 25-21 of
the Code of the City of Emporia, Kansas, 1983", with all sections or portions thereof intended to be
omitted or changed clearly marked to show any such omission or change, and to which shall be
attached a copy of the ordinance codified herein, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection
and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge and all
administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of the ordinance shall be supplied,

marked, as may be deemed expedient.

Sec. 25-22. Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations Adopted:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 342/510
(a)Adopted: There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating traffic upon
highways and streets of the city of Emporia that certain standard safety regulation known as the
"federal motor carrier safety regulations, parts 383, 385 and 390-397" and except such articles,
sections, parts or portions as are hereafter omitted, deleted, modified or amended. No less than
three (3) copies of said book shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as adopted by Ordinance
No. 09-21", with all sections or portions thereof intended to be omitted or changed clearly marked to
show any such omission or change and to which shall be attached a copy of ordinance 09-21, and
filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours.
The police department, municipal judge, city prosecutor and all administrative departments of the city
charged with the enforcement of these regulations shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such
number of official copies of said book as may be deemed expedient.
(b)Deletions, Substitutions And Amendments:
Sections 390.37 and 383.53 of the "federal motor carrier safety regulations" are hereby deleted and
the following provision is substituted to read as follows:
"(a) The court clerk of Emporia, Kansas, is hereby directed to abstract all convictions of violations
committed by persons holding a commercial driver's license (CDL) to the driver's control bureau of
the department of revenue of the state of Kansas. Any further action to a person's CDL as a result
of the abstracted conviction will be at the discretion of the driver's control bureau in accordance
with state statutes and regulations.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of the "federal motor carrier safety
regulations", parts 383, 385 and 390-397. The judge of the Emporia municipal court may, in the
manner prescribed by K.S.A. 12-4305 or any amendments thereto, establish a schedule of fines
for violations of any section of the "federal motor carrier safety regulations", parts 383, 385 and
390-397, such fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus court costs. Any person who
violates the provisions of the "federal motor carrier safety regulations", parts 383, 385 and 390-
397, shall, upon conviction, be punished as set forth in the schedule of fines. Any person who
violates any provision of the "federal motor carrier safety regulations", parts 383, 385 and 390-397,
for which a fine is not scheduled shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00) plus court costs. Such fines shall be imposed upon a voluntary entry of
appearance and upon a plea of guilty or no contest to a complaint alleging such violation and
payment of the fine and any court costs."
Section 396.9(a) of the "federal motor carrier safety regulations" is hereby deleted and a new section
396.9(a) is substituted to read as follows:
"Section 396.9(a). Personnel Authorized To Perform Inspections. Inspections of motor carriers'
vehicles in operation shall be conducted by commercial vehicle safety alliance (CVSA) certified
officers.
(b) Prescribed Inspection Report. A driver/vehicle examination report shall be used to record
results of motor vehicle inspections conducted by authorized city of Emporia police officers.
(c) Authorized personnel shall declare and mark "Out of Service" any motor vehicle which by
reason of its mechanical condition or loading would likely cause an accident or a breakdown. An
"out of service vehicle" sticker, shall be used to mark vehicles "out of service."
1. No motor carrier shall require or permit any person to operate nor shall any person operate
any motor vehicle declared and marked "Out of Service" until all repairs required by the "out of
service notice" have been satisfactorily completed.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 343/510
2. The term "operate" as used in this section shall include towing the vehicle, except that
vehicles marked "out of service" may be towed away by means of a vehicle using a crane or
hoist. A vehicle combination consisting of the emergency towing vehicle and an "out of
service" vehicle shall not be operated unless such combination meets the performance
requirements of this subchapter except for those conditions noted on the driver equipment
compliance check.
3. No person shall remove the "Out of Service Vehicle" sticker from any motor vehicle prior to
completion of all repairs required by the "out of service notice."
(d) Motor Carrier's Disposition.
1. The driver of any motor vehicle receiving an inspection report shall deliver it to the motor
carrier operating the vehicle upon his arrival at the next terminal or facility. If the driver is not
scheduled to arrive at a terminal or facility of the motor carrier operating the vehicle within 24
hours, the driver shall immediately mail the report to the motor carrier.
2. Motor carriers shall examine the report. Violations or defects noted thereon shall be
corrected.
3. Within 15 days following the date of the inspection, the motor carrier shall:
a. Certify that all violations noted have been corrected by completing the "signature of
carrier official, title, and date signed" portions of the form; and
b. Return the completed roadside inspection form to the issuing agency at the address
indicated on the form and retain a copy at the motor carrier's principal place of business or
where the vehicle is housed for 12 months from the date of inspection."
(Ord. 09-21, § 1, 8-5-2009)
Secs. 25-23-25-35. Reserved:
ARTICLE III. STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING 177
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 25-36. Trucks In Commercial, Industrial, And Residential Districts:
(a) It shall be unlawful to park any semitrailer or truck which is over twenty two feet (22') in length on any
street in a residential district which is not marked as a federal or state highway except delivery
vehicles in the process of loading or unloading.
(b) It shall be unlawful to stop, stand or park any semitrailer without a truck tractor along any street or
alley in the City of Emporia, Kansas.
(Code 1962, § 21-210; Ord. No. 84-46, § 1, 10-3-84)
Sec. 25-37. Vehicles parked over forty-eight (48) hours.
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, or permit the parking, storing or standing of, any vehicle upon
any street, street parking or public way or municipal parking lot in the city for any continuous period of
more than forty-eight (48) hours. Any vehicle which shall have been found to have remained parked,
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 344/510
stored or located upon any of such streets, parkings or ways of the city for a continuous period of more
than forty-eight (48) hours shall be deemed a public nuisance and such nuisance may be abated by
towing or removal upon the order of a police officer.
(Ord. No. 357, § 1, 12-28-67)
Sec. 25-38. Parking during snow removal operations.
(a) Whenever snow has accumulated or there is a possibility that snow will accumulate in the city streets
so that snow removal operations will be required, the city manager may declare an emergency, and
until such emergency is terminated by the city manager no vehicle shall be parked on the streets
designated by ordinance, between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.
(b) Notice of the existence of such an emergency shall be given at least two (2) hours before this
emergency ordinance takes effect by such means as are available through the local press, and radio,
and the placing of appropriate written or printed notices or warnings on the vehicles parked within the
area. The state of emergency shall be terminated by notice given substantially in the same manner
as the state of emergency was invoked.
(Code 1962, § 21-215(a)(b))
Sec. 25-39. Parking in street parkings.
No person shall park a vehicle on the parkings.
(Ord. No. 1004, § 1, 6-18-80)
Sec. 25-40. Private property-Generally.
(a) It shall be unlawful for the driver, operator or owner of any motor vehicle to enter onto, stop, stand or
park a motor vehicle on any posted private property, without having the express or implied consent of
the owner, lessee or person in charge of said private property.
(b) "Posted" shall mean the displaying of a sign, not smaller than twelve (12) inches in height and twelve
(12) inches in width and not larger than twelve (12) inches in height and eighteen (18) inches in width
exposed to the public view and located at some prominent location on said private property bearing
the following information:
"PRIVATE PROPERTY-No parking without consent of owner."
(c) If at any time a vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of subsection (a), the police
department, upon the signed formal complaint of the owner, lessee or person in charge of said
private property on which said vehicle is parked may remove or cause to be removed said vehicle,
keeping it in custody or control until redeemed by the owner thereof, after having paid the cost of
removal and storage.
(d) This section shall not apply to parking on public streets, city-owned off-street parking lots, or other
public parking areas or parking lot areas on private property accessible and available for the public
provided, however, it shall apply to any publicly-owned real property which is utilized by the public for
purposes of vehicular travel and parking with permission of the owner, but not as a matter of right.
(e) Complaints brought under the provisions of this section may be processed through the traffic
violations bureau of the city.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 345/510
(f) Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a Class C
misdemeanor.
(Ord. No. 295, §§ 1-5, 3-1-67; Ord. No. 94-11, § 1, 3-16-94)
Cross reference- Penalty for Class C misdemeanors, § 1-6.
Sec. 25-40.1. Same-Inaccessible areas.
(a) It is unlawful for any person to park, or cause to be parked any vehicle on any private property in the
city without the express or implied consent of the owner or person in possession or control of such
property or for a time period in excess of that for which the consent was given by the owner or
person in possession and control of the property.
(b) If at any time a vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of subsection (a), the police
department, upon the formal complaint of the owner, lessee, or person in charge of said private
property on which said vehicle is parked, may at its discretion, issue a citation to such vehicle for
parking on private property without permission.
(c) Any vehicle parked in violation of this section is hereby deemed a nuisance and preservation of the
public safety and welfare requires that such vehicles be removed without delay. Therefore, any police
officer, acting in his or her official capacity, is hereby authorized, at his or her discretion, to order the
towing or removal of said vehicle, without the permission of the owner or person using the same, to a
public or private garage or yard suitable for the storage of impounded vehicles.
(d) This section shall not apply to parking on public streets, city-owned off-street parking lots or other
public parking areas or parking lot areas on private property accessible and available to the public
provided, however, it shall apply to any publicly-owned real property which is utilized by the public for
purposes of vehicular travel and parking with permission of the owner, but not as a matter of right.
(e) Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not to exceed one
hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned not to exceed thirty (30) days, or be both so fined and
imprisoned.
(Ord. No. 1129, §§ 1-5, 11-17-82; Ord. No. 94-11, § 2, 3-16-94)
Sec. 25-41. Fire Lanes:
(a)It shall be unlawful for the driver, operator, or owner of any motor vehicle to stop, stand or park a
motor vehicle on any property which is clearly marked as being reserved as a fire lane.
(b)Fire lanes shall be a minimum of ten feet (10') in width by sixty feet (60') in length in close proximity,
easily accessible and adjacent to the main entrance of the building which they serve. Said land shall
further run parallel with said building and shall be designated as a fire lane by a sign indicating that
the area is reserved as a fire lane, that no parking is permitted therein, and that violators shall be
subject to tow.
(c)Fire lanes shall be posted by the displaying of a sign twelve inches (12") in height and eighteen
inches (18") in width appropriately displayed and of a height not to be out of the line of vision of a
driver seated in a vehicle, and shall bear the information designated in subsection (b) of this section.
(d)Owners of private property with parking lots accessible and available to the public may establish a fire
lane or fire lanes subject to the provisions of this section by designating a fire lane or fire lanes
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 346/510
pursuant to the guidelines of this section by filing a notice with the city clerk and receiving the
approval of designated representatives of the city.
(e)If at any time a vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the
police department, upon the signed formal complaint of the owner, lessee or person in charge of the
property on which said vehicle is parked, may remove or cause to be removed said vehicle, keeping
it in custody or control until redeemed by the owner thereof, after having paid the costs of removal
and storage.
(f)Complaints brought under the provisions of this section may be processed through the traffic violation
bureau of the city. (Ord. 1046, §§ 1-6, 6-17-1981)
Sec. 25-42. Handicapped Parking Spaces:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any vehicle in a parking space on private
property which is clearly marked as being reserved for the use of handicapped persons or persons
responsible for the transportation of handicapped persons unless such vehicle bears a special
license plate or identification card issued pursuant to KSA 8-161 or 8-132a and is being operated by
or used for the transportation of a handicapped person or disabled veteran, except a parking space
which is clearly marked as being reserved for the use of a specified handicapped person.
(b)Said parking spaces shall be located in close proximity and easily accessible to the use or uses they
serve, and shall be designated as reserved for the disabled by a sign bearing the international
symbol of access appropriately displayed and of a height not to be obscured by a vehicle parked in
the space or be out of the line of vision of a driver seated in a vehicle.
(c)Owners of private property with parking lots accessible and available to the public may establish
reserved spaces subject to the provisions of this section by designating a parking space pursuant to
the guidelines of subsection (b) of this section and by filing a notice with the police department. (Ord.
1042, §§ 1-3, 6-3-1981)
Sec. 25-43. Citations And Violations Generally:
(a)It shall be the duty of authorized personnel of the police department and such other parking
enforcement officers as appointed by the chief of police to report:
(1) The particular parking requirement the vehicle parked is in violation of, and if said violation is
overparking, the number of the parking meter which indicates the vehicle occupying the parking
space adjacent to such parking meter is or has been parking in violation, or the time zone limitation
of the area in which said vehicle is parked.
(2) The state license plate number of such vehicle.
(3) The date and time during which such vehicle is parking in violation.
(4) The fine for the violation of the particular parking requirement as established by the fine schedule
of the city.
(5) Any other facts, knowledge, or information displayed on the vehicle or otherwise available, which
may identify its user or is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending
such violation.
(b)The police officer or parking enforcement officer shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a parking
violation notice containing the above information, notifying the owner or operator thereof that such
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 347/510
vehicle is parked contrary to the requirements for parking and instructing such owner to insert the
designated fine in the courtesy envelope provided with said notice and deposit the envelope in such
special receptacle or receptacles as may be provided for this purpose, affix the proper postage and
mail said envelope and enclosed fine to the traffic violations bureau or pay said fine at the traffic desk
in the municipal building. (Ord. 1043, § 1, 6-3-1981; Ord. 96-17, § 1, 5-15-1996)
Sec. 25-44. Booting, Towing Or Removal Of Vehicle For Nonpayment Of Fine:
If a violator of a parking restriction does not pay the fine or appear at the traffic desk in the municipal
building to contest citation within a period of ten (10) days, the parking fine shall be doubled. The traffic
citation affixed to the vehicle shall provide for a conspicuous warning of the time restriction for contest or
payment and the parking fine shall double after ten (10) days if not paid or contested. Further, that the
vehicle may be rendered inoperable, and/or towed if there is an accumulation of parking fines on the
vehicle in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00), and no other warning shall be necessary. Any
vehicle being rendered inoperable, towed or removed as provided for herein shall be surrendered to the
duly identified owner or person using the same upon the payment of all fines or the signing of a notice to
appear in municipal court, and the payment of the expenses of booting, towing, storage charges, and
any other reasonable charge resulting from said booting, towing or removal. (Ord. 1043, § 2, 6-3-1981;
Ord. 10-30, 11-3-2010)
Secs. 25-45 25-55. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. PARKING METERS
Sec. 25-56. Definitions:
The following words, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Parking Meter Zones : Portions of streets or municipal parking lots described and established by the
governing body as zones within which parking of vehicles shall be controlled, regulated and inspected
with the aid of timing devices or meters, herein referred to as parking meters or meters.
Roadway : That portion of a street between the regularly established curb lines.
Sidewalk : That portion of a street between the curb lines and the adjacent property lines.
Street : Every way set apart for public travel, except alleyways, bridle paths, and footpaths.
Vehicle : A conveyance propelled by motor power. (1962 Code § 21-401)
Sec. 25-57. Installation Of Meters:
Parking meters installed in parking meter zones, as established by the governing body, shall be installed
upon the curb immediately adjacent to the individual parking spaces hereinafter described, and each
parking meter shall be so constructed and adjusted as to show, when properly operated, a signal that
the space adjacent to which it is installed is or is not legally in use. (1962 Code § 21-403)
Sec. 25-58. Spaces:
The city manager shall have lines or markings painted upon the curb or street adjacent to each parking
meter designating the parking space for which said meter is to be used, and each vehicle parked
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 348/510
adjacent to any parking meter shall park within said lines or markings. It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle across any such line or marking, or to park a vehicle in such a position that it shall not be entirely
within the space designated by such lines or markings. (1962 Code § 21-404)
Sec. 25-59. Use Required:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or
operated or controlled by him to be upon any street within a parking meter zone in any space adjacent to
which a parking meter showing a signal indicating that such space is illegally in use, other than such
time as is necessary to operate the meter to show legal parking, between the hours of eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M., Sundays and legal holidays excepted. (1962 Code § 21-405;
Ord. 232, § 1, 11-3-1965; Ord. 96-20, § 1, 6-5-1996)
Sec. 25-60. Rates And Charges:
The coins required to be deposited in a parking meter shall entitle the vehicle owner or depositor to
parking time in accordance with the legend as stated on the parking meter and as established by the
governing body. (1962 Code § 21-406)
Sec. 25-61. Use Of Slugs, Etc.:
It shall be unlawful to deposit or to cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or
substitute for a coin of the United States. (1962 Code § 21-407)
Sec. 25-62. Injuring, Destroying, Etc., Meters:
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to open or for any person to deface, injure, tamper with
or wilfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed pursuant to this division.
(1962 Code § 21-408)
Sec. 25-63. Use Of Funds:
The amount of the coins required to be deposited in parking meters, or payments made in lieu thereof, is
hereby levied and assessed as a fee to provide for the proper regulation, control and inspection of traffic
upon the public streets and municipal parking lots, and to cover the cost of supervising, regulating and
inspecting the parking of vehicles in the parking meter zones, the cost of placing and maintaining lines or
markings, designating parking spaces in parking meter zones, and for the cost of purchasing,
establishing and maintaining parking lots for public parking purposes, the cost of purchase, supervision,
protection, inspection, installation, operation, maintenance, control and use of the parking meters
installed hereunder and the special fund in which such fees shall be placed shall be devoted exclusively
to those purposes. (1962 Code § 21-411)
Sec. 25-64. Division Supplemental:
This division shall be supplementary to all other ordinances. (1962 Code § 21-412)
Secs. 25-65 25-75. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS
Sec. 25-76. Established; Records:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 349/510
All municipal parking lots located within the city shall be established by the governing body by resolution;
a record of said lots shall be kept by the city clerk and available for public inspection at all hours
normally construed as regular business hours. (Ord. 1095, § 1, 4-7-1982)
Sec. 25-77. Hours Of Operation; Use For Commercial Purposes Or Storage:
Except as otherwise provided, all municipal parking lots so established pursuant to this division shall be
open twenty four (24) hours a day for parking purposes; provided it shall be unlawful for any person to
place or cause to be placed any motor vehicle on any municipal parking lot for commercial or storage
purposes. Any vehicle left unattended on a municipal parking lot for a period in excess of twenty four
(24) hours shall be presumed and deemed placed for storage purposes. (Ord. 1095, § 2, 4-7-1982)
Sec. 25-78. Restrictions, Permits, Etc.:
(a) The governing body may, by resolution, establish parking restrictions on any municipal parking lot,
provided, that when establishing such restrictions the governing body may cause and require signs
or markings to be placed in such lot indicating the established parking restrictions.
(b) The city clerk may issue parking permits authorizing the holder to use stalls in municipal parking lots
allowing permit parking without payment of the meter fee; provided:
(1) The permit shall allow the use of metered municipal parking lots by one vehicle only;
(2) A permit shall not be transferable from vehicle to vehicle or holder to holder;
(3) Permits shall be of a fee and duration as established by the governing body; and
(4) No permits shall be issued for parking in metered stalls on public streets.
(c) The governing body may, by resolution, close any municipal parking lot or portion thereof to public
parking when it is determined such closure would be in the best interest of the citizens of the city.
Such resolution shall specify the lot, or portion thereof, to be closed, the time period of closure and
the purpose of such closure. (Ord. 1095, § 3, 4-7-1982; Ord. 1096, § 1, 5-5-1982)
Sec. 25-79. Violations:
Any vehicle parked in violation of a municipal parking lot restriction shall be deemed a public nuisance
and such unoccupied vehicle left parked or standing in violation of the posted municipal parking lot
restrictions shall be subject to tow or removal on the order of any police officer, without permission of the
owner or person using the same, to a public or private garage or yard suitable for the storage thereof.
Any vehicle being towed or removed as provided for herein shall be surrendered to the duly identified
owner or person using the same upon payment of fine or the signing of a notice to appear in municipal
court and the payment of expenses of towing, storage charges, and any other reasonable charge
resulting from said towing or removal. (Ord. 1095, § 4, 4-7-1982)
Sec. 25-80. Suspension Of Timed Parking:
(a)The governing body designates the city manager of Emporia, Kansas, as the public official
responsible to exercise discretion to suspend timed public parking at meters and in public parking
lots at any time or place within the city limits of the city of Emporia when it is in the public interest in
order to accommodate visitors to parades, festivals, sports events, street events or any special
events. Suspension of timed parking also includes periodic closure of public parking in order to
accommodate one event, or a series of events.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 350/510
(b)The timing of the suspension will be such as to reasonably accommodate the event. Any request for
suspension of timed parking shall be received in the city manager's office at least fifteen (15) days
prior to the event. If the request is granted, a parking order shall be issued which shall state the
nature of the event, the geographic location of the affected parking, and the duration of the
suspension of timed parking.
(c)Such parking order shall be provided to the chief of police and shall be published once in the
"Emporia Gazette" at least seven (7) days prior to the beginning of the event. (Ord. 10-04, § 1, 3-17-
2010; Ord. 10-09, § 1, 4-21-2010)

DIVISION 4. DOWNTOWN DISTRICT

ARTICLE IV. BICYCLES 178
Sec. 25-91. Reserved:
Sec. 25-92. Operation Generally:
No bicycle shall be operated upon the streets of the city unless the bicycle is in good mechanical
condition, and shall not be operated in a careless or unsafe manner. (1962 Code, § 21-503)
Sec. 25-93. Parking:
(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, bicycles shall not be parked upon any public
sidewalk at any time. Bicycles shall not be parked on public streets in such a manner as to interfere
with the normal operation of motor vehicles.
(b) Bicycles may be parked in approved racks upon the public streets or sidewalks, but only after said
racks and their location are approved by the chief of police. Any person who places or permits a
bicycle rack upon any street or sidewalk without first securing the approval of the chief of police shall
be in violation of this article. The chief of police may designate such public areas in which bicycles
can be parked. (1962 Code, §§ 21-504, 21-505)
Sec. 25-94. Riding On Sidewalks; Skateboards:
(a) No person shall rollerskate or ride in or by means of a skateboard, bicycle, coaster, toy vehicle or
other similar device upon any sidewalk in the central business district, provided, however, that this
section shall not apply to a law enforcement officer engaged in the performance of his or her official
duties.
(b) It is unlawful within the city for any person upon a skateboard, scooter, or other similar wheeled
device:
(1) To go upon any street or highway in the city except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and
when so crossing such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the
duties applicable to pedestrians.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 351/510
(2) To go upon any property, whether publicly or privately owned, within the central business district.
(3) To go upon any city owned parking lot or grounds, other than a designated skateboard park.
(4) To go upon any other parking lot or property within the city when such property is clearly and
visibly marked by a sign or signs indicating that skateboard, scooter or other similar wheeled device
use is prohibited therein. Such signs shall have lettering of at least one and one-half inches (1 1/2")
high and one-half inch (1/2") wide. When such signs are present upon privately owned property, the
police department shall be authorized thereby to enforce the provisions of this section.
(5) To coast or otherwise move upon a skateboard, scooter or other similar wheeled device in a
reckless manner on any public sidewalk within the city, or without exercising due care for the safety
of others using the sidewalks, or to otherwise endanger or interfere with pedestrian traffic.
(c) Violation of any of the provisions of this section is punishable by a fine of up to one hundred dollars
($100.00) and up to forty (40) hours of community service.
(d) In addition to any other penalty imposed, any skateboard, scooter or other similar wheeled device
may be seized by the police department in connection with said violation and may be released to the
owner upon the payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00) impoundment fee. (1962 Code, § 21-506;
Ord. 89-4, § 1, 2-1-1989; Ord. 94-54, § 1, 12-21-1994; Ord. 01-39, § 1, 10-17-2001)
ARTICLE V. TRAFFIC SAFETY COMMITTEE
Sec. 25-95. Established:
A traffic safety committee is hereby created for the purpose of establishing and regulating the
placement, removal, or adjustments in routine traffic and parking matters. The committee shall also be
available to provide review and recommendation to the governing body on traffic matters of a nonroutine
nature. The traffic safety committee shall consist of the city manager, who shall serve as chair, fire chief,
police chief and city engineer, or their designees. The committee shall establish a regular meeting time
at least monthly and a majority of the committee must be present to constitute an official meeting and to
conduct business. Any action shall be by a majority vote of the entire committee. (Ord. 87-12, § 1, 5-20-
1987; Ord. 10-03, § 1, 2-3-2010)
Sec. 25-96. Delegation Of Authority:
(a)The traffic committee shall have authority to consider and establish routine traffic and parking
regulations. Routine traffic and parking regulations shall be deemed to consist of:
(1) The removal or placement of warning, informational, and regulatory signs.
(2) The designation of school crossing zones and crosswalks.
(3) Signalization sequence of existing traffic control signals.
(4) Designation, establishment or adjustment of speed limitations.
(5) The designation of the time sequence of parking meters.
(6) The designation of emergency traffic routes.
(b)Any item of a traffic or parking nature not meeting the definition of "routine" as established in this
section shall be deemed a nonroutine traffic or parking item and shall be considered in accordance
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 352/510
with section 25-97 of this chapter. (Ord. 87-12, § 1, 5-20-1987)
Sec. 25-97. Nonroutine Traffic And Parking Matters:
Traffic and parking matters of a nonroutine nature shall be referred upon the discretion of the governing
body to the traffic committee for consideration and recommendation to the governing body. All
recommendations to the governing body shall be in writing and shall contain the basis for the
conclusions reached by the traffic committee. Final action on such matters shall be taken only by the
governing body. (Ord. 87-12, § 1, 5-20-1987)
Sec. 25-98. Procedure:
The traffic safety committee shall consider any request for the placement, removal or adjustment of a
routine traffic or parking matter made to the city or may institute consideration of such routine matters
upon their own motion. All such requests shall be forwarded to the chair of the committee, who shall
place consideration of the request on the agenda of the next scheduled meeting of the committee.
Applicants shall be notified of the date of the committee meeting. If the committee determines an
application has merit, it shall forward a recommendation to the governing body. The governing body
shall consider the recommendation at a regularly scheduled study session. If the governing body
determines that the application has merit, it shall return the application to the traffic safety committee for
a public hearing. The traffic safety committee shall hold the public hearing at their next regularly
scheduled meeting more than thirty (30) days following the determination of the governing body that the
application has merit. Notice of the date, time and location of the public hearing shall be published not
less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days before the date of the public hearing in the
official city newspaper. The applicant shall be notified by regular mail not less than fifteen (15) days
before the date of the hearing. All property owners within one block of the application site, or other
distance as the chair considers appropriate, shall be notified by regular mail not less than fifteen (15)
days before the date of the hearing. The applicant and all interested parties shall be permitted to testify
at the public hearing, subject to the rules set forth by the chair. Following the close of the public hearing,
the committee shall make a final determination regarding routine applications as described in this article.
The committee shall make a recommendation to the governing body for all nonroutine applications as
described in this article. The decision of the committee for routine applications and the governing body
for nonroutine applications shall be final. (Ord. 87-12, § 1, 5-20-1987; Ord. 10-03, § 2, 2-3-2010)
Sec. 25-99. Appeal To Governing Body:
A decision of a routine application by the traffic safety committee may be appealed to the governing
body by a person making the request or anyone aggrieved by the determination. The appellant shall
provide in writing to the chair of the committee the basis for their appeal. The governing body shall
consider the appeal at a study session not more than sixty (60) days after the appeal has been filed with
the chair of the committee. The governing body shall make a determination whether to approve or deny
the appeal not more than thirty (30) days following the close of the appeal hearing. The governing body
may also return the appeal to the committee for reconsideration at the committee's next regularly
scheduled meeting. The committee shall forward a recommendation to the governing body. The decision
of the governing body shall be final. The determination of the committee shall not be implemented
pending any action of the governing body. (Ord. 87-12, § 1, 5-20-1987; Ord. 10-03, § 3, 2-3-2010)
Sec. 25-100. Emergency Signage:
Emergency regulatory and warning signs may be installed as directed by the traffic safety committee as
the committee determines is necessary to promote the public health, safety and welfare. Such signage
shall be effective until such time as the committee and governing body has made a final determination
on the emergency signage as set forth herein. (Ord. 87-12, § 1, 5-20-1987; Ord. 10-03, § 4, 2-3-2010)
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 353/510
Chapter 26
TREES AND SHRUBS 179
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 26-1. Maintenance of public property.
Property owners shall be responsible for the maintenance of all trees, shrubs and plants in the public
right-of-ways adjacent to their properties.
Sec. 26-2. Protection during building operations.
Any person carrying on any building operation or other work near enough to any tree or shrub within the
parking, alley, street, park or public grounds to injure such tree or shrub shall place barricades or guards
about all such sufficient to protect them from all injury.
(Code 1962, § 22-102)
Sec. 26-3. Protection from utility wires.
It shall be the duty of any person owning or controlling or having charge of wires or other conductors of
electricity, when said wires pass through or near trees within the streets or parks of the city, to cause
such wires to be temporarily removed or the electricity in such wires to be shut off when it is necessary
in order to remove, prune, trim or treat any such tree or trees. When it shall become necessary to cut off
the electricity or remove the wires, the city, through its duly authorized agent, shall give the owners or
person in control of such electrical wires or transmission agents, a notice of such necessity and it shall
be the duty of the owners or parties controlling such wires within forty-eight (48) hours from the time of
such notice to cause the wires to be temporarily removed or the electricity to be cut off therefrom a
sufficient length of time to trim or treat such trees.
(Code 1962, § 22-104)
Sec. 26-4. Diseased or infected trees or shrubs.
(a) Whenever any competent city authority, or competent state or federal authority when requested by
the governing body, shall file with the governing body a written statement based upon a laboratory
test or other supporting evidence that trees or tree materials or shrubs located upon private property
within the city are infected or infested with or harbor any tree or plant disease or insect pest or larvae,
the uncontrolled presence of which may constitute a hazard to, or result in the damage or destruction
of, other trees or shrubs in the community, describing the same and where located, the governing
body shall direct the city clerk to forthwith issue notice requiring the owner or agent of the owner of
the premises to treat or remove any such designated tree, tree material or shrub within a time
specified in such notice; said notice shall be served by the chief of police or other police officer, by
delivering a copy thereof to the owner, or agent of such property or if the same be unoccupied and
the owner a nonresident, then the city clerk shall notify the owner by mailing a notice to the owner's
last known address by registered or certified mail.
(b) If the owner or agent shall fail to comply with the requirements of said notice within the time specified
in the notice, then the city shall proceed to have the designated tree, tree material or shrub treated or
removed and report the cost thereof to the city clerk, and the cost of such treatment or removal shall
be paid by the owner of the property or shall be assessed and charged against the lot or parcel of
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 354/510
ground on which the tree, tree material or shrub was located. The city clerk shall, at the time of
certifying other city taxes to the county clerk, certify the unpaid costs and the county clerk shall
extend the same on the tax roll of the county against said lot or parcel of ground.
(Code 1962, § 22-105)
State law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-3204.
Secs. 26-5-26-14. Reserved.
