Chapter 27
VEHICLES FOR HIRE 181
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 27-1-27-15. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. TAXICABS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 27-16. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Taxicab shall mean any vehicle used for the carriage of persons for hire within the city and not operated
over fixed routes and scheduled time. Each taxicab is hereby declared to be a common carrier of
persons.
Taxicab driver shall mean any person licensed to drive a taxicab.
Taxicab station shall mean an office within the commercial zone of the city maintained as a headquarters
from which one or more taxicabs operate both day and night and having a telephone and an attendant
continuously on duty to answer the telephone, receive and communicate calls for taxicab service and
keep records pertaining thereto.
(Code 1962, § 11-601; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-17. Vehicle inspection and display of licenses, lights, etc.
(a) No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a duly issued state license; no such taxicab shall be
operated unless it is equipped with the proper brakes, lights, tires, horns, muffler, rear vision mirror
and windshield wipers in good condition. The chief of police may inspect every taxicab so often as
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 355/510
may be necessary, to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this section. Should the chief of
police upon inspection find that such vehicle is not in proper mechanical condition, he shall issue a
report to the city clerk who upon receipt of such report shall suspend the operation of such vehicle's
license until such defect is rectified and shall issue a written notice of said suspension to the
applicant; provided, that said applicant shall have a right of appeal to the governing body from said
suspension, however, said suspension shall continue to operate during the pendency of the appeal.
(b) Each vehicle, while operated, shall have the license which has been issued in accordance with the
article conspicuously displayed inside the taxicab, in such a manner as to be entirely visible from the
rear seat of the taxicab. Each taxicab shall have painted or affixed in letters of a contrasting color, not
less than three (3) inches high on each front door and on the rear of the body the word "taxicab",
"taxi" or "cab", the license number, and the number assigned, if required. Each taxicab shall be
equipped with a small lamp, mounted on the top front portion of the taxicab, displaying a white light
which shall have the word "taxi" or "taxicab" clearly visible from the front. Said lamp shall be mounted
high enough from the top of the taxicab to be clearly visible from both the front and rear of the
taxicab. In addition, the name of the taxicab station under which the vehicle is operated must be
permanently displayed upon both sides of each taxicab, said letters to be at least two (2) inches in
height to be painted or affixed to each door. If more than one cab is operated by a taxicab station
licensee, each taxicab shall be designated by a different number, which number shall be indicated on
the vehicle as previously required.
(Code 1962, § 11-607; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-18. Requirements for taxicab stations.
Each taxicab station must maintain at least one taxicab in readiness for service at all times, have a
telephone and attendant continuously on duty to answer the telephone, receive and communicate calls
from taxicab service and keep appropriate records pertaining thereto. The telephone number of the
taxicab station must be listed in a local telephone directory under the name of such taxicab station.
(Code 1962, § 11-608; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-19. Passengers.
(a) No taxicab shall stop or take on or discharge passengers at street intersections, and must leave the
crosswalks unobstructed; such a vehicle shall pull to the curb to make all such stops and must not
receive or discharge passengers while in motion; such a vehicle shall stand no longer time than is
necessary to take on or discharge passengers, except when standing at its regular stand.
(b) The front seat of any taxicab shall not carry more than one passenger in addition to the driver nor
shall such vehicle carry more persons than its rated seated capacity.
(c) It shall be the duty of the driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any person who so seeks to
use the taxicab, provided such person is not intoxicated, and conducts himself in an orderly manner.
No person shall be admitted to a taxicab occupied by a passenger without the consent of that
passenger.
(d) The driver shall take his passenger to his destination by the most direct available route from the
place where the passenger enters the taxicab.
(Code 1962, § 11-611; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-20. Traffic rules.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 356/510
It shall be the duty of every driver of a taxicab to obey all traffic rules established by statute or ordinance.
(Code 1962, § 11-612; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-21. Use to perpetrate crimes.
It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in the perpetration of a crime.
(Code 1962, § 11-613; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-22. Rates and charges.
Taxicab rates shall be set at the discretion of the owner of licensed taxicab stations within the city,
subject to the following conditions:
(1) All rates shall be posted in plain view in the office of the city clerk in a location designated by the
city clerk. All rates shall be posted in plain view in each and every taxicab operated by each
individually licensed company.
(2) Any changes or amendments to the taxicab rates shall be posted in plain view in the office of the
city clerk in a location designated by said city clerk, and acknowledged by the city clerk. Any changes
or amendments to the taxicab rates shall be posted in plain view in each and every taxicab operated
by each licensed taxicab station; both of said postings shall be posted for thirty (30) days prior to
implementation of the new rates.
(3) The posted rate shall include all charges for all services to be provided, including but not limited
to, the rate for a single passenger, an additional passenger, package delivery, and waiting time.
(4) The size of the notice of proposed rate change shall be as follows:
a. For posting in the office of the city clerk, at least eight and one-half (8 1/2) inches by eleven (11)
inches.
b. For posting in the taxicabs, at least four (4) inches by six (6) inches.
(5) The posting of a proposed rate charge shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
a. The present taxicab rate;
b. The proposed taxicab rate;
c. The date posted;
d. The date effective;
e. The taxicab station's owner's or authorized representative's signature;
f. The city clerk's signature.
(Code 1962, § 11-614; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-23. Packages.
The owner of a licensed taxicab station or a driver of a taxicab within the city shall have the right to
refuse to deliver or accept for delivery any package which shall exceed the weight of fifty (50) pounds or
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 357/510
which because of its size may not be completely enclosed within the truck compartment of the taxicab or
be safely transported within the passenger compartment of the taxicab.
(Code 1962, § 11-615; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-24. Records.
It shall be the duty of everyone operating a motor vehicle under this article to keep a written record of the
in and out calls of each driver, giving the time and place of each call, which record shall be preserved,
and at all times open to the inspection of any officer of the city.
(Code 1962, § 11-610; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-25. Rules and regulations.
The city manager is hereby authorized to make and publish rules and regulations to govern the use of
the streets and alleys of the city by the licensees herein, and to designate the places where they stand
and to regulate the rates of fare charged for use of said vehicles.
(Code 1962, § 11-609; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-26. Civil liability.
Nothing in this article shall be construed as relieving or lessening the liability of any person, firm or
corporation conducting operations under the provisions of this article for damages to any property or any
person, nor shall the city be held as assuming any liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein,
licenses issued pursuant to the provisions hereof, or for failure to provide the services herein described.
(Ord. No. 1088, § 3, 3-3-82)
Sec. 27-27. Penalty.
The owner of any taxicab, the owner of any licensed taxicab station, any licensee or any person violating
any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor.
(Code 1962, § 11-618; Ord. No. 1088, § 1, 3-3-82)
Cross reference- Penalty for Class C misdemeanor, § 1-6.
Secs. 27-28-27-35. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 27-36. Required 182:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating a taxicab, taxicab station, or driving any
taxicab without first having secured a license therefor. No person shall operate or be licensed to operate
a taxicab or be granted a taxicab driver's license without then holding a taxicab station license or being
associated with and operating under the written consent of another who then holds such license;
provided, that a license may be issued for special hauling without the licensee being associated with a
taxicab station, if said licensee does only special hauling and does not hold himself out as a public
carrier. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any vehicle to allow such vehicle to be used as a taxicab
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 358/510
unless such vehicle is registered with the city clerk and a license secured therefor. (1962 Code § 11-602;
Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982)
Sec. 27-37. Application And Investigation:
(a)Any person desiring a license required by this article shall make application therefor in writing to the
city clerk and accompany the application with the required fee for each taxicab station and taxicab
driver. The application shall be verified and be upon a form prepared by the city clerk.
(b)Any person desiring to obtain a taxicab station license or renewal shall apply in writing to the city clerk
stating:
(1) The applicant's name; and if a corporation, the names of all stockholders and officers; and if a
partnership, the names of all general partners;
(2) The name under which the station will be operated;
(3) The location of the station;
(4) The telephone number of the station;
(5) The number of taxicabs to be operated; and
(6) The name of each taxicab driver operating from the station.
(c)Any person desiring a taxicab driver's license shall apply in writing to the city clerk stating:
(1) His name;
(2) His age;
(3) His occupation;
(4) His residence;
(5) His experience and qualifications to operate a motor vehicle;
(6) The class C license number issued him by the state;
(7) A statement that the applicant is able to effectively communicate in the English language;
(8) A statement that the applicant has not within two (2) years immediately preceding the date of
making application been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude, or been
convicted of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or reckless
driving; and
(9) The name of the taxicab station licensee under which he expects to operate, accompanied by the
written consent, approval and recommendation of said taxicab station licensee.
(d)Each application for either a taxicab station license or a taxicab driver's license shall be referred to
the chief of police for investigation, report and recommendation to the city clerk. (1962 Code § 11-
604; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982; Ord. 90-11, § 1, 5-16-1990)
Sec. 27-38. Registration Of Vehicles; Insurance 2:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 359/510
Any holder of a taxicab station license or a taxicab driver's license desiring to use any vehicle as a
taxicab shall file with the city clerk a written application for the registration of such vehicle. The
application shall state the make, type, motor number, serial number, license tag number, the name of the
owner of such vehicle, the name of the taxicab station licensee under whose license such vehicle is to
be operated, and a statement that the vehicle is in good mechanical condition. The applicant, upon
making such application, shall also file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance, issued by an
insurance company authorized by the insurance department of the state to write such insurance,
providing public liability insurance, including passengers in such taxicab, in an amount not less than that
required by the statutes of the state. Each insurer shall agree (by either endorsement on the policy or
separate instrument) to provide at least ten (10) days' written notice to the city of any cancellation or
alteration. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the city clerk upon receiving the information
contained in this section and the appropriate fee, shall issue a license for the operation of said vehicle.
(1962 Code § 11-606; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982)
Sec. 27-39. Issuance And Issuance Standards Taxi Drivers' Licenses:
(a)If the application as set out in subsection 27-37(c) of this chapter is in proper form and accompanied
by cash in the amount of the license fee, the city clerk shall, if the applicant is qualified as provided
by law, authorize the issuance of a license to the applicant.
(b)No license shall be issued to:
(1) Any person who does not hold a valid class C driver's license issued under the laws of the state
at the time of the application for a taxicab driver's license;
(2) A person who is not able to effectively communicate in the English language;
(3) A person whose character or habits make them unfit to transport the public;
(4) A person who within two (2) years immediately preceding the date of making application has been
convicted of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or convicted of
reckless driving;
(5) A person who habitually violates the traffic ordinances and laws of the city or the state.
(6) Registered sex offenders or a person previously convicted of a sex offense, or a person awaiting
trial on a sex offense.
(c)In the event the city clerk does not receive the report and recommendation of the chief of police within
ten (10) business days of the application for a taxi driver's license, the city clerk shall issue to the
applicant a temporary taxi driver's license if the application as set out in subsection 27-37(c) of this
chapter is in proper form and accompanied by cash in the amount of the license fee. Such temporary
license shall be valid for the purpose of authorizing a person to operate a taxicab pursuant to section
27-36 of this chapter for a period of sixty (60) days or until notice from the city clerk that she has
received the report and recommendation of the chief of police and has either denied or granted a taxi
driver's license, whichever date occurs first. If no complaints have been received regarding the
applicant, the city clerk may extend the temporary license for a period not to exceed an additional
sixty (60) days. Such extension shall expire upon the expiration of the time frame specified for such
extension or notice by the city clerk of the grant or denial of the taxi driver's license. Upon expiration
of the temporary license (including any extension thereof) as provided herein, such license shall be
deemed null and void and have no further force and effect without further action by the city. In the
event the temporary license expires by virtue of a notice of denial of the issuance of a taxi driver's
license by the city clerk, the applicant may appeal such denial pursuant to the provisions of
subsection (d) of this section.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 360/510
(d)Any applicant for a taxicab driver's license which is denied by the city clerk may appeal such denial to
the governing body by filing within ten (10) calendar days after such denial a notice of appeal with the
city clerk. Thereupon, the city clerk shall place the application on the agenda of the next meeting of
the governing body.
(e)Notwithstanding any of the preceding, when passing upon an application, the governing body shall
give consideration not only to the applicant's qualifications but also the protection of the public and
the need for additional taxicab drivers. No more licenses shall be granted than the governing body,
after due consideration, deems to be justified by the public need. Applications from persons then
holding a license under this article shall be given first consideration, but after such licenses have
expired, all applications shall be considered in the order in which filed with the city clerk. All
applications on file for more than seven (7) months shall be deemed withdrawn and shall not
thereafter be considered. (1962 Code §§ 11-603, 11-605; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982; Ord. 84-2, § 1, 1-
18-1984; Ord. 90-11, § 2, 5-16-1990; Ord. 97-2, § 1, 2-5-1997; Ord. 14-08, 4-2-2014)
Sec. 27-39.1. Issuance And Issuance Standards Taxi Station:
(a)If the application as set out in subsection 27-37(b) of this chapter is in proper form and accompanied
by cash in the amount of the license fee, the city clerk shall, if the applicant is qualified as provided
by law, authorize the issuance of a license to the applicant.
(b)No license shall be issued to:
(1) A copartnership, unless all members of such partnership shall otherwise be qualified to obtain a
license;
(2) A corporation, if any manager, officer or director thereof or any stockholder owning any aggregate
more than twenty five percent (25%) of the stock of such corporation, would be ineligible to receive a
license hereunder;
(3) A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or
agent possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee;
(4) A person who within two (2) years immediately preceding the date of making application has been
convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude.
(c)Any licensee for a taxicab station license which is denied by the city clerk may appeal such denial to
the governing body by filing within ten (10) calendar days after such denial a notice of appeal with the
city clerk. Thereupon, the city clerk shall place the application on the agenda for the next meeting of
the governing body.
(d)Notwithstanding any of the preceding, when passing upon an application, the governing body shall
give consideration not only to the applicant's qualifications but also the protection of the public and
the need for additional taxicab stations. No more licenses shall be granted than the governing body,
after due consideration, deems to be justified by the public need. Applications from persons then
holding a license under this article shall be given first consideration; but after such licenses have
expired, all applications on file for more than seven (7) months shall be deemed withdrawn and shall
not thereafter be considered. (Ord. 84-2, § 1, 1-18-1984; Ord. 90-11, § 3, 5-16-1990)
Sec. 27-40. Appeal From Denial Of Taxicab Driver's License KSA § 8-235(b).3:
Any license for a taxicab driver which is denied upon the basis of said driver's character and habits may
appeal such denial to the district court by filing within ten (10) days after such denial, a notice of appeal
with the clerk of the district court and by filing a copy of such notice with the city clerk. Thereupon, the
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 361/510
city clerk shall certify a copy of such decision of the governing body to the clerk of the district court.
(1962 Code § 11-616; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982; Ord. 84-2, § 1, 1-18-1984)
Sec. 27-40.1. Appeal From Denial Of Taxicab Station License:
Any license for a taxicab station which is denied upon the basis of said owner's character and habits
may appeal such denial to the District Court by filing within ten (10) days after such denial, a notice of
appeal with the clerk of the District Court and by filing a copy of such notice with the City Clerk.
Thereupon, the City Clerk shall certify a copy of such decision of the Governing Body to the clerk of the
District Court. (Ord. 84-2, § 1, 1-18-1984)
Sec. 27-41. Fee:
For the purpose of regulation, there is hereby levied an annual license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for
each taxicab station, ten dollars ($10.00) for each vehicle used as a taxicab, and five dollars ($5.00) for
each taxicab driver. No refund of such a fee shall be made for any unused period of a license. All license
fees shall be paid to the City Clerk. (1962 Code, § 11-603; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982)
Sec. 27-42. Transfer Or Assignment:
No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this Article shall be assignable or transferable. (1962
Code, § 11-603; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982)
Sec. 27-43. Term:
All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this Article shall expire on December 31 next following
their issuance. (1962 Code, § 11-603; Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982)
Sec. 27-44. Suspension Or Revocation:
(a) The Governing Body may revoke or suspend a license issued pursuant to this Article for any of the
following reasons:
(1) Filing a false or misleading application;
(2) Permitting the licensed vehicle to be used for unlawful purposes;
(3) Nonpayment of any license fee;
(4) Being convicted of a felony, any crime involving moral turpitude or good character of the holder of
any license, driving while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or reckless driving;
(5) Violating any of the provisions of this Article or any other ordinance of the City or any law of the
State;
(6) Habitually violating the traffic laws of the State or of this City;
(7) In the case of a taxicab station licensee, for the licensee recommending a taxicab driver when he
knew, or should have known, said driver did not meet the requirements and qualifications of this
Article;
(8) Undesirable business practices or improper conduct of employees;
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 362/510
(9) For refusal to accept passengers;
(10) In the case of a taxicab driver's license for such driver, while on duty, drinking any intoxicating
liquor, or using any profane or obscene language, shouting or calling to prospective passengers or
disturbing the peace in any way.
(b) Prior to any revocation or suspension, the Governing Body, upon at least five (5) days' written notice,
shall conduct a hearing and decide whether to revoke or suspend such license. Said hearing may be
continued from time to time to obtain witnesses or to gather any information necessary by the
Governing Body. In the case of the revocation of the license, no new license shall be issued to such
person or any person acting for or on his behalf for a period of six (6) months. In the case of either
revocation or suspension of license, no refund of any license fee shall be had. (1962 Code, § 11-617;
Ord. 1088, § 1, 3-3-1982)
DIVISION 3. LIMOUSINE SERVICE
Sec. 27-45. Definition:
Limousine Service : A public passenger motor vehicle with driver furnished, for hire for exclusive use at
scheduled times at a charge fixed in advance. (Ord. 90-5, § 1, 2-21-1990)
Sec. 27-46. Requirements For Limousine Service Operators:
All provisions of Article II, Divisions 1 and 2 of Chapter 27 of this Code are to be complied with by
limousine service operators as though fully set forth in this Division with applicable substitution of terms.
Provided, that the following provisions shall not apply to limousine service operators:
(1) That portion of subsection 27-17(b) of this Article as follows: "Each taxicab shall have painted or
affixed in letters of a contrasting color, not less than three inches (3") high on each front door and on
the rear of the body the word 'taxicab', 'taxi' or 'cab', the license number and the number assigned, if
required. Each taxicab shall be equipped with a small lamp, mounted on the top front portion of the
taxicab, displaying a white light which shall have the word 'taxi' or 'taxicab' clearly visible from the
front. Said lamp shall be mounted high enough from the top of the taxicab to be clearly visible from
both the front and rear of the taxicab. In addition, the name of the taxicab station under which the
vehicle is operated must be permanently displayed upon both sides of each taxicab, said letters to be
at least two inches (2") in height to be painted or affixed to each door. If more than one cab is
operated by a taxicab station licensee, each taxicab shall be designated by a different number, which
number shall be indicated on the vehicle as previously required";
(2) Section 27-18 of this Article; and
(3) Subsections 27-22(1), (2) and (4)(b) of this Article. (Ord. 90-5, § 1, 2-21-1990)
Chapter 28
WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 185
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 28-1-28-15. Reserved.

ARTICLE II. MUNICIPAL WATERWORKS 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 28-16. Rates, Rules, Etc., Part Of Water Service Contract; Termination Of
Service For Violations:
The rates, rules and regulations relating to the waterworks system promulgated by the city shall be
considered a part of the contract with every person supplied with water by and through the waterworks
system, either within or without the corporate limits of the city. Each person shall be bound thereby, and
in case of violation of any rules or regulations in force, the water may be cut off from the premises or
place of violation and not turned on again except by an order of the water superintendent after
satisfactory assurance that there shall be no further cause for violation. (1962 Code, § 23-102)
Sec. 28-17. Unauthorized Use:
It shall be unlawful for any person to take or use water from the waterworks of the city without notice to
the city and without paying for the same as provided by this article. (1962 Code, § 23-111)
Sec. 28-18. Application For Water Service:
Any person making proper application and complying with such requirements shall be supplied with
water by the city provided his property adjoins a water main or distributing line. All applications for water
must be made to the city clerk by the owner or agent of the property to be supplied. (1962 Code, § 23-
103)
Sec. 28-19. Refusal Of Service:
Water service may be refused or discontinued by the city to any customer whose plumbing is not
installed or reconstructed in accordance with the plumbing code of the city. (1962 Code, § 23-113)
Sec. 28-20. Taps:
The city shall tap all water mains or distributing pipes, inserting a corporation cock for the connection to
the service pipe. (1962 Code, § 23-104)
Sec. 28-21. Service Lines:
(a)Generally: All consumers shall keep their own water fixtures, service pipes and curb cocks in good
repair and protected from frost at their own risk and expense, and shall prevent all unnecessary
waste of water, keeping all fixtures closed when not in use. It is expressly stipulated that no claim
shall be made against the city because of any break in the service or any damage arising from
cutting off water to repair mains, make connections, or for any other purpose that becomes
necessary; the right is hereby reserved to cut off water at any time without notice when necessity
compels.
(b)City Maintenance: The city shall maintain the water service line from the main to the meter, except
when the meter is located on private property, then the city shall maintain the service line from the
main to the property line.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 364/510
(c)New Services: New water services, enlargements or relocations of water service lines shall be at the
expense of the customer. The water utility shall install the corporation cock, service pipe, and curb
cock at the closest point from the main to the property requesting service. Fees for services provided
will be assessed on the basis of actual cost for labor and materials based on the city's established
fee schedule. A service line shall not be extended beyond one hundred feet (100') without the
approval of the governing body.
(d)Service Replacement: When an existing service line from the main to the meter or property line,
whichever comes first, reaches a point when repair is not feasible, the city shall replace the line at
the expense of the water utility.
(e)Rules And Regulations: The city manager, with the approval of the governing body, shall from time to
time adopt and promulgate rules and regulations necessary for the operation of the utility consistent
with this code. (1962 Code, § 23-106; Ord. 88-10, § 1, 3-16-1988)
Sec. 28-22. Meters:
(a)All water sold by the city shall be measured by meter. All meters shall be furnished by the city and
installed without cost to the consumer. The meters shall be located adjacent to the curb cock where
practicable and otherwise at such point as the superintendent of waterworks shall direct. The owner
shall leave a gap in the service line of proper size to accommodate the meter and connections
furnished by the city and shall leave sufficient room about the meter for the installation of a meter
box, where the meter is placed outside of the buildings.
(b)No person shall injure, molest or in any way interfere with any water meter, meter box or cover or
anything appertaining thereto, and no persons shall deposit dirt, stone or rubbish of any nature in any
meter or meter box or service box. The occupant of any building or premises where a meter is
located shall keep the meter free from all obstructions so that it is at all times conveniently accessible
for reading, inspecting or repairing. Subject to constitutional limitations, the water superintendent or
persons authorized by him may enter, at any reasonable hour, premises supplied with water in order
to inspect or repair meters, pipes or fixtures, or to investigate the use of water.
(c)Where a meter is located inside any building or in such other place or manner that the city cannot use
customary methods for its protection against freezing or other injury, the owner of the property in
which such meter is placed shall be responsible for its protection and any damages sustained by
such meter shall be chargeable to the property served in the same manner as prescribed for repairs
to service lines.
(d)Whether a meter is located in a building, an approved meter box or housing in the parking or sidewalk
or elsewhere, the consumer or owner of the property in which such meter is placed shall be
responsible for its protection and preservation, and any damage sustained by such meter shall be
charged to the consumer or owner of the property served and the same shall be collectible in the
same manner as monthly water bills.
(e)In case any meter fails to register for any cause, the amount charged for water during such period
shall be estimated by the superintendent of waterworks, such estimate to be based on the average
amount registered during like preceding period.
(f)If any meter is found to vary in excess of two percent (2%) from one hundred percent (100%)
accuracy, the reading of the meter shall be corrected according to the percentage of inaccuracy
found, but no correction shall extend beyond the date of the last regular monthly reading. A meter
with this level of inaccuracy shall also be immediately repaired or replaced with an accurate meter.
The water utility shall test any meter on request; and, if any meter tested is inaccurate in excess of
two percent (2%), the unit will be corrected; and, if any meter tested is found to vary less than two
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 365/510
percent (2%), the meter shall be replaced and a fee not to exceed the actual cost to the city for
shipping and testing shall be made on the next water bill. (1962 Code, § 23-107; Ord. 88-10, § 2, 3-
16-1988; Ord. 07-19, § 1, 8-1-2007)
Sec. 28-23. Service Pipes:
(a)On streets where paving is ordered, all existing water service pipes of other than type "K" copper shall
be replaced at the expense of the property owner. When service pipes are run only to the curb cock
for future use, the end of the pipe must be securely tapped or plugged and a curb cock and service
box installed.
(b)All new connections and all repairs to existing connections from the city water main to the water meter
shall be type "K" copper or brass pipe not less than three-fourths inch (3/4") in internal diameter, or
cast iron not less than two inches (2") in internal diameter. A curb cock shall be located in the meter
tile on the main side of the meter for services up to two inches (2") in size. Larger services shall have
a shutoff valve installed which meets the specifications of the American Water Works Association
and is approved by the director of public works. (1962 Code, § 23-107; Ord. 87-31, § 1, 10-7-1987)
Sec. 28-24. Use Restrictions:
Except as specifically permitted, water customers shall not allow water to be taken from the premises.
Water shall be used only on the premises to which the service is extended, and no more than one
consumer shall receive water through a single meter, except by special written permission of the
superintendent of waterworks. (1962 Code, § 23-108)
Sec. 28-25. Tampering With Valves, Etc.:
No person shall turn on or shut off the water at any valve, curb cock, corporation cock or other place
regulating the supply of water from the waterworks system except duly authorized employees of the city
or persons authorized to do so by the superintendent of waterworks; provided, that any licensed plumber
may turn on or shut off water for the purpose of testing his work but he shall leave the valve or curb cock
in the same condition in which he found it. (1962 Code, § 23-111)
Sec. 28-26. Approval Of Extensions, Etc.:
Any existing or future additions to or extensions of water mains or laterals using city water shall meet city
inspection, regulation and requirements, and if not approved by the city, service may be refused or
discontinued. (1962 Code, § 23-112)
Sec. 28-27. Fluoridation Of Water Supply:
Upon receiving the consent and approval of the state board of health and until further direction of the
governing body, the city is hereby authorized and directed to provide the means and to proceed with the
introduction of sufficient fluoride to raise the total fluoride concentration in the finished water to one part
of fluoride to every million parts of water being distributed in the water supply system of the city. (1962
Code, § 23-301)
Sec. 28-28. Water Conservation Provisions:
(a)Purpose: The purpose of this section is to conserve the water supply of the city of Emporia, Kansas,
to meet the needs and demands of the citizens of the city and any customers outside of the city limits
that are served by a rural water district; to provide for the declaration of a water supply emergency
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 366/510
and the implementation of voluntary and mandatory water conservation measures throughout the city
in the event such an emergency is declared; and to set forth penalties for noncompliance with this
section. This section shall only apply to water supplied by the city.
(1) It is the policy of the city to primarily maintain water supplies for potable purposes, including
drinking, sanitation, bathing and public health and safety purposes. The second priority is to ensure
adequate water supplies to maintain and promote businesses' needs and agricultural requirements
for livestock.
(2) The city shall comply with all statutory and contractual requirements, including those with the
state of Kansas. The city shall include any designations or advisories issued by the governor or state
agency in implementing the provisions of this section.
(b)Definitions: As used in this section, unless context clearly requires otherwise:
Alternate Day: Allows outside water use only on alternate days. To equalize the load on treatment
and distribution facilities, residential service areas are usually divided (by way of house numbers) into
two (2) equally sized groups and each group of customers is allowed to use water for outside uses
on specified days.
Consumer: Any person using water for any purpose from the city's water distribution system and for
which a regular charge is made.
Fountain: Includes all outdoor ornamental and decorative devices that recirculate water that are not
used for drinking purposes.
Once Per Week Watering: Not more than once every seven (7) consecutive calendar days. May also
be one specific day per week that a group of customers is allowed to use water for outside use.
Outside Watering: Includes, but is not limited to, water used for outdoor watering, either public or
private, for gardens, lawns, trees, shrubs, plants, parks, golf courses (except greens), sidewalks,
driveways, parking lot aprons, playing fields, swimming pools or other outdoor recreational areas; or
the washing of motor vehicles, boats, trailers, appliances, machinery or the exterior of any building or
structure.
Times For Outside Watering: Such times for outside watering shall be set forth in a resolution of the
governing body or as directed by the city manager in accordance with this section.
Water: Water available to the city of Emporia, Kansas, for treatment by virtue of its water rights or
any treated water introduced by the city into its water distribution system.
Water Salesman: Device or devices supplied by the city for the purchase of potable or nonpotable
water into tanks or similar large storage devices.
Wells: Devices designed to pump water from underground sources not connected to potable water
supplies, such as, but not limited to, city and rural water district water mains.
(c)Voluntary Conservation Measures: In the event it is determined by the city manager that it is
necessary and prudent in order to protect the water supply for public potable purposes, the city
manager may decide to implement voluntary conservation measures. Voluntary water restrictions
may include, but not be limited to, limitations on the following uses:
(1) Alternate day watering for all grass except golf course greens and tees, which may be watered
daily as necessary to protect the grass. Watering not more than once per week for all other types of
vegetation.
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 367/510
(2) Times for outside watering, but not less than between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
(3) Request citizens and businesses reduce water usage, such as repair of household leaks within
forty eight (48) hours and installing and/or using water saving devices.
(d)City Responsibility In Event Of Voluntary Water Restrictions: In the event a water watch is issued or
the city manager institutes voluntary water restrictions, the city shall:
(1) Provide notice of the voluntary water restrictions in the official city newspaper, notify local media,
and provide notice on the city outlets, including, but not limited to, the city's website, Facebook page,
Twitter account, water bills and signage;
(2) Make occasional news releases to the local media describing present conditions and indicating
the water supply outlook for the remainder of the season;
(3) Advertise water saving tips in the local media and on city outlets;
(4) Contact plumbers requesting that they make leak repairs their highest priority;
(5) Repair water mains as soon as possible with a goal of within forty eight (48) hours of detection;
(6) Monitor its use of water and curtail nonessential activities, such as hydrant flushing and street
cleaning.
(e)Declaration Of A Water Warning: In the event the city manager makes a recommendation to the
governing body that additional water restrictions are necessary, the governing body of the city shall
be empowered to declare by resolution that a water warning exists and include in each resolution the
mandatory conservation measures that are to be included during the period of the warning. Such a
warning period shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by resolution by the governing body to
have ended. The resolutions declaring the existence and end of a water warning shall take effect
upon publication in the official city newspaper.
(f)Mandatory Conservation Measures: Upon approval of a resolution declaring a water warning as
provided in subsection (e) of this section, as directed by the governing body, the city manager is
authorized to implement mandatory water conservation measures, including:
(1) Phase I:
a. Watering of vegetation once per week on the day established by the city (excludes commercial
and industrial production);
b. Times for outside watering, but not less than between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M.;
c. Residential, commercial and industrial leaks shall be repaired within forty eight (48) hours;
d. Golf courses, soccer fields and similar recreational facilities shall restrict watering of all areas
necessary to follow the industry standards to maintain the integrity of the vegetation;
e. Greenhouses and commercial nurseries shall restrict watering to the minimum necessary to
protect plants. Greenhouses and commercial nurseries shall curtail all nonessential water use and
use recognized conservation practices of the industry;
f. Refilling outdoor swimming pools once per week and only after sunset;
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 368/510
g. Washing vehicles, equipment and similar devices at residences or businesses other than
commercial car and truck washes shall only be permitted by handheld bucket or hose and only for
the purposes of maintenance and repair of equipment;
h. Outside use of water for cleaning buildings, streets, sidewalks, parking lots and similar areas
shall be prohibited;
i. Fountains may operate if they recirculate water but not during windy periods. Fountains that do
not recirculate water shall not be operated;
j. Rates for the water salesmen shall be increased fifty percent (50%) from normal rates;
k. Waste of water shall be prohibited.
(2) Phase II:
a. Watering of vegetation once per week on the day established by the city (excludes commercial
and industrial production);
b. Times for outside watering, but not less than between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M.;
c. Residential, commercial and industrial leaks shall be repaired within twenty four (24) hours;
d. Golf courses, soccer fields and similar recreational facilities shall restrict watering of all areas
necessary to follow the industry standards to maintain the integrity of the vegetation;
e. Refilling outdoor swimming pools shall be prohibited. Chemical applications sufficient to meet
the public health requirements shall be maintained;
f. Washing vehicles, equipment and similar devices at residences and businesses other than
commercial car and truck washes shall be prohibited;
g. Outside use of water for cleaning buildings, streets, sidewalks, parking lots and similar areas
shall be prohibited;
h. All fountains shall be shut off;
i. Rates for the water salesmen shall be increased one hundred percent (100%) from normal rates;
j. Businesses and government agencies that exceed two hundred thousand (200,000) gallons in
the most current billing period and have used more than their average amount of water used for
the same period in the previous three (3) calendar years shall prepare and submit water
conservation plans to the city with a target of reducing water by five percent (5%), including
specific action steps such as, but not limited to, installation of water saving devices, developing
more efficient water operations and providing information to employees on how to reduce water
usage. Customers that have multiple meters shall be calculated based on the aggregate amount of
water used in all meters;
k. Waste of water shall be prohibited;
l. The governing body shall have the power to adopt emergency water rates designed to conserve
water supplies. Such emergency rates may provide for, but not be limited to, uniform charges for
water usage per unit of use (uniform unit rate);
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 369/510
m. Any other restrictions the governing body determines are necessary and prudent to protect the
water supply shall be established.
(g)City Responsibility In Event Of Water Warning: In the event a water warning is declared, the city shall:
(1) Provide notice of the mandatory water restrictions in the official city newspaper, notify local media,
and provide notice on the city outlets, including, but not limited to, the city's website, Facebook page,
Twitter account, water bills and signage;
(2) Make occasional news releases to the local media describing present conditions and indicating
the water supply outlook for the remainder of the season;
(3) Advertise water saving tips in the local media and on city outlets;
(4) Contact plumbers requesting that they make leak repairs their highest priority;
(5) Contact lawn care companies to request help for customers to alter their watering schedule and
to discourage new lawn seeding or sodding;
(6) Contact commercial car and truck washes to post information from the city in a visible location
regarding drought conditions and water conservation activities;
(7) The city will encourage the use of recycling systems and other conservation techniques available
to commercial and industrial businesses;
(8) The city will provide free mulch when available and encourage homeowners to utilize mulch to
reduce the need for watering;
(9) All public and semipublic restroom and shower facilities shall provide urgent conservation
messages;
(10) All lodging facilities shall provide guests with water conservation information at the time of
registration. All lodging facilities shall offer guests the voluntary option of not having sheets and
towels changed during multinight stays;
(11) Repair water mains as soon as possible with a goal of within twenty four (24) hours of detection;
(12) Monitor its use of water and curtail nonessential activities, including, but not limited to, hydrant
flushing, street cleaning, watering of vegetation except as is necessary to maintain the life of the
vegetation, and any other use of water deemed nonessential by the city manager;
(13) Notify the county emergency manager to begin the process of declaring a countywide
emergency.
(h)Declaration Of A Water Emergency: In the event the state reduces the amount of water provided to
the city or the city manager makes a recommendation to the governing body that additional water
restrictions are necessary, the governing body shall be empowered to declare by resolution that a
water emergency exists and the mandatory conservation measures to be included during the period
of the emergency. Such an emergency period shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by
resolution of the governing body to have ended. The resolutions declaring the existence and end of a
water supply emergency shall take effect upon publication in the official city newspaper.
(i)Mandatory Conservation Measures: Upon the approval of a resolution declaring a water emergency as
provided in subsection (h) of this section, the city manager is authorized to implement certain
mandatory water conservation measures, including all commercial and industrial businesses, in the
following descending order:
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 370/510
(1) Waste of water shall be prohibited;
(2) Encourage businesses to reduce water usage and to install water saving devices;
(3) Watering of outside vegetation shall be prohibited, including all city property. Seeding and sodding
of lawns shall be prohibited;
(4) Installation of water saving devices in governmental facilities designated by the city manager,
such as, but not limited to, waterless urinals and faucet aerators;
(5) Refilling outdoor swimming pools shall be prohibited. Chemical applications sufficient to meet
public health requirements shall be maintained;
(6) Outside use of water for cleaning buildings, streets, sidewalks, parking lots and similar uses shall
be prohibited;
(7) Washing vehicles, equipment and similar devices at residences and businesses shall be
prohibited;
(8) Issuance of hydrant meters and use of water for construction purposes shall be prohibited;
(9) Water to commercial car and truck washes shall be shut off unless a conservation plan approved
by the city is on file;
(10) Businesses and governmental agencies designated in water warning phase II shall implement
the approved conservation plan;
(11) The water salesmen shall only be permitted for household use. Residents shall first obtain a
permit and shall be limited to a maximum of one thousand (1,000) gallons per week until the
emergency is lifted or water is available to the property;
(12) The governing body shall have the power to adopt emergency water rates designed to conserve
water supplies. Such emergency rates may provide for, but not be limited to, uniform charges for
water usage per unit of use (uniform unit rate);
(13) Any other restrictions the governing body determines is necessary and prudent to protect the
water supply shall be established.
(j)City Responsibility In Event Of Water Emergency: In the event a water emergency is declared, the city
shall:
(1) Provide notice of the mandatory water restrictions in the official city newspaper, notify local media,
and provide notice on the city outlets, including, but not limited to, the city's website, Facebook page,
Twitter account, water bills and signage;
(2) Make daily news releases to the local media describing present conditions and indicating the
water supply outlook for the remainder of the season;
(3) Advertise water saving tips in the local media and on city outlets;
(4) Hold periodic public meetings to discuss the emergency, the status of the city's water supply and
further actions that may be taken;
(5) All lodging facilities shall place information regarding water conservation in each room. All lodging
facilities shall offer guests the voluntary option of not having sheets and towels changed during
multinight stays;
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 371/510
(6) Ask commercial and industrial users to prepare plans for reducing the amount of water they may
use;
(7) Repair water mains as quickly as possible;
(8) Close the Jones Aquatic Center;
(9) Monitor its use of water and curtail nonessential activities;
(10) Seek additional emergency supplies from Lake Kahola, other users and the state and federal
government;
(11) Notify the county emergency manager to request a declaration of a countywide emergency.
(k)Commercial And Industrial Program: Upon the declaration of a water emergency as provided in
subsection (h) of this section, the city manager is also authorized to coordinate with local commercial
and industrial water users and rural water districts concerning the mandatory conservation measures
as set forth in subsections (f) and (i) of this section. The city manager is empowered to promulgate
such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this section, any water
emergency resolution, or emergency water rate ordinance. Such regulations shall be subject to the
approval of the governing body at its next regular or emergency meeting. The city shall first maintain
water supplies for hospitals and medical offices; government offices; schools; college facilities;
recreational facilities including indoor pools; designated cooling centers; private wastewater systems;
and other buildings and locations deemed essential by the county emergency manager.
(l)Violations, Disconnections And Penalties:
(1) If the city manager or other city official charged with implementation and enforcement of this
section or a water emergency resolution learns of any violation of any water use restrictions imposed
pursuant to subsections (f) and (i) of this section, a written notice of violation shall be affixed to the
property where the violation occurred and mailed to the consumer of record and to any other person
known to the city who is responsible for the violation or its correction.
(2) The notice shall describe the violation and order that it be corrected, cured or abated immediately
or within such specified time as the city determines is reasonable under the circumstances. If the
order is not complied with, the city may terminate water service to the consumer subject to the
following procedures:
a. The city shall give the consumer notice in accordance with subsection (l)(1) of this section that
water service will be discontinued within a specified time, but not less than five (5) days, and that
the consumer will have the opportunity to appeal the termination by requesting a hearing
scheduled before the city clerk, designated as a hearing officer by the governing body;
b. If such a hearing is requested by the consumer charged with the violation, he or she shall be
given a full opportunity to be heard before the termination is ordered; and
c. If a request for hearing is not served on the city clerk within five (5) business days following the
date of the mailing of the written notice on the accused party or if the city clerk finds that the
allegations of such notice are true, water service will be terminated and additional monetary
penalties shall be imposed. This monetary penalty shall be as provided below in addition to the
normal city reconnection fee as established by administrative regulation and responsibility for the
payment of water previously used. All of these financial obligations must be met before water
service shall be resumed. The monetary penalties set forth are as follows:
1. Upon a first violation, a fee in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00).
1/15/2020 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/KS/Emporia/index.htm 372/510
2. Upon a second violation, a fee in the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00).
3. Upon a third violation, and any subsequent violations, a fee in the sum of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00).
(3) In the event a water emergency has been declared by the governing body, the city manager shall
be permitted to terminate water service immediately until the violation has been cured or abated or a
hearing held by the city clerk, after which the water service may be turned on following payment of
any fines or penalties and the city reconnection fees have been paid. (Ord. 89-10, § 1, 4-19-1989;
Ord. 13-18, 6-19-2013)
Sec. 28-29. Fire Protection Lines:
Fire hydrants located on private property including all line extensions, tap and saddle, valve, tee and all
appurtenances to serve such hydrants from the main water line shall be paid for and maintained by the
user or developer and shall be installed in accordance with city standards. Fire hydrants located within
the right of way or within public utility easements and all appurtenances from the main shall be paid for
and maintained by the city at large. Domestic water service may be tapped from a private fire protection
line (either sprinkler or fire line) provided that an engineer licensed with the state shall certify the fire
department that it is acceptable, based on the size and use to do so.
Failure of such combination fire/domestic lines to function properly shall be the responsibility of the
property owner and the city assumes no liability. Any leak on private fire/sprinkler lines shall be the
responsibility of the owner to repair. Failure to repair a leak within a reasonable amount of time may
result in water service being discontinued from said service until the leak is repaired. (Ord. 98-10, § 1, 4-
1-1998)
Secs. 28-30-28-40. Reserved:

Sec. 28-44. Wholesale Rate:
Wholesale water consumers shall pay the following rates for water furnished them by the city:
(1) For water furnished within the city a monthly service charge according to the schedule
established by subsection 28-41(1) of this division and in addition thereto all water usage shall be
charged at the rate of ninety cents ($0.90) per one thousand (1,000) gallons; and
(2) For water furnished outside the city, a monthly service charge according to the schedule
established by subsection (1) of this section and in addition thereto all water usage shall be charged
at the rate of ninety cents ($0.90) per one thousand (1,000) gallons. (1962 Code, § 23-202A; Ord.
945, § 1, 4-18-1979; Ord. 06-37, § 4, 12-20-2006)
